A.   Sections show a fatty tumour which appears circumscribed.  It consists of sheets and also some lobules of adipocytes, with some intervening bands of dense fibrous tissue.  The tumour has been extensively sampled.  There is moderate variability in size and shape of adipocytes but no lipoblasts are identified and no atypical cells areidentified in the fibrous bands or elsewhere.  There are no histologic features to suggest malignancy.  The tumour appeared well circumscribed macroscopically but histologically itabuts excision margins.  Adequacy of excision is difficult to assess.  Focally at the edge of the tumour there may be some extension into adjacent skeletal muscle (blocks O5, O5); this is a feature described in intramuscular lipomas.

I favour a diagnosis of intramuscular lipoma rather than atypical lipomatous tumour.  A tissue block will be sent to WARIALDA MULTIPURPOSE SERVICE's Hospital for FISH to look for MDM2 amplification; such amplification is identifiable in most atypical lipomatous tumours/ well differentiated lipoma-like liposarcomas, but is absent in benign tumours (Sirvent et al. Am J Surg Pathol 2007; 31:1476-89).  A supplementary report will be issued.
The histologic features do not fit for a hibernoma.

Sections of the tumour show similar appearances to that seen inthe previously excised left colon tumour (24O65140). It has a lobulated contour and is composed of pleomorphic malignant spindled, stellate and multinucleated cells. In most areas, these malignant cells appear to be haphazardly arrangedwhile whorled structures are seen in other areas. Scattered foci of osteosarcomatous component are present (Block 17). The surrounding fatty tissue show adipocytic cells with mild size variation in which atypical hyperchromatic cells are seen in the stroma of their fibrocollagenous septae. The aggregate of features is consistent with that of a malignant sarcoma with a dedifferentiated liposarcoma arising from a well differentiated sclerosing type liposarcoma being favoured.
The dedifferentiated component is present at the inferior margin (Block 12) and appears clear of all the other margins.
The well-differentiated component is present at the superficial (Block 2), 3 o'clock (Block 6)and superior (Blocks 8 and 14) margins.
MDM2 amplification study may be helpful.

A.  Sections show a high grade endometrial carcinoma consisting predominately of sheets of tumour cells with pleomorphic nuclei containing vesicular chromatin and occasional prominent nucleoli.  Numerous multinucleated forms with occasional bizarre nuclear pleomorphism are seen.  Extensive mitoses and necrosis are present.  Focally admixed with the high grade tumour are deposits of endometrioid adenocarcinoma showing focal squamous differentiation.  Extensive carcinoma in situ is also present of both endometrioid and serous type.  The tumour mainly forms an exophytic mass on the anterior wall of the uterus however, tumour invades to a depth of 10mm through a wall thickness of 16mm.  Focal lymphovascular invasion is seen.  The endocervix is uninvolved and the ectocervix shows ulceration consistent with prolapse.  The overall features are that of a predominately anaplastic/undifferentiated carcinoma with focal endometrioid and serous components.  The remainder of the uterus shows multiple calcified leiomyomas.

There is no atypical ductal hyperplasia, DCIS or evidence of invasive malignancy.

A.  Sections of omentum show small deposits of carcinoma with a papilliform architecture with occasional psammoma bodies.The nuclei show mild pleomorphism with occasional intranuclear inclusions.  The appearances favour serous adenocarcinoma.

B.  Sections of the uterus show endometrial adenocarcinoma comprising well formed glandular elements lined by columnar cells.  Focal mucinous differentiation is present.  The nuclei focally have high grade features with clear chromatin and prominent nucleoli.  The appearance of this carcinoma is that ofendometrioid adenocarcinoma with grade 1 architecture and grade 3 nuclei giving an overall grade of 2.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.  Carcinoma invades to a depth of 9mm through a wall thickness of 11mm.  The ectocervix and endocervix show no significant abnormality.  Both ovaries show benign serous cystadenomas and both fallopian tubes show no significant abnormality.

The morphological appearance of the carcinomas within the omentum and endometriumare different and are thus favoured to be synchronous tumours of primary peritoneal serous adenocarcinoma and endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium.
This case has been reviewed by Dr Q Cauterucci.
A & B.  Cervix, uterus, tubes and ovaries, omentum:
-  Primary peritoneal serous adenocarcinoma of the omentum
-  Grade 2 endometrioid adenocarcinoma of the endometrium
-  Invasion to a depth of 9mm through a wall thickness of 11mm
-  Benign serous cystadenomas of the ovaries

The findings of a glial lesion composed of markedly pleomorphic tumour cells with low proliferative activity. This case was analysed for 1p/19q LOH using Vysis dual colour probe sets LSI 1p36/LSI 1q25 and LSI 19q13/19p13.  Cut-off values were adopted from Smith et al. 2000 (J Clin Oncol:18;636-645) who defined a 1p/1q ratio of <0.85 and a 19q/19p ratio of <0.9 as indicating LOH.  The case was also hybridised with Vysis LSI EGFR/Cep7 dual colour probe pair to assess whether amplification of EGFR was present.
Mean copies of EGFR per cell:  3.81
Interpretation:  No EGFR amplification present polysomic.
CONCLUSION:  Negative for both 1p/19q loss and EGFR amplification.

Report from RHW Pathology, Department of CORONARY CARE UNIT, MCLAREN VALE:

57 year old man with a previous history of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid treated with resection and radiotherapy to the neck.  Now two separate intracerebral lesions, a complex enhancing lesion in the left posterior frontal periventricular white matter with surrounding oedema.  A second exophytic non-enhancing lesion in the corpus callosum protrudes from the genu into the right frontal horn.

Thirty nine (39) slides labelled "62S02144 JUAN" were received including 2 intraoperative smears ("A" and "B"), 2 haematoxylin and eosin stained frozen sections ("F/S A" and "F/S B"), 11 haematoxylin and eosin stained paraffin sections ("AFS1", "BFS1", "C1", "C1 recut 1-6", "C2", "Dl"), 2 sections stained for reticulin ("C1" and "D1"), 17 sections from block C1 immunostained for NeuN, chromogranin A, 68kD neurofilament protein, p53, GFAP (x2), synaptophysin, vimentin (x2), CD34, Ki-67, IDHIR132H, MIC2, pancytokeratin, CD68, EMA and TTFI, and 5 sections from block D1 immunostained for 68kD neurofilament protein, lDH132H, pancytokeratin, CD34 and TTFI.
B and D (Left periventricular frontal tumour).

Multiple fragments of tumour consisting of moderately pleomorphic elongated cells, predominantly arranged in interweaving bundles.  Scattered cells with nuclear pseudoinclusions are identified.  Mitoses are easily found and the Ki-67 labelling index is approximately 20-30%.  Foci of necrosis are present and there is prominent microvascular proliferation.  Compared to the right frontal tumour (see below) this lesion is more cellular and the cells more uniform and less pleomorphic.
Special stains demonstrate perivascular reticulin only and highlight the microvascular proliferation.  The tumour cells are strongly Vimentin positive and many are also GFAP positive.

There is moderate granular membranous and some cytoplasmic MIC2 staining. CD34 stains endothelial cells.  There is a small amount of focal patchy interstitial staining, although this is much less prominent than in the contralateral lesion (see:below).  Scattered strongly p53 : positive cells are noted, probably <5%. Compared to the contralateral lesion there are also more numerous weakly staining cells.

The majority ofthe tumour cells are negative for EMA although very rare cells, especially at periphery of several tissue fragments contain an EMA-positive paranuclear dot.  Stains for NeuN, chromogranin, synaptophysin, pancytokeratin, IDH1 RI25H and TTFI are negative.
A and C (Right frontal corpus callosum tumour):

The intraoperativesmear contains two populations of cells.  The predominant component consists of cells with large round or lobated nuclei of slightly different sizes with a thin, well defined nuclear membrane, uniformly granular chromatin containing several chromcentres and often a prominent nucleolus.  Scattered binucleate cells are noted and a number of these nuclei also containing pseudoinclusions.  There is a minor component of relatively uniform cells with elongated round ended nuclei but no nucleoli.  Some -perivascular lymphocytes are noted but no vascular proliferation is seen.
The permanent sections consist of multiple pieces of tissue including fragments of normal cerebral cortex and fragments of solid tumour.

The tumour is moderately cellular and pleomorphic.  Many of the tumour cells have medium to large round or lobated nuclei with a prominent nucleolus and a small amount of well delineated perinuclear clear to granular cytoplasm.  A number also contain nuclear pseudoinclusions and several are bi- or trinucleate.  Scattered triangular cells with darkly staining amphophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei are also included as are cells with large, hyperchromatic somewhat "smudgy" chromatin, cells with ovoid nuclei and perinuclear halos, and some with finely vacuolated cytoplasm.  Although a number of these cells resemble dysplastic neurons, stains for neural antigens including neurofilament protein, NeuN, synaptophysin and chromogranin are negative.

In some areas the interstitium is finely vacuolated and slightly basophilic, suggesting mucin.  There are scattered micro-cysts and very rare calcospherites.  No Rosenthal fibres or eosinophilic granular bodies are identified with haematoxylin and eosin. No ependyma is identified.

Perivascular chronic inflammatory cells are noted, often surrounding veins with some adventitial fibrosis.  There is no vascular proliferation or necrosis and mitotic figures are not identified.  The Ki67 labelling index is low (visually estimated at approximately 2%).

Although in one fragment the tumour appears to be well demarcated from the surrounding dense paucicellular fibrillary gliosis, neurofilament antibodies highlight prominent axons bundles traversing the tumour.  These are accentuated adjacent to vessels.  In some areas beaded axons and axonalspheroids are also noted.

Special stains demonstrate perivascular reticulin only.  The GFAP staining is generally pale and most of the tumour cells do not show cytoplasmic immunoreactivity adjacent to the nucleus, although scattered GFAP positive processes are noted, especially adjacent to vessels.  These processes do not radiate towards the vessels as seen in ependymal perivascular pseudorosettes.

In addition to normal endothelial staining there is very strong, uniform CD34 immunoreactivity between the tumour cells resulting in haloes of CD34 negative cytoplasm surrounding-tumour nuclei.  Included fragments of cerebral cortex show the expected normal endothelial staining.  Vimentin also shows prominent dark interstitial staining in many of the tumourfragments, although less intense than the CD34 staining, as well as some cytoplasmic staining.  Prominent activated microglia and scattered macrophages are noted within the tumour with CD68 antibodies. Approximately 4-5% of tumour nucleiare weakly p53 positive.

NeuN identifies normal neurons in cortical fragments but not tumour cells. lmmunostains for synaptophysin, IDH R125H, chromogranin, pancytokeratin and TTFI are negative.  MIC2 (CD99) is also negative although there is high background staining.

FISH analysis (Dr R Maltez, CLONCURRY MULTI-PURPOSE HEALTH SERVICE's Hospital) on the right frontal tumour was negative for lp/19q loss although polysomy for Ip and 19q was demonstrated.  There was no EGFR amplification.
MGMT methylation analysis by pyrosequencing (Dr Koori Challis, QUILPIE HOSPITAL Cancer Centre) demonstrated MGMT promoter methylation in both tumours.
Left frontal tumour:  GLIOBLASTOMA (WHO GRADE IV)
Right frontal tumour:  DIFFUSE ASTROCYTOMA (WHO GRADE II; see Comment)

The right frontal lesion is a low grade glioma without high grade features and is best classified as a diffuse astrocytoma (WHO grade II).  However, a number of unusual morphological findings are noted, including the very limited GFAP staining and the strong CD34 immunoreactivity, that are not typical of most WHO grade II diffuse astrocytomas.

Although limited or absent GFAP staining is described in some subependymal giant cell astrocytomas, there are no other features supporting this diagnosis.  Similarly, although CD34 immunoreactivity is a feature of many glioneuronal tumours and of pleomorphic xanthoastrocytomas, the other morphologicaland immunohistochemical findings in this case do not support these diagnoses.

The relationship between the left and the right frontal lesions is uncertain.  Although they are radiologically and morphologically distinct, suggesting separate lesions, the possibility of microscopic continuity or a common origin cannot be entirely excluded. FISH analysis to assess Ip and 19q polysomy and EGFR amplification will be performed on the left frontal glioblastoma.  If clinically indicated, further genetic analysis may be helpful.

This case was reviewed by Dr Arie Perry (Director of Neuropathology, UCSF) who agreed that the left frontal lesion is a glioblastoma (WHO grade IV).  He also agreed that the right frontal tumour is unusual but considered that the features were those of a low grade tumour, best classified as a diffuse astrocytoma (WHO grade II).
commented that he had also seen low grade astrocytomas with limited GFAP immunoreactivity.  He suggested that further immunostaining for other glial markers,
including Olig-2, Sox-2 and S100, might-be helpful.

C.  Specimen labelled "Left thyroid" consists of a left hemithyroid measuring 35 x 20 x 10mm and weighing 3.6g.  The anterior margin is inked blue and the tracheal margin is inked black.  On sectioning multiple 2mm to 3mm pale areas are identified.  AE from superior to inferior in 6 blocks.

A.  Sections of right lobe of thyroid show two separate foci of papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 10mm and 4mm respectively.  The larger tumour (designated as tumour 1) was sampled for frozen section.  Tumour 1 shows a mixed papillary and follicular architecture.  Tumour 2 shows follicular architecture only.  No solid/insular architecture is seen.  No coagulative necrosis is seen.  Both tumours are well circumscribed but not encapsulated.  There is no evidence of vascular invasion.  No extra-thyroidal extension is seen.  The tumour 1 is confined within the thyroid and is completely excised.  The tumour 2 is present focally at the surgical resection margin, indicating microscopic residual disease (block A7).  The thyroid tissueaway from the tumour shows Hashimoto's thyroiditis/lymphocytic thyroiditis.  No parathyroid tissue is seen.  Two (2) small lymph nodes are present within the soft tissueattached to the right lobe.  The lymph nodes are unremarkable.  There is no evidence of tumour metastasis.

B.  One (1) lymph node is identified.  Several Psammoma body type calcifications are present but no actual papillary carcinoma cells are seen.  In the right clinical setting, this is considered as positive tumour metastasis.

C.  Sections of left lobe of thyroid show three separate foci of papillary thyroid carcinoma measuring 3mm, 2mm and 1mm respectively.  All the tumours show follicular architecture only.  No solid/insular architecture is seen.  No coagulative necrosis is seen.  All tumours are well circumscribed but not encapsulated.  There is no evidence of vascular invasion.  No extra-thyroidal extension is seen.  All the tumours are confined within the thyroid and are completely excised.  The thyroid tissue away from the tumour shows Hashimoto's thyroiditis/lymphocytic thyroiditis.  No parathyroid tissue is seen.

D.  Six (6) lymph nodes are identified.  The lymph nodes are unremarkable.  A small piece of thyroid tissue is also present with thyroiditis/lymphocytic thyroiditis.  There is no evidence of tumour metastasis.
A.  Right hemithyroid - Papillary thyroid carcinoma.
B.  Lymph node - Metastatic papillary carcinoma (see text).
C.  Left thyroid - Papillary thyroid carcinoma.
D.  Centralneck node - No evidence of malignancy (0/6).
Location:  DICKINSON 2 SOUTH-YEA AND DISTRICT MEMORIAL HOSPITAL

A.  The specimen has been entirely embedded and examined.  The specimen comprises fibroadipose tissue, subcutis, skeletal muscle and some fascia.  Adjacent to this short sutured margin (towards tumour) there is organising granulation tissue, fibrosis, chronic inflammation and fat necrosis consistent with previous surgery.  Within this area there are vascular changes consistent with previous radiotherapy including mural hyalinisation and intimal myxoid alteration.  Scattered within the area adjacent to the short sutured margin and within septa between skeletal muscle bundles, there are dispersed spindle and stellate cells with a generally low nuclear cytoplasmic ratio, mild nuclear atypia and some fine cytoplasmic vacuolation.  Some cells have a ganglion cell-like appearance.  These cells are favoured to represent fibroblast/myofibroblasts with mild atypia secondary to radiotherapy.  Occasional similar cells are seen withinfat lobules, however, no definite lipoblasts, significant variation in adipocyte cell size or markedly atypical stromal cells are seen.  No diagnostic evidence of residual sarcoma is seen.
The previous excision (89F79143) was reviewed when reporting this case.
The case was seen in consultation with Dr W Vollenweider whoconcurs.
B.  The specimen comprises fragments of viable lamellar bone, fibroadipose tissue and skeletal muscle.  No evidence of sarcoma is seen.

C.  The specimen has been entirely embedded and examined.  Sections show skin to subcutis.  There is  a dermal subcutaneous scar , fat necrosis and a number of suture granulomas.  No convincing evidence of residual sarcoma is seen.

Sections show a circumscribed tumour within submucosa and partly ulcerating the overlying mucosa.  The tumour is of low to moderate cellularity and consists of spindle shaped cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, in haphazard fascicles.  The cells have themorphologic appearance of smooth muscle cells and this is confirmed with strong positive staining for desmin.  Stains for C-Kit (CD117) and CD34 are negative.  No mitoses are identified and the proliferation index with a K-67 stain is very low, <1%.  The appearances are of a leiomyoma.  There isno significant atypia and there is no evidence of malignancy.  Excision is complete.  The overlying mucosa shows features of a severe chronic gastritis.  No Helicobacter is identified.  The gastritis may be non-specific, related to the mass lesion, but there is associated prominentatrophy of specialised gastric glands and the possibility of an autoimmune gastritis should be considered.  There is no intestinal metaplasiaor dysplasia.
2.  Severe chronic gastritis with gland atrophy, see text.

Sections show a well circumscribed 60mm tumour consistent with a renal oncocytoma. The tumour is composed of relatively monomorphic cells with abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests, tubules and lining cystic spaces. Mitoses are not prominent.In some areas the rounded tumour cell nests are surrounded by loose myxoid stroma.
The tumour abuts but does not invade the renal capsule.
The ureteric and vascular resection margins are clear.

The surrounding renal parenchyma shows patchy mild chronic interstitial inflammation and scattered sclerosed glomeruli, particularly around the edge of the tumour, possibly reflecting local compressive changes. Elsewhere the renal parenchyma appears unremarkable.
The tumour is negative for Hale's colloidal iron staining. Immunoperoxidase staining is positive for CD117 and negative for CD10, CK7 and vimentin.
These features are consistent with a renal oncocytoma. Dr Richard Jin has also seen this case and agrees with this diagnosis.

A. Four lymph nodes identified show no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.

B. The solitary tumour identified macroscopically shows features of a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma. It is composed of nests and trabeculae of malignant hepatocytes with increased nuclear pleomorphism,prominent nucleoli, moderate amount of clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm and frequent mitoses. Hepatocellular carcinoma abuts the liver capsule focally but capsular perforation is not seen. Carcinoma is 0.5mm from the closest surgical resection margin. No obvious lymphovascular invasion is identified. Special stains (Reticulin and Perl's iron) reveal markedly thickened liver cell plates and absence of iron deposition within the tumour. On immunohistochemistry, the tumour shows positive staining with Hepar-1 and AFP, and negative staining with CK7 and CK20. Polyclonal CEA shows a canalicular staining pattern while CD34 highlights the endothelial-lined trabeculae of the tumour.

The uninvolved liver parenchyma shows preservation of normal lobular architecture. There is a mild lymphocytic infiltrate within the portal tracts but no significant interphase or lobular inflammation is noted. There is a mild expansion of the portal tracts without septa formation. The METAVIR activity and fibrosis scores are A0 and F1 respectively. The orcein special stain and Hepatitis B surface antigen immunostain are positive, in keeping with the clinical history. No furthersignificant pathology is noted with the remaining special stains (PAS, PAS/D, Masson, reticulin, Perl's iron and rhodanine). There is no evidence of cirrhosis.

Sections of the gall bladder show mild wall thickening associated with mild chronic inflammation.  Mild Rokitansky Aschoff sinus formation is present.  The appearance is consistent with mild chronic cholecystitis.  There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.
- NO EVIDENCE OF METASTATIC CARCINOMA IN FOUR LYMPH NODES (0/4)

There is a small amount of uninvolved endometrium and this shows features of exogenous hormone effect.
Sections of the ovaries and fallopian tubes are unremarkable.

B.  Sections show a grade 3 endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma which fills and expands the the uterine cavity and is wildly invasive extending into the outer half of the myometrium of the uterus in both the anterior and posteriorhalves.  The tumour shows extensive solid and trabecular architecture with a lesser component of glandular architecture.  There is also moderate squamous differentiation.  There is extensive tumour necrosis predominantly superficially and centrally within tumour nests.  Focally there is an area of sheet-like growth in which tumour cells display more pronounced nuclear pleomorphism, vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli (block B17). At its deepest point of invasion, in an area where the myometrium is relatively thin, the tumour extends close to the serosal surface, 22.8mm through a myometrium 23mm thick (B25).  Elsewhere the tumour invades 41.5mm through myometrium 48.5mm in maximal thickness B10/B11). The serosa does not appear involved by tumour.  There is extensive lymphovascular invasion both within the inner and outer half of the myometrium.  No definite perineural invasion is seen.  The cervix is uninvolved by tumour.  The uterus also shows several leiomyomata including a lipoleiomyoma which is focally invaded by carcinoma.  A leiomyoma is also present in the posterior lower segment expanding the stromal compartment of the cervix.  The ectocervix and endocervix are otherwise unremarkarkable and uninvolved by tumour. The mucosa of the left fallopian tube is expanded by foamy histiocytes, however, no carcinoma is seen.  The right fallopian tube is unremarkable.  The right and left ovaries are unremarkable and uninvolved.  Within the right parametrium there are two leiomyomas.
C.  The cystic area in the omentum described is an area of cystic fat necrosis.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

The surface of the skin has a linear scar measuring 85mm and otherwise looks unremarkable.  There are three sutures (short - deep  inferior margin, double - iliac crest, long - superior or 12 o'clock).  The muscle measures 100 x 60 x 50mm and the serosal surface of the muscle is dull with nodular soft tan outgrowths. On sectioning there is a variegated tan to opaque yellow tumour within the muscle.  The tumour measures 40 x 30 x 25mm and the margins are as follows:  abuts the iliac crest, and inferior - deep (6 o'clock) margin, 10mm from the 3 o'clock margin, 10mm from the 9 o'clock margin, 50mm from the 12 o'clock margin and abutting the inferior or 6 o'clock margin.

Blocks: 1 & 2 - 6 o'clock margin; 3 & 4 - 12 o'clock margin; 5 & 6 - (paired blocks) representative skin to subcutaneous fat; 7 - tumour and closest iliac crest and deep margin; 8 & 9 - adjacent blocks; 10 to 13 - (paired blocks) tumour and 3, 9, iliac crest and deep margins; 14 - closest 9 o'clock margin.

B.  Specimen labelled "Right peritoneal mass" consists of an encapsulated smooth solid pale yellow mass measuring 130 x 100 x 45mm. Onsectioning the cut surface shows a homogenous pale yellow cut surface with ill defined lobules.  There are no areas of haemorrhage or necrosis.  Representative in 12 blocks.

C.  Specimen labelled "Small bowel nodule" consists of a nodule of fibrofatty tissue measuring 25 x 20 x 15mm.  The outer surface is smooth lined and there is a ragged area (surgical defect).  The surgical defect inked black.  On sectioning the nodule is composed of lobules of pale yellow fatty tissue.  No areas of necrosis or haemorrhage are identified.   Specimen is serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

A.  Sections show a high grade sarcoma with mixed appearances.  Part of tumour (less than 5%) shows well differentiated liposarcoma.  The rest of tumour (more than 95%) shows undifferentiated high grade sarcoma.  There is abrupt transition between well differentiated liposarcoma and high grade non-lipogenic area.  Within the undifferentiated high grade component, there are large areas of necrosis.  Frequent mitoses, marked nuclear pleomorphism and invasion of skeletal muscle are seen.  No obvious heterologous elements are seen.  The appearances are consistent with those of dedifferentiated liposarcoma.  The tumour is incompletely excised.  The tumour focally involves the 9 o'clock margin (block A11).  The tumour is less than 0.5mm to the iliac crest/deep margin (block A7) and is less than 1mm to the 6 o'clock margin (block A2).
B.  Sections show a well differentiated liposarcoma (adipocytic type).  The tumour is incompletely excised.  The tumour extends to the resection margin over a broad area.
C.  Sections show a well differentiated liposarcoma (adipocytic type).  The tumour is incompletely excised.  The tumour extends to the resection margin over a broad area.
D.  Sections show an undifferentiated high grade sarcoma invading skeletal muscle.  There is marked crushing artefact.  The deep iliac crest margin is involved.
A.  Intra abdominal sarcoma - Dedifferentiated liposarcoma.
B.  Right peritoneal mass - Well differentiated liposarcoma.
C.  Small bowel nodule - Well differentiated liposarcoma.
D.  Deep iliac crest margin - Dedifferentiated liposarcoma.

The uterus measures 70 x 50 x 30mm and has a smooth and shiny serosal surface.  The ectocervix measures 30 x 20mm and has an unremarkable surface.  On sectioning the endometrium is 1mm in maximum thickness and the myometrium is 12mm in maximum thickness.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  The right fallopian tube and fimbria measures 60mm in length and 5mm in maximum diameter.  The right ovary measures 20 x 7 x 7mm and has an unremarkable cut surface.  The left fallopian tube and fimbria measures 55mm in length and 5mm in maximum diameter.  The left ovary measures 25 x 10 x 7mm and has an unremarkable cut surface.

Blocks: 1 to 3 - one full LS anterior body and cervix; 4 to 6 - one full LS posterior body and cervix; 7 - right fimbria andfallopian tube; 8 - right ovary AE; 9 - left ovary AE; 10 - left fimbria and left fallopian tube.

A.  The ectocervix and endocervix show no significant abnormality.  The endometrium is weakly proliferative.  A single leiomyoma is identified within the myometrium.  Foci of psammomatous calcification are seen on the serosal surface of the uterus, right and left fallopian tubes and ovary. The ovaries and fallopian tubes otherwise show no significant abnormality. There is no evidence of malignancy.

B.  Sections show a rounded nodule of foamy histiocytes with a central region of necrosis.  Scattered foci of psammomatous calcification are present throughout the nodule. There is no evidence of malignancy.

C.  The omentum is extensively sampled revealing a single very small deposit of adenocarcinoma embedded within omental fat.  The tumour cells have pleomorphic nuclei with eosinophilic macronucleoli suggestive of serous adenocarcinoma.  Small collections of foamy histiocytes and occasional foci of psammomatous calcification are also seen.

The presence of foamy histiocytes and residual psammomatous calcification are consistent with therapy effect.  The distribution of the psammomatous calcification together with the very small focus of adenocarcinoma within omentum are suggestive of a primary peritoneal serous adenocarcinoma.
A - C.  Uterus and cervix, tubes and ovaries, omentum:
-  Very small focus of residualserous adenocarcinoma within the omentum.
-  Residual psammomatous calcification and therapy effect.

Specimen labelled "L chest wall lesion short stich superior single long 1st rib double long 2nd rib", consists of a specimen of skin (105 x 40mm) subcutaneous fatty tissue and muscle (120 x 100 x 40mm), upper sternum (70 x 35 x 20mm), medial end of clavicle (30 x12 x 12mm), anteromedial end of 1st rib (52 x 20 x 17mm) and anteromedial end of 2ndrib (35 x 15 x 10mm).  The upper sternum measures (70 x 35 x 20mm).  There are three marking stitches as described.  There is a 75mm long elliptical scar on the skin. There is a tan solid mass expanding the manubrium (slices three and four), measuring 25 x 15 x 10mm.  This mass is well-defined andis 3mm from the anterior and 16mm from the posterior surfaces.

There is also a cavity anterior to and abutting the sternum, and slightly superior to the 2nd rib, measuring 30 x 20 x 18mm (slices five to seven).  The cavity is partially filled with soft haemorrhagic material.  It is 11mm from the superficial and 6mm from the deep margin, and is well away from all other margins.

Blocks: 1 - representative slice one (lateral margin); 2 - cavity on superficial margin slice three; 3 - inferior margin slice three; 4 and 5 - paired sections skin and cavity; 6 - deep margin and slice four; 7 - deep margin slice six; 8 - inferior margin slice six; 9 - skin slice seven; 10 and 11 - paired sections ?fibrotic area and deep margin (margin in block 11);12 - representative slice thirteen (medial margin) please see diagram; 13 - shave left clavicle margin; 14 first rib margin; 15 - shave left 2nd rib margin; 16 - right 1st rib shave margin; 17 & 18 - paired sections, superior 3rd of slice four (17 - superficial; 18 - deep); 19 & 20 - paired sections, superior 3rd of slice five (19 - superficial; 20 - deep); 21 to 23 - continuous section showing cavity lower manubrium and first rib, slice six; 24 - lower cavity manubrium and 2nd rib. (TO: EO;OE/vo 6.4.64)

Sections of the described cavity anterior to and abutting the sternum in the superior part of the specimen show a deposit of high grade pleomorphic sarcoma.  Thisinvolves the bone of the manubrium (block 28) and adjacent soft tissue.  It has a pushing margin and much of it is surrounded by dense fibrous tissue.  Decalcification has affected tumour preservation but it is cellular and composed of cells with large, pleomorphic nuclei and a variable amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm.  Numerous multinucleate tumour giant cells are present.  No lymphovascular invasion is identified.  Tumour abuts the first rib but the rib is not involved.  The second rib is also not involved by tumour.  Tumour within manubrium is 3mm from the deep excision margin but there is intact bone between tumour and the margin.  Other margins are well clear.

Sections of the described tan mass expanding the manubrium show dense fibrous tissue expanding and partly replacing the bone; no tumour is seen in this region.  Sections from the inferior part of the specimen show an old seroma cavity with surrounding dense fibrous tissue.  There is some old fat necrosis in the surrounding tissue, with associated mild patchy chronic inflammation.  Adjacent muscle is atrophic.  No tumour is seen in the inferior part of the specimen.
Left chest wall:  Recurrent high grade pleomorphic sarcoma involving manubrium and adjacent soft tissue.

A.Sections of the described omental and peritoneal nodules show deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma.  The tumour consists of closely packed, back to back glands and some solid areas.  The glands are lined bycolumnar epithelial cells with moderately pleomorphic, vesicular nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.  The appearances are most consistent with a metastatic endometrioid adenocarcinoma from ovary.  A section from one of the small bowel resection margins shows focal tumour cells within thickened subserosal tissue.  A section of the other small bowel resection margin is free of tumour.

B.  Sections show tumour with a similar appearance to specimen A.  The features are most consistent with an endometrioid adenocarcinoma of ovary, grade 2.  No normal ovaryis identified.  Immunostains will be performed and a supplementary report issued.

C.  Sections show omentum with extensive involvement by similar tumour to specimensA & B.  Some necrosis is noted.  There is focal squamoid differentiation.  The appearances are most consistent with metastatic endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

A.  Specimen labelled "Uterus, tubes, ovaries, cervix, rectosigmoid colon" consists of a uterus with attached cervix, right and left adnexa, attached rectosigmoid colon and mesenteric fat received en bloc.

The uterus measures 75 x 45 x 50mm.  The serosal surface of the uterus is covered in multiple fibrous adhesionswhich completely obliterate the pouch of Douglas.  The uterus is adherent to the bowel posteriorly.  On opening the uterus three endometrial uterine polyps are present measuring 15 to 45mm.  The endometrium otherwise is 1mm in maximum thickness over a total wall thickness of 30mm.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  The left adnexa contains a cystic structure measuring 45 x 40 x 30mm.  The cyst is unilocular with a wall thickness of 3mm.  Two solid cream masses are located adjacent to the cyst measuring 30 x 25 x 20mm and 13 x 10 x 12mm.  A possible fallopian tube is identified embedded withinthe larger mass.  The right adnexa contains a dark grey cystic structure measuring 45 x 35 x 25mm with a wall thickness of 5mm.  Within this cyst a tubular structure is identified ?fallopian tube.  No fimbria are identified.

The attached segment of bowel measures 355mm in length and is received entangled in a loop with multiple fibrous adhesions.  One end, the presumed proximal end, is stapled shut, while the other end is open.  The bowel wall appears indurated in areas with a maximum wall thickness of 15mm.  These indurated areas are approximately 90mm from the proximal margin and 100mm from the distal margin.  No mucosal lesions are identified.  A moderate amount of mesenteric fat is located on the posterior aspect of the specimen, measuring approximately 100 x 70mm.  Several lymph nodes are identified in the mesenteric fat.
The stapled end of the bowel is inked black.  The free end is inked blue.  Vaginal cuff margin inked blue.

A.  Sections of the cervix are unremarkable.  Sections of the endometrium show that this is thin and inactive.  The endometrial polyps are benign.  There is extensive tumour within fibrofat adherent to the serosa of the posterior uterus and within adhesions between the loops of rectosigmoid colonand the posterior uterus.  Tumour extends from the serosal surface of the uterus some distance into the underlying outer myometrium.  The tumour has features most consistent with a moderately differentiated serous carcinoma.  Some psammoma bodies are noted.  There is some evidence of treatment effect with replacement of tumour by dense fibrous tissue; there is between 10 and 50% tumour replacement by fibrous tissue.

Both ovaries are identified in sections from the right and left adnexal tissues.  There is extensive tumour withinadherent fibrous tissue on the surface of both ovaries but there is minimal tumour involvement of the deeper ovarian tissue.  Portions of both fallopian tubes are also identified in sections from both adnexa.  There is extensive tumour within soft tissue adherent to the outer surfaces of both fallopian tubes.  One section from the fimbrial end of the right tube appears to show a focus of carcinoma in situ of residual tubal epithelium (block A20); the sections of residual fallopian tube are otherwise unremarkable.

Sections from the indurated segments of the rectosigmoid colon show extensive tumour withinfibrofat adherent to the bowel serosa, and extending some distance into the underlying outer muscularis propria.  No tumour involvement of the bowel mucosa or submucosa is seen.  A total of nine lymph nodes were identified in the attached mesenteric fat and these are all free of tumour.  There is focal tumour involvement of the bowel serosa at the proximal excision margin.
B.  Sections show pieces of essentially unremarkable large intestinal wall.  No tumour is seen.
C.  Sections show omental fat with extensive involvement by poorly differentiated serous carcinoma.  There is minimal histologic evidence of treatment effect.

A.  The left ovarian tumour is a serous adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows extensive involvement of the ovarian, as well as, fallopian tube parenchyma. There are areas of serosal involvement and foci of lymphovascular space invasion. Approximately 5% of the primary tumour shows high grade cytologic atypia. There is minimal chemotherapy related change (less than 5%). There is focal uterine serosal involvement by metastatic adenocarcinoma (anterior and posterior uterus). The uterine ectocervix and endocervix show patchy mild to moderate active inflammation and tubal metaplasia. There is no convincing cervical involvement by adenocarcinoma. The endometrium appears inactive/weakly proliferative with focal polypoid cystic atrophy. The myometrium shows a hyalinised leiomyoma. The right ovary and fallopian tube show scattered detached foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma.
B.  Sectionsare of fibroadipose tissue showing extensive involvement by metastatic adenocarcinoma.
C.  Sections are of fibroadipose tissue showing extensive involvement by metastatic adenocarcinoma.

D.  Sections are of fibroadipose tissue showing extensive involvement by metastatic adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows focal clear cell change (less than 2%). There is minimal chemotherapy related change (involving approximately 5% of tumour).
E.  Sections are of fibroadipose tissue showing multifocal metastatic adenocarcinoma. There is minimal chemotherapy related change (involving approximately 5% of tumour).

F.  Sections of appendix show fibrous obliteration of the appendiceal lumen. There are multiple foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma, located within the appendiceal serosal, muscularis propria and in peri-appendiceal adipose tissue.
G.  Sections of omentum show multiple foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma.

There is minimal chemotherapy related change (less than 5%).

A.  Sections of the ovary show a poorly differentiated serous carcinoma.  This consists of sheets and trabeculae of cells forming papillae and slit-like glands.  There is some patchy tumour necrosis.  Lymphovascular invasion is noted in adjacent parovarian soft tissue.  Sections of the fallopian tube show extensive involvement of the mucosa, wall and serosa by serous carcinoma.  Much of the tumour in the tube wall is present within small lymphatic and/or blood vessels.  There is also extensive tumour involvement of the fimbrial end of the tube.  No definite carcinoma in situ of the residual tubal epithelium is identified.  The tumour in the fallopian tube could be metastatic from the ovary or could be part of a field effect in the Mullerian epithelium.

B.  A section of the posterior cervix shows extensive involvement by serous carcinoma; this involvement extends from the serosal/adventitial aspect and there is extensive lymphovascular invasion.  Thelining mucosa of the cervix is not involved.  The serous carcinoma extends to the inferior excision margin of the posterior cervix.  A section of the anterior cervix also shows patchy tumour involvement just beneath the serosal/adventitial surface.

Sections of the endometrium show that this is thin and inactive.  The described endometrial polyp is benign.  There is prominent lymphovascular invasion by serous carcinoma in the outer myometrium and there is extensive involvement of the outer fundal myometrium by serous carcinoma.  Sections from the right posterior cornual region show extensive myometrial involvement by serous carcinoma, with prominent lymphovascular invasion.  There is also a focal, minor component of clear cell carcinoma in the myometrial tumour (blockB17).  Leiomyomas are confirmed in the myometrium.

Sections of the left ovary show extensive lymphovascular invasion by serous carcinoma.  Sections of the left fallopian tube show involvement of the wall and serosa by serous carcinoma, with prominent lymphovascular invasion.  No definite carcinoma in situ of remaining tubal epithelium is seen.
C.  Sections of omentumshow deposits of metastatic serous carcinoma.
Representative slides have also been viewed by Dr W Devall.

B.  Sections of the cervix are unremarkable. Sections of the endometrial tumour show an endometrioid adenocarcinoma.  It is architectural grade 1 but has severe cytologic atypia, with large vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli, so is overall grade 2.  No definite myometrial invasion is seen.  No lymphovascular invasion is seen. There is no cervical involvement.  There are foci of adenomyosis in the myometrium and a leiomyoma is also confirmed in the myometrium.

Sections of the left fallopian tube show that this is distended by a grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma with a papillary architecture.  This involves the mucosa and projects into the tube lumen.  Most of the lining epithelium of the tube is unremarkable, apart from being attenuated by the tube dilation.  The tubal tumour shows mucinous differentiation.  Sections of the left cornu show no connection between the endometrial tumour and the left tubal tumour.

At the fimbrial end of the tube there is focal involvement of the surface epithelium by endometrioid adenocarcinoma.  Sectionsfrom the right and left parametrial soft tissue show occasional small subserosal deposits of metastatic endometrioid adenocarcinoma.
Sections of the right fallopian tube are unremarkable.  Sections of the right ovary show a simplecyst. The ovary is otherwise unremarkable.

C.  Sections show ovary with extensive involvement by a grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma.  This shows extensive mucinous differentiation.  A fibroma is also noted.  With immunostains the tumour cells are strongly oestrogen receptor and cytokeratin 7 positive, and also show patchy progesterone receptor positivity, but they are cytokeratin 20 negative.  The appearance and immunophenotype are most consistent with a primary endometrioid adenocarcinoma showing mucionous differentiation, rather than a metastatic mucinous carcinoma.
D.  Sections show unremarkable fat.  No tumour is seen.  (ec)

Comment:  It is most likely thatthe endometrioid adenocarcinomas of the endometrium and left ovary are separate primaries. Sections of the left cornu show no connection between the endometrial tumour and the left tubal tumour.

The rest of myometrium shows features of adenomyosis and leiomyoma.  The serosa is unremarkable except foci of endometriosis.  There is no evidence of definite lymphovascular invasion.  The carcinoma involves the endocervix and cervical muscle wall.  Thecervical/vaginal resection margin is clear.  The parametrium is unremarkable.

A.  Specimen labelled "Uterus, cervix, tubes and ovaries" consists of a uterus with attached cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries weighing 238g in total.  The uterus measures 100 x 60 x 40mm with a roughened surface.  The ectocervix measures 30 x 35mm and has an unremarkable surface.  The anterior uterine body is inked blue, posterior black.  On sectioning the endometrium is less than 1mm in maximum thickness and the myometrium is 25mm in maximum thickness.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  The right fallopian tube measures 60mm in length with amaximum diameter of 8mm.  The right ovary consists of a complex solid and cystic mass measuring 70 x 45 x 45mm.  The mass is approximately 50% solid and 50% cystic. The solid areas have a cream fleshy and haemorrhagic variegated appearance.  The cystic areas contain multiloculated cysts filled with haemo serous material with a wall thickness of approximately 1 to 2mm.  The left fallopian tube measures 80mm in length with a maximum diameter of 8mm.  The left ovary consists of a solid and cystic mass measuring 75 x 55 x 50mm. On sectioning this mass appears to be continuous with the right ovary.  This mass is also 50% solid and 50% cystic. The solid areas have a fleshy cream and haemorrhagic variegated appearance. The cystic areas contain a yellow fluid and are predominately thin walled with a wall thickness of 1mm.

Blocks: 1 to 3 - full LS through anterior body and cervix; 4 to 6 - full LS through posterior body and cervix; 7 - right cornu; 8 - left cornu; 9 - LS of right fallopian tube; 10 - representative TS right fallopian tube; 11 to 14 - representative right ovarian mass; 15 - Left ovarian mass; 16 - representative TS left fallopian tube; 17 - to 23 - representative left ovarian mass.

A. Sections show moderately differentiated serous adenocarcinoma, involving both ovaries.  Tumour is also present on the serosal surface ofthe uterus, plus the outer half of the myometrium in the left cornu and anterior body of the uterus. Focal lymphovascular invasion is present.

The lesion has a complex glandular and papillary architecture, and is composed ofglands and papillae lined by tumour cells with markedly enlarged nuclei and prominent nucleoli.  Psammoma bodies are seen.
The endometrium appears atrophic and shows no evidence of malignancy.
The cervix is unremarkable.  There is no evidence of a HPV effect or CIN.

D. Sections show metastatic adenocarcinoma, up to 6 mm in size, in 3 out of 6 lymph nodes.  There is no evidence of extranodal spread.
E and F. Sections show fibrous tissue and fat metastatic with adenocarcinoma.
G.  Sections show metastatic adenocarcinoma in fibrous tissue and fat.  The underlying skeletal muscle appears uninvolved.
H.  Sections show a 20 mm nodule of metastatic adenocarcinoma within omental fat.

A.  Sections of uterus show a serous adenocarcinoma (grade 3).  The carcinoma shows a mixture of papillary and solid architecture.  The carcinomashows superficial myometrial invasion (inner half) and the depth of invasion is 3mm (block A7).  The myometrium is 19mm in thickness.  The endocervix and cervix are unremarkable.  There is focal lymphovascular invasion within outer half of the myometrium (block A2).  The rest of endometrium is atrophic and shows no significant abnormality.  There is focal adenomyosis.  The uterine serosa is unremarkable.  Small fragments of serous adenocarcinoma are present within the lumens of both fallopian tubes.  The rest of fallopian tubes are unremarkable.  The right ovarian cyst is a simple cyst and the cyst lining is completely denuded.  The left ovary shows multiple foci of metastatic serous adenocarcinoma measuring up to 3mm in diameter.  All the tumour metastases are on the outer surface of left ovary.

A, B.  Sections show pieces of tumour tissue.  The tumour is cellular and consists of sheets of cells with large, hyperchromatic atypical nuclei and a variable amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm with poorly defined cell borders.  Mitoses are identified and there is palisaded tumour necrosis.  There is also some microvascular proliferation.  No normal brain tissue is seen.  The appearances are of glioblastoma (WHO grade 4).
p53:  Positive.  Around 50% of tumour cells show positive nuclear staining.
Tissue will be forwarded to Dr Y Contreres, CENTRAL GIPPSLAND HEALTH SERVICE (MAFFRA) Centre, for MGMT testing and a supplementary report issued.
Block for potential treatment trial (if required):
Viable tumour with less procedural artefact is best seen in block A2.
Ki-67:  High proliferation index.  Around 50% of tumour cells show positive staining.
Tissue was sent to the MATER ADULT HOSPITAL Centre for MGMT testing.
DNA was extracted from paraffin tissue.  The DNA was bisulphite modified and subjected to pyrosequencing to amplify a region of the MGMT promoter in order to detect methylation.
Please note that this test was done in a research laboratory which is not NATA accredited.

Sections of the appendix show replacement of the mucosa by a mucinous neoplasm with low to moderate dysplasia.  In most areas, the mucosal epithelium is underlined by a chronic inflammatory infiltrate, and in the sections examined, there is no apparent perforation. There are no areas of high grade changes within the mucosa.  There is extensive infiltration of the appendiceal wall together with extensive involvement of other abdominal organs by pseudomyxoma peritonei.  There are numerous mucin lakes, some of which are rimmed bysimilar appearing atypical mucinous epithelium of low to intermediate grade.  However, in other areas, there are aggregates of poorly differentiated signet ring cells with appearances in keeping withmucinous adenocarcinoma.  This pseudomyxoma process involves the serosal aspect of portions of both the small and the large bowel with encasing of portions of both organs by tumour.  There is also surface involvement of the spleen and gallbladder, together with extensive involvement of the omentum and peritoneum.

Representative sections of the gallbladder mucosa are unremarkable andsections of the stomach are also unremarkable.  There is no evidence of inflammation and Helicobacter are not seen.  Sections of splenic parenchyma are within normal limits.

A.  Sections show fragments of peritoneum with surface inflammatory fibrinous adhesions.  Mild mesothelial hyperplasia is also seen.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

B.  Sections through the large ovarian tumour show a mucinous neoplasm of intestinal type with complex architecture and areas of cribriform expansile growth with desmoplastic stroma in keeping with a well differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma.  No extracellular deposits of mucin are present. Extensive areas of tumour necrosis are identified.The fallopian tube shows inflammatory adhesions and is otherwise unremarkable.  No extracapsular extension by tumour is identified.

Sections through the smaller ovarian mass show features of borderline mucinous neoplasm (proliferating mucinous cystadenoma). Extensive areas of necrosis are present.  No definite evidence of invasion is identified.  No extracapsular extension is seen. The fallopian tube shows inflammatory adhesions and is otherwise unremarkable.
Sections through the omentum show areas of mixed inflammatory infiltrate associated with mesothelial hyperplasia and otherwise no significant abnormality.
Sections through the spleen show an area of organisinginfarction and surface adhesion formation and otherwise no significant abnormality.

Sections through the gallbladder show surface mixed inflammatory infiltrate associated with mesothelial hyperplasia. A reactive cystic ductlymph node is also identified.  The gallbladder mucosa appears unremarkable.

Sections through the separately submitted omentum shows scattered reactive lymph nodes with no evidence of tumour.  Mesothelial hyperplasia associated with mixed inflammatory infiltrate is also present.
Sections through the separate fragments of peritoneum and umbilicus show mixed inflammatory infiltrate associated with variable mesothelial hyperplasia with no evidence of tumour.
Immunoperoxidase staining of the tumour cells from the larger ovarian mass shows positive staining with CK7, CK20 (weaker), CEA and CDX-2.
Comment : The mucinous adenocarcinoma is of intestinal type andorigin from a distant site (especially appendix) cannot be entirely excluded. Clinicopathological correlation is recommended.
-INFLAMED PERITONEUM WITH MESOTHELIAL HYPERPLASIA.  NO EVIDENCE OF TUMOUR.

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germlinemutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

Following presentation at the Colorectal Meeting by Dr J Warntz, the recent past history of a rectal carcinoid tumour was realised. In view of this, neuroendocrine markers were performed on the solitary lymph node metastasis and these were found to be positive, consistent with metastaticcarcinoid tumour (low grade neuroendocrine tumour) rather than rectal adenocarcinoma.
The staging of the current rectal adenocarcinoma is therefore classified as pN0.
Dr J Panak has discussed this amendment to the staging with the clinical team.

A.  Specimen labelled "Subtotal pancreas and spleen", consists of an en bloc distal pancreatectomy and splenectomy.  The distal pancreas is 125 x 65 x 45mm.  The spleen is 145 x 95 x50mm, weighs 222g, and contains no focal abnormality.  There is attached unremarkable greater omentum, 285 x 200 x 15mm. The posterior margin overlying the tumour has a grooved area (inked blue) and a flat area located distalto the groove (inked black).  There are three stapled margins adjacent to the groove (inked green).  The tumour is 1mm clear of the inked black margin and 2mm clear of the inked blue margin. MICROSCOPIC (Reported byDr V Sagastume & registrar Dr V Calvert):

A.  Sections of the pancreas show a focallyencapsulated tumour with a multinodular growth pattern; with a maximum macroscopic dimension of 85mm.  The tumour cells are predominantly arranged in trabeculaeand acini separated by hyalinised stroma.  The tumour cells have granular cytoplasm and mainly uniform nuclei with a clumped nuclear chromatin pattern.  Moderate numbers of mitoses are seen, up to 18 mitoses per 50 high power fields (block 4).  There is no necrosis within the tumour.  Focal lymphovascular invasion is seen with tumour covered by endothelial cells.  No perineural invasion is seen.

The tumour shows diffuse positive staining with synaptophysin and CD56, while patchy positive staining is seen with chromogranin.  Insulin, gastrin, glucagon and somatostatin stains are essentially negative.  Positive staining is seen with PR and alpha1-antitrypsin.  The tumour is negative for CD10 and tumour nuclei are negative for beta-catenin.  The Ki-67 proliferation index is up to 5%.
The morphological, immunohistochemical and Ki-67 proliferation index of this tumour are consistent with a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour (NET), grade 2 (WHO classification, 2010).

The tumour has a mainly pushing border, and comes to less than 0.1mm of the superior margin, 0.2mm of the posterior margin, 1mm ofthe pancreatic margin and 1.5mm of the inferior margin.  The tumour extends beyond the pancreatic parenchyma, with tumour nodules surrounded by peripancreatic adipose tissue (pT3).
The uninvolved pancreas shows residual islets of Langerhans with almost complete atrophy of the exocrine glands with fat replacement.  The spleen shows no significant abnormality.
Fifteen lymph nodes are negative for metastatic tumour (0/15).
B.  Section of the omentum show no significant abnormality.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

- Surgical margins close but free of tumour.

Specimen labelled "Whipple's with portal vein" consists of a Whipple's resection with a bowel measuring 270mmin length including area of distal stomach 25mm in length.  The pancreatic head measures 65 x 55 x 50mm.  Upon opening, the proximal duodenum appears dilated with the mucosa flattened.  There is a roughened area near the ampulla projecting into the lumen which is possibly ulcerated, measuring 15 x 10mm.  The duodenal mucosa appears haemorrhagic distally but otherwise unremarkable.  The anterior pancreatic margin is inked blue.  The uncinate is inked black.  The posterior is inkedgreen with the portal vein area inked red.  The superior aspect is also inked black.  The pancreatic neck resection margin is shaved and the underlying area is inked yellow.  The cut surface reveals a friable tumour which appears to be centred in the duodenum in close proximity to the papilla.  The tumour extends into the lumen and appears to partially obstruct it.  The surrounding pancreatic tissue appears fibrotic and it is difficult to assess the extent of involvementof the tumour into the pancreas.  The cystic duct appears dilated throughout its length and was unable to be probed into the duodenum, and appears therefore obstructed.  Multiple lymph nodes were identified in the pericystic duct and along the gastric resection margin.  The attached gallbladder measures 100mm in length with a maximum external diameter of 45mm.Maximum thickness of the wall is 7mm.  The wall appears oedematous in places.  The mucosa has prominent yellow streaks around.  The lumen is full of large amounts of green biliary sludge but no gallstones are identified.  The cut surface reveals that the tumour appears clear of the portal vein.  Two separate fragments of fatty tissue ?omentum were identified measuring 130 and 150mm in maximum dimension.  A few small cream nodules are identified in the omental fat ?fat necrosis.  No other suspicious areas are identified.

Sections show a 26mm moderately differentiated pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma extending into the duodenal mucosa in close association with the Ampulla of Vater.

The large pancreatic and common bile ducts show areas of acute inflammation consistent with obstruction. The surrounding pancreatic tissue shows large areas of atrophy and loss of pancreatic acinar tissue with associated fibrosis consistent with obstructive chronic pancreatitis. Extensive desmoplasia is also associated with the carcinoma.

Sections from the gallbladder show mild thickening of the gall bladder wall due to muscle hypertrophy consistent with chronic cholecystitis. The omentum shows areas of fat necrosis and a foreign body reaction to suture material.
The adenocarcinoma has the following features:
pT3 Tumour extends beyond pancreas but without involvement of the celiac axis or superior mesenteric artery.
Cut ends of stomach / duodenum: Not involved
Inferior pancreas: 4mm clear - fibrosis and distortion of atrophic ducts makes assessment of this margin difficult.
Number of lymph nodes present:  (4 peripancreatic, 1 peri cystic duct, 2 peri gastric)
Present - venous invasion is identified in a medium sized vein adjacent to edge of tumour.

Present - There is widespread perineural invasion, including foci involving nerves well away from the advancing edge of the carcinoma. Large nerve involvement is identified close to the uncinate margin.

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.
Preserved nuclear staining of a carcinoma for MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 and MSH6 indicatesa low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

Sections from the cardia, body, antrum, greater curve and lesser curve show extensive involvement of the stomach wall by a poorly differential adenocarcinoma of diffuse type.  The tumour consists of small groups, cords and single cells which are present extensively throughout the mucosa, submucosa, muscle layer and subserosa.  The cells have large, moderately pleomorphic nuclei and a variable amount of pale eosinophilic cytoplasm.  Numerous signet ring cells are noted.  Tumour extends to the serosal surface of the stomach and also extensively infiltrates fat attached to the lesser curve and omental fat attached to the greater curve.  Focal lymphovascular invasion is noted in the submucosa of the body.  Foci of perineural invasion are also identified in the stomach wall.

There is metastatic tumour in six out of eight lymph nodes which were found in fat attached to the lesser curve, and in one out of fournodes which were found in omental fat attached to the greater curve.

Sections from the proximal margin show a short length of squamous lined oesophageal wall.  There is adenocarcinoma involving the full thickness of the wall of the distal oesophagus and undermining overlying normal surface squamous epithelium, but the proximal margin appears free of tumour.  Tumour is 3mm from the proximal margin at the closest point.
Sections of the distal margin show small intestinal wall including Brunner's glands.  No tumour is seen in the small intestinal wall and the distal margin is well clear of tumour.
Remaining uninvolved gastric mucosa shows changes of a chronic gastritis with intestinal metaplasia.  Stains for Helicobacter pylori will be performed and a supplementary report issued.
Sections of the spleen and splenic hilar fat show no abnormality.
Total gastrectomy and spleen:  Poorly differentiated gastric adenocarcinoma of diffuse type, with lymph node metastases (7/12).   pT4a   pN3a
No Helicobacter is identified with giemsa stains.

A.  Sections show tumour tissue.  No normal brain is seen.  The tumour is cellular and consists mainly of spindle cells with elongated nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, in haphazard short fascicles.  There are also foci where the tumour cells have more plump atypical nuclei and better fined cytoplasm.  Mitoses are present, including atypical forms.  The features are consistent with a gliosarcoma with predominant sarcomatous component.

B.Sections show pieces of tumour tissue.  The larger piece has overlying dura.  No normal brain tissue is seen.  The tumour is similar to specimen A.  It consists mainly of spindle cells in short, haphazard fascicles.  Mitoses are frequent,numbering up to 22 per 10 HPF, and some atypical mitoses are noted.  Some tumour cells have a single, prominent nucleolus.  The cells are predominantly spindle shaped but there are patchy areas of more plump, pleomorphic, atypical cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and better defined cell borders.  Some binucleate and multinucleate tumour cells are also noted.  There are patchy foci of tumour necrosis.  Tumour abuts and focally invades into and through the overlying dura (block B4).

Reticulin stains show that most of the tumour is reticulin rich but a minor component has more scant reticulin.  The features are most consistent with a gliosarcoma.  The sarcomatous component is the predominant spindle cell tumour which is reticulin rich, while the high grade glioma (astrocytic) component has the more plump, pleomorphic cells and scant reticulin.  The high grade glioma component also shows more prominent and extensive GFAP positivity.  There is a merging of the glial and sarcomatous components.  A p53 immunostain is negative.  A Ki-67 stain shows a high proliferation index, estimated at around 80%.
The histology of the previous tumour (20S65987 B&C) has been reviewed.  Further stains are pending on that specimen and a supplementary report will follow.
IDH1 immunostaining and MGMT promoter methylation testing was done on the previous tumour and has not been repeated.

C.  Sections show a piece of greymatter and white matter with some reactive astrocytosis, and also some tumour tissue.  The tissue appears to include a pial surface and subpial accumulation of tumour cells is noted.
D.  Sections show a piece of tumour tissue.  The tumour is cellular and predominantly composed of spindle cells.
B.  Right temporal:  Gliosarcoma (WHO grade 4) with predominant sarcomatous component.
C.  Deep temporal tissue:  Involvement by gliosarcoma.
D.  Arachnoid thickening:  Involvement by gliosarcoma.

The histology of the previous right parietal tumour (20S65987) has been reviewed and further reticulin and GFAP stains have been performed.  The previous tumour lacks the spindle cell appearance of the present tumour and reticulin is only around blood vessels, not individual cells.  Also, it is generally GFAP positive.  The previous tumour is still considered to be a glioblastoma (WHO grade 4); no sarcomatous component is identified.

A.  Sections of right adnexal mass show a papilliform carcinoma with extensive necrosis.  The tumour has a complex cribriform and slender papillary architecture.  The tumour cells have elongated, round to oval nucleiwith vesicular chromatin and a variable amount of cytoplasm.  The nuclei are pleomorphic, with irregular nuclear contours, coarse chromatin and nucleoli.  Some cells are multinucleate.  Mitoses are frequent.  Occasional psammoma bodies are identified.  The features are of a moderately differentiated serous carcinoma.  There is some rather florid reactive mesothelial proliferation within, and on the surface of, the mass but no tumour is identified on the serosal surface.

The left tube and ovary are unremarkable.

No tumour is seen on the serosal surface.  There is focal perineural invasion in the subserosa but no definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.  The tumour is around 18mm from the proximal appendiceal resection margin.  There is some reactive mesothelial proliferation on the serosal surface of the appendix.

E.  Sections show a cyst lined by simple flattened and cuboidal epithelium.  The wall of thecyst is thin, and there are multiple small calibre blood vessels within the cyst wall.  There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.

G.  Sections of caecal nodules show adipose tissue with focal mild chronic inflammation and mesothelial reaction.  No tumour is seen.
H.  Sections show necrotic fat with infiltrating giant cells, chronic inflammatory cells and histiocytes at the periphery.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

Tumour at posterior gastric wall - ?GIST.  Superior posterior gastric wall tumour.

Specimen labelled "Tumour stomach" consists of a tubular segment of stomach 25 x 10 x 10mm with a nodule at one end 32 x 30 x 25mm.  The segment of the stomach has a T shaped stapled line.  The staples are removed and the margins are inked in blue and black as per the diagram.The nodule is covered by smooth shiny serosa.  The nodule has a solid cut surface ranging from pink in centre and pale towards periphery in colour.
Blocks:  1 to 3 - representative sections of the nodule (block 3 - reserved block); 4 & 5 - sections through the nodule andthe neo margins.  Please see the diagram.

The gastric tumour is a 32mm gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST). The GIST is predominantly circumscribed with a lobulated, pushing margin and expands the muscularis propria. The tumour is moderately cellular and is composed of bland spindled cells arranged in broad interweaving fascicles. In areas, the tumour cells appear moderately pleomorphic with variably sized nucleoli. There is widespread conspicuous paranuclear cytoplasmic vacuolisation. Centrally, the tumour shows prominent stromal oedema and hyalinosis. Mitoses are present up to 3 per 50 high power fields. Necrosis is inconspicuous. The tumour is largely surrounded by muscularis propria, but focally extends close to, but does not appear to involve, theserosal surface. The tumour is clear of the gastric resection margins (0.56mm). The overlying gastric mucosa shows no significant histologic abnormality.
Immunohistochemical stains were performed and the results are as follows:
Tumour cells positive for: CD117, CD34.
Tumour cells negative for: SMA, Desmin, S100, CAM5.2.
The Ki-67 immunoproliferative index highlights approximately 7% of tumour cell nuclei.

The morphologic and immunohistochemical features are consistent with a gastro-intestinal stromal tumour (GIST). Although the behaviour of these tumours can be unpredictable, individual tumours less than 50mm in size and with a low mitotic rate (less than 5/50hpf), are typically associated with a low risk of aggressive behaviour (7th edition of the AJCC/TNM).
Please correlate with clinical, radiologic and intra-operative findings.
Gastric tumour: 32mm gastrointestinal stromal tumour, close to gastric resection margin (0.56mm) (please see comment).
Location:  St Vincent-TUMBARUMBA MULTI PURPOSE SERVICE

Section of the liver show a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma. The tumour is 120 mm in maximum diameter (macroscopic measurement) and is composed of moderately atypical hepatocytes separated by fibrous stroma. The tumour cells are arranged in a trabecular and nested pattern, and show mild  variation in nuclear size and shape with conspicuous nucleoli. Numerous trabeculae are more than three cells thick and have irregular edges. Large cytoplasmic eosinophilic globules, nuclear inclusions and bile pigment are present inmany tumour cells. Focal clear cell change is also present.
The tumour lacks the typical morphology of fibrolamellar carcinoma (as suggested in the clinical history).
A focus suspicious for lymphovascular invasion is present.
The surgical margins area well clear of tumor. The tumour abuts the capsular surface of the liver.
HEPAR-1: Patchy positive in tumour cells (repeatedon separate blocks)
CAM5.2: Strongly positive in tumour cells.
AFP: mildly positive with focal strong positivity in tumour cells at periphery (?fixation artifact).
CD34: Positive in endothelial cells lining sinusoids within the tumour. (repeated)
AFP: Patchy strong positivity in tumour cells.
The Ki67 proliferation index is less than10%.
Estrogen receptor: Negative (focal staining in adjacent normal liver)
The non tumour liver shows no significant abnormality. Rare PAS positive, Diastase resistant globules are identified, of uncertain significance. An alpha-1 antitrypsin stain is in progress.
The sections of the gallbladder show mild, focal cholesterolosis, but no other significant abnormality.
B. The sections of the liver show focal nodular hyperplasia measuring approximately 7mm in maximum diameter. There is no evidence of malignancy.
C.  The sections show thirteen lymph nodes with no evidence of metastasis (0/13). Three fragments of pancreas with no significant abnormality are also noted.

B. LIVER SEGMENT I.  FOCAL NODULAR HYPERPLASIA
C. LYMPH NODES: THIRTEENLYMPH NODES NEGATIVE FOR METASTASIS (0/13)
The alpha 1 antitrypsin stain shows non-specific, diffuse cytoplasmic staining only.

Specimen labelled "Transverse colon", consists of a hemicolectomy specimen in three pieces. The largest piece consists of terminal ileum 50mm in length and up to 20mm in diameter attached to caecum and ascending colon 280mm in length.  The caecum measures 50mm in diameter and the ascending colon 30mm.  The appendix is identified and measures 110mm in length and up to 7mm in diameter. Two separate segments of small bowel are also present, measuring 120mm in length and 15mm in diameter and 50mm in length and 10mm in diameter.

Within the main specimen, the attached mesocolon measures approximately 300 x 100 x 30mm and shows fat wrapping around the ascending colon. On opening, an ulcerated, sessile polypoid tumour 36 x 18 x 7mm ispresent 35mm from the distal resection margin.  On section, the tumour extends into muscularis propria but not beyond it.  The ascending colon shows polyps up to 9mm in diameter.  A 15mm lipoma is present 20mm from the ileocaecal valve.  The mucosa of the terminal ileum is unremarkable.

Synchronous carcinomas (complete a separate form for each cancer): Not applicable
Other:A submucosal lipoma is noted in the ascending colon.
Pigmented macrophages are noted in the mucosa and submucosa.
The appendix and terminal ileum show no significant abnormality.
Response to neoadjuvent therapy - Not applicable
Grade 0 (complete response) - No viable cancer cells
Grade 1 (moderate response) - Single cells or small groups of cancer cells
Grade 2 (minimal response) - Residual cancer outgrown by fibrosis
Grade 3 (poor response) - Minimal or no tumour kill; extensive residual cancer

Sections show a markedly enlarged lymph node.  The normal architecture is effaced and there is also extension of lymphoid tissue into surrounding fibrofat.  Around half the node has a follicular architecture.  The follicles are abnormal, being relatively uniform in size and closely packed.  They consistof mixed centroblasts and centrocytes and there is an adjusted centroblast count of greater than 15 per high power field in the follicles.  This component has features of a follicular lymphoma, grade 3A.  The remainder of the node has a diffuse architecture.  This comprises sheets of mainly large lymphoid cells with irregular nuclei and generally scanty eosinophilic cytoplasm.Some cells have eosinophilic cytoplasmic globules, consistent with immunoglobulin (Russel bodies).  This component has features of a diffuse large B cell lymphoma.  Focally in the node there is a circumscribed necrotic area with some surrounding histocytes and fibrous tissue.  No Mycobacteria or fungi are identified with Truant or Silver stains.
CD20, Pax5, CD79a, CD10 - all positive infollicular and diffuse areas.
CD3 - highlights background and T cells.
Kappa - patchy positive staining, including Russel bodies.
Cyclin D 1 - stains Russel bodies and cytoplasm but no nuclear staining of tumour cells.
Ki-67 - proliferation index of up to around 60% in both follicles and diffuse areas.
Right groin lymph node:   Follicular lymphoma, grade 3A (50%) and diffuse large B cell lymphoma (50%) (WHO).

The remainder of the lesion has a glandular architecture, in keeping with endometrial differentiation.
The tumour involves the anterior and posterior uterine walls.
The maximal depth of invasion is in the anterior uterine wall, 16mm through a wall 27mm thick.
There is no evidence of invasion into the cervix.
Focal adenomyosis is seen in the myometrium.
The cervix is unremarkable.  There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.
Simple cysts are present in the left ovary.
The right ovary shows a benign serous cystadenoma.
The fallopian tubes show no evidence of malignancy.

C. Sections show fibrous hernial sac with no evidence of malignancy.
D. Sections show 2 lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy.
E. Sections show 2 lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy.
F. Sections at multiple levels show fat with no evidence of malignancy.
G. Sections show 2 lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy.
H. Sections show 1 lymph node with no evidence of malignancy.
I.  Sections show 1 lymph node with no evidence of malignancy.

A. The sections show a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma consistent with cholangiocarcinoma.  The tumour surrounds the large bile ducts near the hilum.  Although most of the bile ductepithelium has been sloughed, atypical cells arising from the epithelium and forming papillary structures protruding into the duct can be seen (slide A5).  The tumour invades into adjacent liver and soft tissues and involves the caudate, left and right lobes.  Several small tumour nodules, many involving the portal tracts, are found distant from the main lesion (e.g., slide A 15 in the left lobe).  Malignant cells focally reach the capsular surface of the liver.  There is patchy chronic inflammation but no cirrhosis in the liver.  Several irregularly dilated bile ducts are seen and atypical epithelial cells are present in occasional dilated bile ducts.

tumour has a heterogenous appearance.  In many areas, there are glandular structures with abundant fibrotic stroma.  Variable amounts of mucin formation are seen, highlighted by the PAS stain.  Inother areas, there are micropapillary structures or cribriform glands with central necrosis.  There is a variable degree of pleomorphism in the tumour cells.  The cytoplasm varies from clear to pale eosinophilic and is moderately abundant. The tumour cells strongly express keratin 19 antigen by the immunoperoxidase technique.  Keratin 7 antigen is also expressed but in a patchy distribution.  There is no convincing expression of Hep-Par 1 antigen. Membranous expression ofbeta catenin is present but not nuclear expression of this antigen.  The tumour extends to the soft tissue resection margin over a 5mm front (block A5) and focally it is 0.3mm from the liver resection margin (block A6).  Tumour is foundwithin thin walled lymphovascular channels in the portal tracts but no tumour is found within major branches of the hepatic artery and portal vein.  Prominent perineural invasion ispresent.
The liver tissue abutting the tumour shows necrosis, reactive biliary proliferation and cholestasis.

No malignancy or dysplasia is seen in the vascular margin (slide A1) and common bile duct margin (slide A2). No definite malignancy or dysplasia is seen in the cysticduct margin (slide A16) but some of the tissue is distorted by diathermy artefact and difficult to evaluate.
Metastatic adenocarcinoma is seen in four of five hilar lymph nodes with extranodal spread present.  There is direct invasion of another hilar node (slide A10).

The gallbladder is slightly dilated and thin walled but shows no malignancy or dysplasia.  However, most of the mucosa shows autolytic changes.  No malignancy is seen in the cystic duct lymph node (slide A19).
B. The three lymph nodes show an incidental finding of lipogranulomas.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
A. Liver: Left hepatic duct cholangiocarcinoma with perineural andlymphovascular invasion; five of six hilar nodes contain adenocarcinoma.
B. Lesser sac lymph nodes: No malignancy in three nodes.
