B. Sections show skin with prominent solar elastosis excised to the level of underlying skeletal muscle. There is a 40mm malignant dermocutaneous tumour with similar morphology as that seen in the previous excision from MACQUARIEWARD Pathology (labelled 90-BTNC 91552 Suga, Y 900750915;see also review report by Dr Y Halonen 90B75091). The tumour is composed of sheets and short fascicles of pleomorphic spindled and epithelioid cells as well as malignant multinucleated cells with bizarre, hyperchromatic nuclei. Mitoticfigures are prominent. The appearance is that of a malignant dermocutaneous tumour with features consistent with a malignant melanoma. Malignant melanoma shows invasion into underlying skeletal muscle but no connection to the epidermis is seen. No obvious lymphovascular or perineural invasion is identified.
Excision appears complete and the excision margins are as follow:

The overlying skin shows a scar in keeping with previous excision. The epidermis appears attenuated in areas with increased numbers of basal melanocytes displaying mild cytologic atypia. However, lentiginous proliferation of these melanocytes is not seen. Subepithelial collections of lymphocytes are focally present but no definite features of a regressed melanocytic lesion are identified.
- NO EVIDENCE OF METASTATIC TUMOUR IN TWELVE LYMPH NODES (0/12)
- CONSISTENT WITH MALIGNANT MELANOMA, MARGINS CLEAR

Received from the HILLSTON DISTRICT HOSPITAL Hospital KIAMA DOWNS, 1 block labelled "90B75091_B4".
The sample was reviewed by a pathologist and was considered to have 50% tumour cells within thearea selected for analysis.

The sample wasanalysed for mutations at or surrounding codon 600 within exon 15 of the BRAF gene encompassing the region containing 97% of all BRAF mutations, using high resolution melting (HRM) analysis (Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer [1]).Abnormal HRM traces are subjected to DNA sequencing for characterisation. This assay is capable of detecting BRAF mutations providing the mutant allele is present at a level of 10% or greater.
No BRAF mutation was detected at or surrounding codon 600 indicating that this patient will not respond to the current V600E specific BRAF inhibitors.

BRAF mutations are found in 5-20% of colorectal cancers and 30-70% melanomas, in the majority of cases(90% in melanoma) the mutation results in the V600E protein change [1-2]. V600E specific BRAF inhibitors e.g. vemurafenib and dabrafenib have been developed to inhibit oncogenic BRAF in melanoma patients. Trials of these inhibitors have shown that melanoma patients with the BRAF V600K mutation may also benefit from treatment [3,4,5]. The presence of a BRAF mutation in colorectal cancer can be used to rule-out Lynch syndrome and it also indicates that the patient will be insensitive to EGFR inhibitors e.g. cetuximab [6].
Please note: Synonymouschanges are not reported.

Reference articles: 1) Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer: http://www.sanger.ac.uk/genetics/CGP/cosmic/. 2) Garnett and Marais (2004) Cancer Cell; 6:313-319. 3) Chapman at al., (2011) N Engl J Med; (364)26: 2507-16. 4) Hauschild etal., (2012) Lancet; 380: 358-65. 5) Ascierto et al., (2013) J Clin Oncol 31: 3205-11. 6) Sharma et al., (2010) Arch Pathol Lab Med; 134:1225-1228. Reference Sequence GenBankAccession Number: BRAF NNM_004333.4.

(50 five possible nodes; 51 four possible nodes).

Peritoneum. Fragments of peritoneum with fatty tissue attached, measuring in aggregate 70x60x30mm. There is a cystic ---hemorrhaging, petechial hemorrhaging, and ?some small pale firm nodules which have been sampled.

Sections of gallbladder show features of mild chronic cholecystitis. There is no evidence of malignancy in the gallbladder wall.  The representative sections of spleen are unremarkable.  Sections of the omentum attached to the spleen show an  omental deposit of metastatic, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal mucinous features.  Two small omental lymph nodes show no involvement.

Sections of the anterior peritoneal nodule confirm multiple deposits of similar moderately differentiated metastatic adenocarcinoma involving the peritoneal surface, and with invasion into the underlying adipose tissue.  Associated lymphovascular invasion is noted.  Several similar nodules of metastatic adenocarcinoma are confirmed within the Pouch of Douglas, including peritoneal surface involvement and invasion into the underlying adipose tissue.  Lymphovascular involvement is also noted in this site.

Sections of cervix show an extensive deposit of moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma invading into the outer wall of cervix and extending to the outer wall of the lower uterine segment. The endometrium appears atrophic.  The myometrium and uterine serosa elsewhere are unremarkable.

Sections of the right fallopian tube show a deposit of moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinomainvolving the fimbrial end of the fallopian tube.  This deposit shows some mucinous features.  The right ovary is largely replaced by metastatic adenocarcinoma.  Sections of the left fallopian tube and left ovary show no involvement.

The proximal and distal margins of resection of the rectum show no involvement. There is an extensive deposit of adenocarcinoma within the perirectal fat, which reaches a diathermied surgical margin over a broad front.  A singleperirectal lymph node shows no involvement.
Sections of the anal squamous mucosa show no atypia.  Metastatic carcinoma is confirmed within the soft tissue mass adjacent to the anal mucosa.

Sections of appendixshow that the lumen and wall of the mid and proximal appendix are obliterated by moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with some areas of mucinous differentiation. The carcinoma extends to involve the serosal surface of themesoappendix.  Lymphovascular involvement is seen in this area.  The distal appendix is not involved, and shows unremarkable appendiceal mucosa.

The resection margins of the ? transverse colon show no involvement.  There are multiple deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma within the omentum and mesentery of the right hemicolectomy, as well as in the serosa, muscularis propria and submucosa of the small intestine.

The polyp in the transverse colon is a tubular adenoma with low grade epithelial dysplasia.  The sessile tumour described within the transverse colon is an area of intramucosal adenocarcinoma arising from an adjacent tubular adenoma.  Sections of the ? anastomosis site show moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with areas of mucinous differentiation, which invades through the full thickness of the colonic wall into pericolic fibroadipose tissue.  The representative section of the mesenteric area of bowel adhesion shows involvement by adenocarcinoma.  There are other foci of adenocarcinoma noted as deposits within the mesentery of the right hemicolectomy.  One ofseven lymph nodes identified from the right hemicolectomy specimen contains metastatic adenocarcinoma, and this metastatic deposit shows areas of signet ring cell change.
Representative sections of the separate fragments ofperitoneum show a small deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma.
SPLEEN, GALLBLADDER, RIGHT COLON, OMENTUM, UTERUS, SMALL BOWEL, PERITONEAL DISEASE :

-MODERATELY TO POORLY DIFFERENTIATED ADENOCARCINOMA, WITH FOCAL AREAS OF MUCINOUS AND SIGNET RING CELL DIFFERENTIATION, INVOLVING THE ANASTOMOTIC SITE IN THE RIGHT HEMICOLECTOMY, THE MESENTERY OF THE RIGHT HEMICOLECTOMY, THE OMENTUM, ANTERIOR PERITONEUM, POUCH OF DOUGLAS, OUTER WALL OF CERVIX, RIGHT FALLOPIAN TUBE, RIGHT OVARY, PERIRECTAL FAT, PERIANAL TISSUE, AND APPENDIX.
-ONE OF SEVEN LYMPH NODES FROM THE RIGHT HEMICOLECTOMY SPECIMEN IS INVOLVED BY METASTATIC, POORLY DIFFERENTIATED ADENOCARCINOMA.
-TWO OMENTAL LYMPH NODES AND ONE PERIRECTAL LYMPH NODE SHOW NO INVOLVEMENT.

PMS2: Positive staining of tumour cell nuclei.
MSH2: Positive staining of tumour cell nuclei.
MSH6: Positive staining of tumour cell nuclei.

Absence of staining for either MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSH-H), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair enzyme.
Positive staining of a carcinoma for MLH1,  PMS2,  MSH2  and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

The antibodies used are not fully characterised for routine diagnostic use. Results may be affected by storage and fixation of specimens, and should be interpreted in conjunction with other investigation, including MSI testing where possible.

Sections of the omentum show circumscribed nodules surrounded by fibrous capsule. The nodules are comprised of numerous vascular channels with intervening fibromyxoid stroma. Metastatic carcinoma is seen in 2 out of 14 lymph nodes.

Sections of gallbladder show features of chronic cholecystitis and cholesterolosis. Onthe serosal surface of the gallbladder, there are deposits of mucin, one of which contains a strip of mucinous epithelium of low to intermediate nuclear grade. No invasion is seen into the wall of the appendix.

Sections of spleen show some deposits of mucin on the peritoneal surface in an  extracapsular location, with some associated strips of low to intermediate nuclear grade mucinous epithelium within these mucin pools. There are also several pools of mucin immediately underlying the splenic capsule, and containing an occasional strip of mucinous epithelium. A single mucinous gland is seen adjacent to one of these mucin pools, within the fibrous pseudocapsule, but no invasion into the adjacent splenic parenchyma is seen. Elsewhere, the splenic parenchyma shows unremarkable red and white pulp, with no obvious abnormality.
The omentum contains multiple deposits of extracellular mucin, many of which contain strips of mucinous epithelium of low to intermediate nuclear grade.

Representative sections of the peritoneum show multiple deposits of extracellular mucin, many of which contain strips of mucinous epithelium of low to intermediate nuclear grade.  Some of these epithelial strips show pseudostratification and tufting, but no complex papillary or cribriform structures are seen. Focally, a few small single mucinous glands are seen, surrounded by fibrous tissue which in one area is desmoplastic. These few small acinar foci are consistent with focal invasion (mucinous adenocarcinoma).

The margins of resection of the right hemicolectomy show no involvement by tumour. There are multiple deposits of mucin and mucinous tumour epithelium on the serosal surface of the hemicolectomy, together with an occasional isolated gland showing some adjacent desmoplasia, suspicious for focal invasion. No tumourinvolvement of the wall of the small or large bowel is seen. The two lymph nodes identified show no involvement.

Comment: The features present are those of intermediate grade mucinous neoplasm involving the serosal surface ofgallbladder, spleen and right hemicolectomy, with focal subcapsular splenic involvement, and several tiny foci of invasion in the serosa and peritoneal deposits, consistent with mucinous adenocarcinoma.

A binary scheme has been proposed for grading appendiceal pseudomyxoma peritonei, with all tumours with significant spread beyond right lower quadrant (bona fide pseudomyxoma) termed mucinous carcinoma peritonei (low grade versus high grade). This low/high grade stratification is similar to Ronnett scheme and WHO.  Tumours with intermediate or hybrid features (PMCA-Intermediate -Ronnett) are grouped with low grade tumours in the Bradley scheme in view of similar behaviour in their series, and in a later series (Chua 2012), but less favourable behaviour was described in the earlier Ronnett series for this intermediate group.

This type of tumour would generally but not exclusively be of appendix origin. From the sections available from the previous appendicectomy from 19/12/2060, although there is a small mucosal probable adenomatous lesion present in one of the sections (see separate review), it would be difficult to definitely conclude that this was the primary lesion histologically. The peritoneal mucinous neoplasm epithelium is more eosinophilic and not very similarto the small atypical focus in the appendix. Clinical correlation recommended.
B.  The lymph nodes are negative for tumour (0/1).

Histology shows abundant extracellular mucin with intervening fibrous connective tissue septae with patchy chronic inflammation. The mucinous tumour is found extensively within the omental cake with numerous peritoneal deposits and serosal deposits over the right colon, gall bladder and capsule of the spleen. Haematosalpinx secondary to obstruction). Noevidence of malignancy is identified.

F.  Histology shows the solid tumour within the small bowel mesentery to be a spindle cell lesion consisting of relatively abundant collagenous fibrotic stroma with an intermediate cellularity population of spindle cells which have mildly atypical nuclei.  Scattered elongated tortuous arching vessels are seen throughout the stroma withscattered lymphocytes.  There is no discernable mitotic activity or areas of necrosis or high grade atypia. The periphery of the tumour is mostly well circumscribed but some irregular infiltrative areas are present. Thetumour lies close to the small bowel wall but does not appear to arise directly from it. Immunostains show patchy positivity for smooth muscle actin, desmin and vimentin and negativity for c-KIT, CD34, S100, cytokeratinand Bcl-2.  Five entrapped lymph nodes at the edge of the lesion show no evidence of malignancy.  The small bowel is otherwise unremarkable.
The appearances are consistent with those a desmoid fibromatosis.  The lesion appears to be clear of the mesenteric fatty resection margin by 4mm.

Sections of the largest lymph node show extensive involvement by amalignant spindle cell tumour.  A further twenty six (26) nodes were identified in the specimen and these all show non-specific reactive changes only.  The apical node is not involved by spindle cell tumour.

The spindle cells are in haphazard fascicles and have large, pleomorphic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.  Mitoses are frequent, numbering around 20 per 10 HPF, and some abnormal mitoses are noted.  There is a small area of infarct-like necrosis in the node but no other tumour necrosis is seen.  No differentiating features are identified with routine staining.  There is a moderate number of admixed benign small lymphocytes and plasma cells amongst the tumour cells.  There is some residual lymphoid tissue, with hyperplastic follicles, at the periphery of the node.  There is some probable extranodal tumour spread, with a pushing margin (blocks 23, 24) but soft tissue margins appear to be free of tumour.
Cytokeratin CAM 5.2, CK AE1/3, CK 5/6, p63 - all negative.
Leukocyte common antigen, CD30, CD20, CD3 - all negative.
CD1A - focal positive.receptor, progesterone receptor - negative.
CD21, CD23 - highlight residual lymphoid follicles only.

The appearances are interpreted as a high grade sarcoma in a lymph node.  It stains S100 and Fascin positive and also shows some patchy CD68 positivity.  I favour this being a primary nodal sarcoma and the immunophenotype fits best with an interdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma.  These are very rare tumours which most commonly present with solitary lymph node involvement.  The clinical course is said to be generally aggressive.
I will send the slides to Dr K Magnan, OPERATING THEATRES Pathology, for an opinion and issue a supplementary report.
Left axillary tissue:  High grade sarcoma involving one lymph node (1/27), favour interdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma.
The slides were sent to Dr FAUSTO Kedra, Anatomical Pathology, for review.  He replies as follows:

The H&E sections supplied are Blocks 17 to 24 from the single largest lymph node which is virtually replaced by a malignant spindle cell tumour. These sections also include 3 separate smaller lymph nodes which show reactive changes and appear uninvolved by malignancy. The tumour is composed of short and intersecting fascicles of spindled cells with occasional small groupings of more epithelioid cells. The tumour cells show considerable nuclear pleomorphism with prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, vesicular chromatin and plentiful eosinophilic cytoplasm. Occasional tumour giant cells areseen. There are scattered foci of tumour necrosis and there is brisk mitotic activity with occasional atypical mitoses. These cells show both cytoplasmic and nuclear staining for S100 protein as well as staining for vimentin, fascin andWT1 (WT1 INTENSIVE CARE UNIT SOUTH stain). These cells appear negative for melan-A and HMB45 both on the Devon Energy stains and PATHOLOGYWEST stains. They are also negative on our staining for tyrosinase and MITF1.  Schmorl's stain for melanin is negative. They are also negative for multiple cytokeratins including pan cytokeratin, cytokeratin 19 and the cytokeratins listed in Dr Jamison's report. They are also negative for EMA. The tumour cells appear negative for leukocyte common antigen, CD20, CD3, CD30, PAX-5 and EBV-LMP. They appear negative for histiocytic and dendritic cell markers CD163, CD68, CD1a, langerin, CD21, CD23, CD35, and CD4, which highlight background histiocytic and dendritic cells only. They are negative for smooth muscle markers Desmin and smooth muscle actin. 
840	5413	In the background there is some residual lymphoid cells including occasional reactive follicles, compressed to the periphery of the node. 
840	5551	Overall, I think the most likely diagnosis is metastatic melanoma. I have not had much experience with interdigitating reticulum cell sarcoma as these are rare tumours, but from the literature they are describedas usually having more bland nuclei without necrosis and a lower mitotic rate and they often show variable staining for CD68, lysozyme and CD45. Review of the atypical melanocytic lesion removed from the left arm in 2061 is recommended.If you have access to SOX10 immunoperoxidase, this might prove helpful.  Unfortunately we have only just received a sample of the antibody and have not been able to get it working as yet. Electromicroscopy might also be considered if there is still doubt over the diagnosis after review of the skin lesion. 
840	6305	DIAGNOSIS: 
840	6316	LEFT AXILLARY LYMPH NODE: MALIGNANT SPINDLE CELL TUMOUR FAVOURING METASTATIC MELANOMA. (End of Dr Violette's report).

With the further history obtained that there was an atypical pigmented lesion removed from the left arm in December 2061, I agree that it seems that the diagnosis is most likely to be metastatic malignant melanoma
The slides were referred to Prof K Tuffey, VICTORIAN HEART HOSPITAL Hospital, for review as requested.
He also favours a metastatic spindle cell or desmoplastic melanoma.

The slides were also reviewed at GATTON HOSPITAL by Prof K Cokel and Dr K Sobran.  They also agree that metastatic melanoma is the most likely diagnosis.  They also reviewed the slides of the previousskin excision (KZ-95-13136).  They comment that there are some atypical spindle cells and that it could represent the primary, however they do not think that there is enough evidence for a definite diagnosis on the limited suboptimal material that is available for assessment.
A tissue block was sent to ONCOLOGY (GYNAE)'s Pathology for BRAF mutation detection.
Targeted BRAF mutation analysis on DNA extracted from the block was negative.  No mutation was detected.

Interpretation:  The tumour sample does not carry a known BRAF gene mutation that affects codon 600 of the BRAF protein.  This patient is not expected to benefit from treatment with a BRAF inhibitor based therapy (Chapman et al.  NEJM 2011; 364: 2507-16).

The tumour is 300 x 150 x 100mm and weighs 1800g.  The external surface is smooth and shiny and is partly covered by adipose tissue.  The external surface appears complete. A.  Sections show a spindle cell tumour of low to moderate cellularity, with some skeletal muscle and a small amount of fat at one edge.  The tumour cells have elongated and plump oval nuclei.  Some of the plump cells are binucleate or multinucleate and have a moderate amount of amphophilic cytoplasm, and these cells often have a single prominent nucleolus.  The cells are haphazardly dispersed in short fascicles within a fibrous stroma.  Mitoses are infrequent and no necrosis is seen.  The tumour abuts the described smooth surface and also extends virtually to the described roughened area at one pole of the specimen (block A5).  In view of the appearances seen in the other specimens (specimens B and C) the features are mostconsistent with a de-differentiated liposarcoma.
B.Sections of the described nodule show that this consists of old, necrotic fat, with surrounding fibrous tissue. There are foci of calcification within the necrotic fat.

Sections of the bowel segment show large intestinal wall.  There is recentischaemic damage to the mucosa.  The wall is unremarkable but, in sections from the described dilated segment, there is atypical spindle cell tumour, of low cellularity, involving subserosal tissue.  No definite tumour is seen in the sections of bowel from the proximal and distal excisionmargins.

Sections from the pericolic fat show mature appearing fat with scattered atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei, both within the fat and in septae between fat lobules (blocks B10, B11).  The features are most in keeping with a well differentiated, lipoma-like liposarcoma.  The identification of this component would mean, therefore, that the high grade sarcoma identified in the specimens A and C, and the osteosarcoma identified in the previous resection from 2059, are most consistent with components of a de-differentiated liposarcoma.
The tumourseen in the subserosal tissue of the colon is most consistent with sclerosing variant of well differentiated liposarcoma.

C.  Sections show tumour with a variable appearance.  The majority has features of a high grade sarcoma.  This mainly consists of highly atypical, pleomorphic cells, sometimes with prominent eosinophilic cytoplasm, within a loose and myxoid stroma.  With immunostains the atypical cells are strongly vimentin and desmin positive and also show some patchy smooth muscle actin and myogenin positivity.  Stains for CD34 and S100 are negative.  The proliferation index with a Ki-67 stain in the most atypical area is around 50%.  The appearances are of a de-differentiated liposarcoma showing rhabdomyosarcomatous differentiation.  Much of the tumour has a lobulated outline but de-differentiated liposarcoma is seen extending to at least one inked excision margin (block C15).

A minor component of well differentiated lipoma-like liposarcoma is also identified (blocks C11, C14).  This also appears to extend to at least one excision margin (block C14).  Some tumour comprising hyalinised tissue of low cellularity, with scattered large atypical cells, consistent with sclerosing variant of well differentiated liposarcoma, is also noted (eg. Block C1, C9, C10).

Sectionsof the attached kidney show end stage stages with marked atrophy, hyalinisation of most glomeruli, severe tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis.  There is atypical spindle cell tumour, consistent with de-differentiated liposarcoma, extending to the renal capsule but no definite invasion of the kidney is seen.
Representative slides have also been viewed by Dr D Kun.
A.   Pleural diaphragmatic mass:  De-differentiated liposarcoma.
B.   Splenic flexure:  Well differentiated, lipoma-like liposarcoma in pericolic fat, and sclerosing variant of well differentiated liposarcoma in subserosal tissue of colon.
C.  Retroperitoneal tumour and left kidney:
1.  High grade sarcoma with features of rhabdomyosarcoma, most consistent with
rhabdomyosarcomatous differentiation in de-differentiated liposarcoma.  Minor
components of well differentiated lipoma-like and sclerosing liposarcoma.

Sections show a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the distal transverse colon.  The tumour is almost circumferential and no residual adenoma is identified.  The carcinoma appears obstructive and has resulting in proximal dilatation. There is no evidence of ischaemic mucosal changesproximally and the mucosa of the colon shows a mild/moderate melanosis coli.

The carcinoma has extended through the full thickness of the bowel wall and shows prominent infiltration of the transverse mesocolon. The tumour also shows involvement of the peritoneum where small glands are seen on the surface of the mesothelium and this peritoneal surface (antimesenteric) appears mildly inflamed.

A total of forty-four (44) lymph nodes are identified (nine lymph nodes adjacent to the tumour, twenty-three proximal nodes and twelve distal nodes).  A single node immediately distal to the tumour is largely replaced by metastatic adenocarcinoma with mild perinodalspread.  No other lymph nodes are involved.

The resection includes a total of nine (9) tubular adenomas both proximal and distal to the carcinoma and there is no evidence of metastatic spread tothe attached omentum.  The distal ileum and appendix show no abnormality.
Distance of tumour to nearer cut end: 260mm

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instabilityphenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.

Specimen labelled "Right kidney" consists of right kidney measuring 150mm (superior to inferior), 85mm (side to side) and 75mm (anterior to posterior) with perinephric fat up to 20mm in thickness weighing 724g.  A short segmentof proximal ureter is present 60 x 5mm.  Sectioning shows a large circumscribed tumour measuring 105 x 85 x 65mm.  The tumour is present in the mid and lower pole and shows a heterogenous yellow greyish/brownish cut surface.  The tumourappears to abut the renal capsule and pelvis. The hilar soft tissue margin is >10mm clear of the tumour macroscopically. The renal vein and ureteric mucosa appear unremarkable.  No lymph nodes are identified.  The adrenal gland is identified in the superior pole 45 x 5 x 4mm showing no unusual features.  The non-neoplastic kidney shows wedge shape solid pale areas (?infarctions).  The perinephric fat at the inferior aspect shows massive haemorrhage.

Blocks: 1 - ureteric and vascular margins; 2 - pelvis and proximal renal vein; 3 - tumour and pelvis; 4 - anterior tumour; 5 - posterior tumour; 6 - inferior tumour; 7 - tumour with inferior sinus fat andhilar margin; 8 - reserve block for tissue bank; 9 - infarction; 10 - non neoplastic kidney; 11 - adrenal; 12 - perinephric fat with haemorrhage.   (HO/ta 12/7/62)

Sections show a renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, Fuhrman grade 2.  The tumour is located in the mid and lower pole of the right kidney and measures 105 x 85 x 65mm.  The tumour abuts the renal capsule and renal pelvis but does not infiltrate these structures.  The renal sinus is infiltrated by tumour and the vessels of the renal hilum and kidney contain embolic material.  The preoperative embolisation appears to have little effect on the viability of the tumour but the adjacent uninvolved kidney shows areas of acute cortical infarction.

There is no evidence of tumour invasion of the renal vein or its branches.  The kidney away from the tumour and areas of infarction appears essentially normal and the adrenal gland also shows no abnormality.
-  Renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, Fuhrman grade 2, size 105 x 85 x 65mm with preoperative embolisation.
-  No evidence of invasion of the renal vein, no invasion of the renal capsule.
-  Surgical margins well clear of tumour.

A.  Sections show a well circumscribed solitary hepatocellular tumour.  The tumour comprises of benign appearing hepatocytes arranged in solid sheets without acinar architecture.  The tumour cells are largerand paler than non-tumour hepatocytes in the surrounding tissue.  No central scars or large arteries are seen.  Focal areas of haemorrhage are present but no necrosis is seen.  Focal areas of fibrosis and septum formation are present.  The tumour is completely excised and is well clear of the resection margin.

The tumour shows a well developed reticulum network (which is confirmed by reticulum stain).  The tumour cells are strongly positive for Hepar-1.  TheKi-67 proliferation index is about 2 to 3%.  CD34 is strongly expressed within the tumour.  The surrounding liver tissue shows macro-steatosis.  There is no significant inflammation.  There is no evidence of architectural change or cirrhosis.

Sections show a solitary hepatocellular tumour (35mm), which is difficult to classify.  The overall appearances are favouring those of well differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma.  The main differentialdiagnosis is hepatocellular adenoma.  Hepatocellular carcinoma usually arises in the background of cirrhosis but no cirrhosis is seen here.  Hepatocellular adenoma is strongly linked to female contraceptive pills/steroids and male cases without linkage to contraceptive pills/steroids are extremely rare.  This case will be sent to Prof Gerald SPANICEK of PROSERPINE HOSPITAL Hospital and a supplementary report will be issued.
B.  Sections of gallbladder show features of chronic inflammation.  The cystic duct lymph node shows no significant abnormality.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
A.  Left lobe liverresection - Hepatocellular tumour favouring well differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (see text).
Reported by Prof Stefan OTANO, WEE WAA COMMUNITY HOSPITAL Hospital.

I favour a diagnosis of well differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, rather than an adenoma, since the lesion has areas with thick trabeculae (>3 cells), focal loss of reticulin fibres, unaccompanied arteries and stromal invasion.  Focally there are a few pseudo glandular structures (dilated bile canaliculi).  Scattered mitotic figures arealso seen.  No vascular invasion is identified.
Review liver, left lobe: Well differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma.

A.  Sections of small bowel show a tumour which ulcerates overlying epithelium.  The cells are uniform in nature with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm and nuclei with granular chromatin and small indistinct nucleoli.  The tumourcells show positive staining with CD56 and are negative for CK20 and TTF1.  The features are that of a neuroendocrine tumour (carcinoid).  The mitotic count is approximately 6 per 10HPF and the Ki67 is approximately 15%.  The tumour is thus classified as a neuroendocrine tumour G2 (NET G2, WHO 2010 classification).  The tumour extensively infiltrates muscularis propria and extends into subserosal and mesenteric adipose tissue.  No definite peritoneal surface involvement is seen.  Lymphovascular invasion is present.  The tumour lies approximately 20mm from the closest resection margin.  Due to the small amount of attached mesentery, no lymph nodes are identified, however there is extensive infiltration of mesenteric adipose tissue by tumour.  The remaining bowel mucosa shows no significant abnormality.
B.  Sections of omentum show extensive infiltration by neuroendocrine tumour.
C.  Sections show a deposit of neuroendocrine tumour.

Absence (loss) of nuclear staining for any of the mismatch repair enzymes MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSI), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair gene.
Preserved nuclear staining of a carcinoma for MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

The gastric tumour is a 95mm gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST). The GIST expands the subserosal tissue and appears circumscribed with a lobulated, pushing margin. The tumour is moderately cellular and is composed of bland spindled cells arranged in short fascicles with areas of intervening stromal hyalinosis, oedema and very focal necrosis. There is widespread conspicuous paranuclear cytoplasmic vacuolisation. Mitoses are present up to 5 per 50 high power fields. The tumour is 5.5mm from the gastric resection margin and extends close, but does not involve, the overlying serosal surface. The overlying gastric mucosa shows a mild to moderate non-specific chronic gastritis.
Immunohistochemical stains were performed and the results are as follows:
Tumour cells positive for: CD117, CD34, focal SMA and focal desmin.
The Ki-67 immunoproliferative index highlights approximately 3-5% of tumour cell nuclei.

The morphologic and immunohistochemical features areconsistent with a gastro-intestinal stromal tumour (GIST). Although the behaviour of these tumours can be unpredictable, individual tumours between 50 and 100mm in size and with mitotic rate of 5/50hpf, are typically associated with a high risk of aggressive behaviour (7th edition of the AJCC/TNM).
Please correlate with clinical, radiologic and intra-operative findings.
Gastric tumour: 95mm serosal based gastrointestinal stromal tumour, 5.5mm to gastric resection margin (see comment).

The right lung tumour is a 70mm high gradesarcomatoid tumour with myxoid stroma. The tumour shows very focal cytokeratin positivity and TTF-1 is negative. This lung tumour has been compared to thepreviously reported right thigh myxofibrosarcoma (JS-86-790183 5.6.2062). The tumours appear identical and have a similar pattern of immunohistochemical staining, including focal cytokeratin positivity (although the thigh tumour was reported as being cytokeratin negative). Overall, the 70mm lung tumour shows features consistent with metastatic high grade myxofibrosarcoma.

Specimen labelled "Wide medial, short superior, long lateral" consists of an orientated wide local excision measuring 50mm (medial to lateral) x  23mm (inferior to superior) x 45mm (superficial to deep).  Two sutures are insitu as designated and a hook wire is seen to insert from the medial aspect.  The superior margin is inked blue, inferior margin black, deep black and the superficial margin inked green.  The specimen is serially sectioned parasagittally from slice one (lateral) to slice eight (medial). Blocks: 1 & 2 - slice one; 3 & 4 - slice two; 5 & 6 - slice three; 7 & 8 - slice four; 9 & 10 - slice five; 11 & 12 - slice six; 1`3 & 14 - slice seven; 15 & 16 - slice eight; 17 - reserve block AE.   Tumour markers on block 3, please refer to attached diagram.
A.  One (1) lymph node is negative for tumour.  The CAM5.2 keratin stain is negative.
B.  One (1) lymph node is negative for tumour.  The AE1/AE3 keratin stain is negative (some background nuclear staining).

C.  Sections show a 14mm grade 2 invasive ductal carcinoma. The carcinoma is present laterally within the specimen and is composed of mild to moderately pleomorphic cells arranged in cords, solid clusters and small tubules. Scattered intracytoplasmic lumen formation is seen.  Although in areas the tumour displays lobular carcinoma-like morphology, including targetoid growth around benign ductules, the E cadherin immunostain is diffusely positive, more consistent with invasive ductal carcinoma.  Invasive carcinoma focally extends to the lateral excision margin superiorly. There are at least five (5) foci of lymphovascular invasion (endothelial lining confirmed with positive expression for D240 and CD31). Unusually, although these foci show similar cytonuclear features to the adjacent stromal invasive tumour they display more distinct tubule formation. Focal minimal calcification is present associated with the invasive tumour.  There is also low to intermediate grade ductal carcinoma in-situ confined within the borders of the invasive tumour.
A synoptic report for breast carcinoma follows.
Degree of DCIS in tumour:  Moderate
Lateral  Positive (block C1); diathermied tumour focally extends to the lateral    margin superiorly
In-situ component: all margins including lateral clear; confined within borders of invasive tumour (see above).
Ki-67 index:  The Ki67 proliferationindex is variable but is approximately 10% in the most proliferative areas.

Miscellaneous:  Away from the tumour the breast tissue shows foci of cystic change.  A focus of columnar cell change with focal hyperplasia is also seen and in one space there is superimposed architectural atypia approaching atypical ductal hyperplasia (block C1).  This is 1mm clear of the lateral resection margin.  A focus of fibrosis, haemorrhage and fat necrosis, consistent with a core biopsy tract, is present immediately adjacent to the tumour (block C3).

Sections show a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the caecum.  The tumour has infiltrated through the full thickness of the bowel wall and involves the serosa.  In one area the serosa is inflamed and haemorrhagic and it is debateable whether tumour cells have breached the serosa.  However in my view this layer has not definitely been breached by tumour (pT3).  The carcinoma also shows early invasion of the mesentery, and abuts the appendiceal orifice and ileocaecal valve.
The appendix shows a small mucocele as a result of adenomatous epithelial lining (cystadenoma) rather than as a result of obstruction.
The right colon contains a single tubular adenoma with mild dysplasia.
Four (4) of the eighteen (18) mesenteric lymph nodes identified contain metastatic carcinoma and one of these shows a focus of perinodal spread.  The apical node is clear.
There is no abnormality of the terminal ileum or colon away from the tumour.

A.  Specimen labelled "Cervix, uterus, tubes and ovaries", consists of a uterus with attached cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries weighing 163g in total.  The uterus measures 70 x 50 x 35mm and has a dull, congested serosal surface.  There is minimal ectocervix present and the remnant tissue measures 20 x 20mm and appears haemorrhagic.

On opening, the endometrium measures less than 1mm in thickness and the myometrium up to 20mm. A 9mm endometrial polyp is present within the posterior fundus.  The myometrium contains fibroids up to 20mm.

The rightfallopian tube measures 50mm in length and up to 5mm in diameter. Multiple parafimbrial cysts up to 3mm are present.  The right ovary measures 28 x 21 x 15mm and has a granular, haemorrhagic serosal surface.On sectioning, the ovary has a nodular cut surface with multiple cysts up to 8mm containing straw-coloured fluid.

The left fallopian tube measures50mm in length and up to 6mm in diameter.  Paratubal cysts up to 4mm are present.  The left ovary is partly solid and partly cystic, measuring 75 x 55 x 40mm.  The outer surface appears predominantly smooth with some adherent omentum and patchy granularity.  Sectioning reveals firm white tumour within the solid areas.  The cystic areas contain yellow gelatinous material.

Blocks 1-4 - full LS anterior body and cervix; 5-6 - further representative anterior endometrium; 7-11 - full LS posterior body and cervix (9/10 paired); 12 & 13 - further representative posterior endometrium; 14 & 15 - representative right ovary; 16 - representative right tube; 17-22 - representative left ovary; 23 - representative left tube; 24 - representative right parametrium; 25 - representative left parametrium; 26 - tumour reserve block; 26 to 31 - Re-select, remainder of ovaries and tubes.

A.  A section of the posterior cervix shows a focus of ulceration and reactive change in the squamous and columnar epithelium.  Focally just beneath the serosal surface of the posterior cervix there is a deposit of serous carcinoma.  The cervix is otherwise unremarkable.

Sections of the endometrium show that this is mainly inactive and there is a benign endometrial polyp.  However there are foci of serous carcinoma in situ in the endometrium.  No myometrial invasion is seen.  No lymphovascularinvasion is seen. There are leiomyomas and there is adenomyosis in the myometrium.  On the serosal surface of the uterus there are scattered foci of high grade serous carcinoma bothanteriorly and posteriorly.

Sections of the left fallopian tube show invasive serous carcinoma at the fimbrial end.  The invasive tumour measures around 6mm in main diameter.There is also carcinoma in situ at the fimbrial ends of both fallopian tubes.

Sections of both ovaries show quite extensive moderately differentiated serous carcinoma on the serosal surfaces but only focally more deeply within the ovaries.  The main described cyst in the left ovary is benign.
A section of the right parametrium shows focal serous carcinoma on the serosal surface. The left parametrium is unremarkable.
B.  Sections show two lymph nodes.  No tumour is seen.
C.  Section shows one lymph node.  No tumour is seen.

D.  Sections of omentum show extensive involvement by moderately differentiated serous carcinoma, mainly in fibrous septae between the fat lobules.   One uninvolved small lymph node is also identified in the omentum.

A.   Serous carcinoma at fimbrial end of left fallopian tube and involving serosa of both ovaries, uterus, posterior cervix and right parametrium.  Serous carcinoma in situ atfimbrial end of right tube.  Serous carcinoma in situ of endometrium.  Uterine leiomyomas and adenomyosis.
B.   Right common iliac lymph nodes:  No tumour (0/2).
C.   Right external iliac lymph node:  No tumour (0/1).

The features are most consistent with a primary moderately differentiated serous carcinomaof the fimbrial end of the left tube, with metastases in the omentum, on the serosa of both ovaries and on the uterine serosa.  There is also serous carcinoma in situ in the endometrium but it is noted thatthe previous uterine curettings and cervical cone biopsy (44S69897) showed extensive serous carcinoma in the endometrium and serous carcinoma involving cervical glands and stroma.  The endometrial and cervical tumour also seem likely to be metastatic from the left tube.  There is also serous carcinoma in-situ at the fimbrial end of the right tube.
Stains for hormone receptors were requested on this specimen but were instead done on the previous uterine currettings specimen (44S69897O); please see that specimen for result.

A.  Sections are of skin extending to deep subcutis, including skeletal muscle at the deep aspect. The 35mm tumour is aleiomyosarcoma. The leiomyosarcoma is composed of moderately pleomorphic malignant spindled cells arranged intersecting fascicles, with increased mitotic activity (up to 30 mitoses/10 hpf) and areas of necrosis. The tumour is 2mm from the deep margin and 1.6mm from the peripheral margin. Immunohistochemical stains show typical SMA and desmin positivity, as well as, focal CD10 positivity. A KI-67 highlights up to 95% of tumour cell nuclei.
B.  Sections of the two right external iliac lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy (0/2).

C.  The 55mm right iliac fossa mass is a malignant spindle cell tumour. The morphology is similar to the anterior abdominal wall tumour and is consistent with a leiomyosarcoma. The degree of cytologic atypia appears greater within this right iliac fossa tumour. The tumour is partially surrounded by a thin cuff of fibrocollagenous tissue, but focally abuts the inked margin.

D.  Theleft anterior abdominal wall tumour is a malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with leiomyosarcoma. The appearance is similar to the previously described abdominal wall and right iliac fossa tumours. The tumour deposit is surrounded by a variably thick rim of fibrocollagenous tissue and is focally less than 0.1mm from the inked margin.

E.  Sections of the small bowel tumour show a malignant spindle cell tumour consistent withleiomyosarcoma. The tumour is largely fragmented and appears focally attached to the outer muscularis mucosa/serosa of the small bowel. The small bowel mucosa and submucosa show no significant histologic abnormality. The tumour is extensively fragmented after processing and accurate assessment of margins is difficult.
ER and PR immuno-histochemistry was requested and the results are as follows:
- Block A5: ER positive (80% predominantly moderate); PR negative (<1%).
- Block C2: ER positive (75% moderate to strong); PR negative.
B.  Right external iliac lymph node: No evidence of malignancy in two lymph nodes (0/2).
C.  Right iliac fossa mass: Leiomyosarcoma, present at margins.
D.  Left anterior abdominal wall: Leiomyosarcoma, focally less than 0.1mm from the inked margins.

Sections of omentum show extensive infiltration by a high grade carcinoma with solid and papillary architecture.  The tumour cells contain highly pleomorphic nuclei with coarse chromatin and occasional prominent nucleoli.  Occasional cells show smudged hyperchromatic chromatin. The tumour cells show strong positive staining with CA125 andCK7.  The CK20, CDX2 and TTF-1 stains are negative.
The morphological appearance and immunohistochemical profile is consistent with serous carcinoma of the gynaecological tract.

A-C.  Sections show three separate invasive carcinomas.  The main carcinoma at 1-2 o'clock 45mm FN is a grade 2 infiltrating lobular carcinoma (tumour 1).  A separate grade 2 infiltrating lobular carcinoma (tumour 2) is present around the large  subareolar ducts of the nipple and is approximately 30mm from the main carcinoma.  An incidental 2.3mm grade 1 infiltrating tubular carcinoma (tumour 3) is present about 2mm deep to tumour 2.

Paraffin sections of the single sentinel lymph node show a minute cluster of tumour cells with occasional intracytoplasmic lumina within the subcapsular sinus measuring <0.1mm in maximum dimension (detected on an H&E stained section, block A1L2). This particular area has cut out on deeper levels examined with H&E and keratin immunostains, however, in adjacent tissue in the same cross section keratin immunostained sections reveal further dispersed single tumour cells within the subcapsular sinus distributed over an area of 4mm.  The total number of tumour cellsin this cross section, both H&E and keratin immunostain detected number less than 200 cells and is consistent with node involvement by isolated tumour cells of lobular carcinoma.  However in a separate cross section of the sentinel lymph node, keratin immunostains reveal a further minute cluster of cohesive and single tumour cells 0.3mm in dimension as well as dispersed single cells in the subcapsular and medullary sinuses, distributed over an area of 5mm.  While an interpretation of this second separate focus of intranodal tumour cells as isolated tumour cells is possible (the 0.3mm cluster is not strictly a completely cohesive and expansile cluster and the total number of tumour cells in this crosssection number less than 200 cells), I have classified it as a micrometastasis (recognizing overlap in the definition).
The left axillary tissue submitted (specimen C) is composed of fatty tissue only.
A synoptic report for breast carcinoma follows.

The firm area described grossly corresponds to lobules showing some stromal fibrosclerosis. Rare foci of benign glandular calcification are present.

The invasive carcinoma is 1mm to the inferior margin (block B8 and B13), is 1.5mm to the superior margin (block B5), is 2mm to the deep margin (block B12) and is 2.5mm to the deep margin (block B9). The medial margin is well clear.  The tumour cells are strongly positive for ER and PR.  The stain for HER-2 is negative.  The breast tissue away from the tumour shows fibrocystic change.

Sections show a 45mm grade 3 infiltrating ductal carcinoma, NOS located at 3 o'clock 70mm from the nipple.  The tumour is composed of moderately pleomorphic with occasional nucleoli and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged mainly in solid nests with minimal tubule formation within a fibrotic and focally myxoid stroma. There is prominent retraction artefact but numerous foci of definite lymphovascular invasion are seen beyond the tumour margins. The second tumour in the lateral breast at 2 o'clock 80mm from the nipple is a 20mm intramammary lymph node completely replaced by metastatic tumour (block A17) with foci of extranodal extension. It displays identical morphology to the main tumour. Two (2) other intramammary lymph nodes are free of tumour.  Eighteen (18) of twenty (29) nine left axillary lymph nodes contain metastatic carcinoma (specimens B & C) and there are numerous foci of extranodal extension. One inta (sic) pectoral lymph node (specimen D) is completely replaced by tumour withextranodal extension measuring about 5mm into extranodal fat over a front of 7mm and focally invading the adventitial layer of a large vein. No striated muscle is seen around the lymph node. A synoptic report for breast carcinoma follows:
Lymphovascular invasion:  Present; numerous foci (at least 6) beyond advancing edge.
Degree of DCIS in tumour:  Moderate
DCIS in adjacent tissue:  Moderate; mostly close to advancing edge of tumour; a small focus at least 20mm medial to the tumour.
HER2 (Novocastra 10A7): Negative: Approximately 20% of tumour cells show weak incomplete membrane staining.
LCIS / ALH:    There is focal Pagetoid involvement of a duct by lobular neoplasia (block A4).

Miscellaneous:  Away from the tumour there are a spectrum of benign changes including cystic change, apocrine metaplasia, columnar cell change, columnar cell hyperplasia, , adenosis, sclerosing adenosis, several benign intraduct papillomas and epithelial hyperplasia of usual type. There is also a lobule and a duct which are partiallyinvolved by columnar cell hyperplasia with architectural atypia and mild cytological atypia (approaching ADH) (block A13). The haemorrhagic area medial to the tumour described grossly corresponds to core biopsy tracts, acute and subacute stromal haemorrhage, stromal fibrosclerosis and adenosis.

A.  Sectionsshow a high grade carcinoma arranged in sheets, trabeculae and papillae containing fibrovascular cores, with extensive areas of necrosis.  The tumour cells have a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm with pleomorphic nuclei containing coarse chromatin and small nucleoli.  Focally the tumour has a squamoid appearance and no glandular formation is seen.  Abundant mitoses are present.  The tumour lies adjacent and focally adherent to the ovary, which otherwise appears normal.  A section of normal fallopian tube is also identified.  The tumour shows strong positive staining with CK7, CA125 and WT1.  The CK20 and CK5/6 stains are negative.

Although the tumour cells have very similar morphology that seen in the previously diagnosed high grade urothelial carcinoma (L7 CONSULTING ROOMS: Q11478963), the immunohistochemical profile is different.  The urothelial carcinoma shows positive staining with CK7 and CK20, plus focal staining with CK5/6.  The CA125 stain is negative.

It is thus concluded that the current tumour may not represent a recurrence of urothelial carcinoma, but instead is favoured to represent a poorly differentiated mulleriancarcinoma.  As a normal ovary and fallopian tube are present, the tumour may be of peritoneal origin.

B.  The ectocervix and endocervix show no significant abnormality.  The endometrium is inactive and contains a small benign endometrial polyp.  The myometrium, fallopian tubes and left ovary show no significant abnormality.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
C.  Sections of the omentum show no significant abnormality.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
This case has been reviewed by Dr Q Ankersen.

A to C. Sections show a cellular lesion, composed of sheets of tumour cells with small ovoid to elongated nuclei and minimal cytoplasm.  Scattered mitoses, endothelial proliferation, palisading and non-palisading necrosis are present. Areas of infarction, haemorrhage withhaemosiderin and haematoidin deposition are seen. Focally there are thin walled vessels present in the background.

Together with immunohistochemical findings, the features would favour a glioblastoma (WHO grade 4), small cell variant.  1p/19q and EGFR FISH testing will be performed to exclude the possibility of an anaplastic oligodendroglioma.

This case was analysed for 1p/19q LOH using Vysis dual colour probe sets LSI 19q13/19p13.  Cut off values were adopted Smith et al. 2000 (J ClinOncol: 18;636-645) who defined a 1p/1q ratio of <0.85 and a 19q/19p ratio of <0.9 as indicating LOH.  The case was also hybridised with Vysis LSI EGFR/Cep7 dual colour probe pair to assess whether amplification of EGFR was present.

CONCLUSION:  EGFR amplification is present, consistent with (primary) small cell glioblastoma.

Specimen labelled "Small bowel" consists of a portion of bowel 302mm in length and up to 40mm in maximal diameter.  There is a stricture present 42mm from one end.  On opening, the lumen is narrowed by a sessile tumour measuring 16mm wide and 18mm long.  There is a nodule measuring 4mm diameter on the serosal surface located 110mm from the end closest to the tumour.  The mucosa away from the tumour is oedematous but otherwise unremarkable.

Blocks:  1 - serosal surface with nodule; 2 - margin distant from tumour; 3 - LS margin close to tumour; 4 - full face tumour with deepest extension; 5 - tumour with normal mucosa away from margin; 6 - tumour with normal mucosa closest to surgical margin; 7 - tumour reserve block if appropriate; 8 & 9 - mesentery with possible lymph nodes.

Sections show small intestinal wall with a neuroendocrine tumour.  This consists of nests, trabeculae and cords of cells with medium sized and large, relatively uniform round nuclei and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm.  The nuclei have fine granular chromatin and sometimes a small nucleolus.  Some tumour cells have pink cytoplasmic granules.  The tumour forms occasional small glands.  The mucosal surface of the tumour is ulcerated.  It arises from the mucosa and invades through the muscularis propria with an infiltrative appearance, and into subserosal tissue.  It appears to breach the serosal surface very focally.  The assessment of lymphovascular invasion is difficult because of retraction artefact around the tumour cell nests but there is considered to be some lymphovascular invasion in the bowel wall and also multifocal lymphovascular invasion in the attached mesentery.  No perineural invasion is identified.  Mitoses are infrequent, less than 1 per 10 high power fields, and there is no tumour necrosis.  The proliferation index with a Ki-67 stain is low, estimated at 2%.  With other immunostains the tumour cells stain strongly chromogranin positive and also show some patchy, weaksynaptophysin positivity.

The sections of small bowel elsewhere are unremarkable and the proximal and distal margins are well clear.  The described separate serosal nodule is a focus of scarring and foreign body reaction, possiblyrelated to previous surgery; no tumour is seen in this nodule.

Only two very small lymph nodes were identified in the mesentery despite repeated careful searching and these are both free of tumour.  However mesenteric tumour in vessels is likely to come close to proximal vascular margins in the attached mesentery.
The appearances are of a well differentiated neuroendocrine tumour (carcinoid tumour, WHO grade 1).
Small bowel segment:  Well differentiated neuroendocrine tumour (carcinoid tumour, WHO grade 1).  pT4 N0.  Multifocal lymphovascular invasion in mesentery, see text.

Sections through the mesenteric nodule show a 35mm deposit of well differentiated neuroendocrine tumour (carcinoid tumour). The appearance is identical to that of the previously reported small bowel carcinoid tumour (62Y96033). The deposit expands the mesentery and is partially surrounded by a cuff of variably dense fibrous tissue and mesenteric fat. Focally, the tissue overlying the tumour deposit is replaced by inflamed granulation tissue. There are scattered foci of lymphovascular space invasion. One of five sampled lymph nodes show metastatic tumour (1/5). The tumour does not involve the overlying bowel wall. The bowel adjacent to the presumed anastomotic site show mild non-specific mucosal chronic inflammatory change with expansion of the lamina propria and thickened intestinal villi. The bowel wall is viable and there are scattered serosal adhesions, including a focal mild foreign body response to polarisable (?suture) material. The surgical margins appear clear of tumour.

Sections of the right breast tissue show widespread involvement by a spectrum of proliferative changes. There is extensive columnar cell change/hyperplasia, apocrine metaplasia/hyperplasia, fibrocystic change, pseudo-angiomatous stromal hyperplasia, adenosis/apocrine adenosis, a benign intra-duct papilloma and numerous benign microcalcifications. Scattered foci of atypical apocrine hyperplasia, as well as, focal atypical ductal hyperplasia (apocrine-type - block 12), are also present. Atypical apocrine hyperplasia is 1.1mm from the superior and lateralmargins and is clear of the remaining margins (>5.5mm). The focus of atypical ductal hyperplasia is 2.2mm from the superior margin and clear of the remaining margins (>10mm). Scattered microcalcifications are present in association with the atypical apocrine hyperplasia and atypical ductal hyperplasia (apocrine type). There are numerous foci of atypical lobular hyperplasia/lobular carcinoma in situ (ALH/LCIS) throughout the entire biopsy. A focus of organising haemorrhage and a biopsy tract, consistent with recent biopsy are present. The overlying skin shows a focus of dermocutaneous scar, but there are no features of Paget's disease. There is no convincing DCIS or evidence of invasive carcinoma.
Representative slides of this case have been shown to Dr A Glausier.

Specimen labelled "Liver resection (right hemi)" consists of a hemihepatectomy with gallbladder attached measuring 155 x 95 x 85mm.  Specimen was received with an incision through the capsule.  Three deposits of cream ill defined tumour are identified all which abut the capsular surface.  Lesion 1 measures 90 x 65 x 65mm and comes to 20mm from the surgical resectionmargin.  Lesion 2 measures 35 x 35 x 33mm and comes to 24mm from the surgical resection margin.  Lesion 3 measures 10 x 10 x 8mm and is well clear of the surgical resection margin.  Each of the lesions has large amounts of necrosis identified within it.  Lesion 1 appears to be situated posteriorly and the tumour is seen to abut the ? bare area. The remainder of the liver appears unremarkable.  The gallbladder measures 80mm in length with a maximal external diameter of40mm.  The serosa appears unremarkable.  The maximum thickness of the wall is 3mm.  The mucosa appears smooth and velvety.  No gallstones are identified.  No cystic duct lymph node is identified.

Blocks:  1 to 3 - lesion 1; 4 & 5 -lesion 2; 6 - lesion 3; 7 - uninvolved liver; 8 - representative gallbladder; 9 - reserved block; 10 to 13 - representative lesion 1 to ? bare area; 14 - lesion 1 including junction of peritonealised and bare area.   (TO: DF; BW/mm 3.12.63)

Sections show three separate subcapsular deposits of moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma ranging from 10mm to 90mm in maximum dimension.  The deposits are predominantly composed of a cribriform or fenestrated arrangement of large malignant glands lined by cells with moderately pleomorphic nuclei.  There is  prominent central necrosis within the complex large glands.  A lesser component of smaller malignant tubular glands is also present.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is seen (some peritumoural retraction artefact and tumour carry over).
The closest deposit is 17mm clear of the surgical resection margin and abuts but does not appear to penetrate the liver capsule at the bare (non-peritonealised) area of the liver (block 14).

Away from the deposits the liver displays a normal lobular architecture.  The portal tracts contain a normal complement of bile ducts, hepatic arteries and hepatic veins and there is no significant portal fibrosis or inflammation.  Apart from minimal patchy macrovascular steatosis the hepatocytes are unremarkable.  An occasional portal Von-Meyenberg complex (bile duct hamartoma) is noted.  The gallbladder is essentially normal.
The tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK20 (patchy minimal), TTF1 (Novocastra clone SPT24 - diffuse strong), CDX2 (diffuse strong).

In the context of a rectal lesion the morphological appearances and diffuse CDX2 immunoexpression are compatible with metastatic rectal adenocarcinoma.  However, the presence of minimal patchy positive tumoural CK20 immunostaining and diffusely positive TTF1 immuonstaining is unusual for colorectal carcinoma.  Thelatter finding is more typically seen in lung adenocarcinoma or thyroid carcinomas but positive expression has been reported in a subset of colorectal adenocarcinomas with the TTF1 antibody used in this case (Novocastra SPT24 clone).  Further clinical and radiological correlation is advised. Comparison with the morphological appearances of the rectal biopsy may be helpful.
-  Three deposits of metastatic moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma 10 to 90mm in maximum dimension (see comment).
-  17mm clear of surgical resection margin and abutting the bare (non-peritonealised) area of the liver.
Mid rectal cancer 8cm from verge, ULAR,  3cm distal margin post wall vagina taken en block.  Previous neo adj. therapy.

The 45mm pancreatic head tumour is a well differentiated pancreatic endocrine neoplasm, intermediate grade. A synoptic for pancreatic endocrine neoplasms follows:
Histologic type (WHO classification): Well differentiated pancreatic endocrine neoplasm.
Histologic grade (TNM grading system): Intermediate grade (2 - 50 mitoses/50 hpf OR foci of necrosis).

Tumour description: The tumour is predominantly circumscribed and encapsulated with a partially separated tumour lobule identified focally. The tumour is composed of moderately pleomorphic neuroendocrine tumour cells arranged in variably thick trabeculae surrounded by an anastomosing network of thin walled vessels. Scattered tumour cells show marked pleomorphism and nuclear hyperchromasia.
Mitotic rate (mitoses per 50 hpf): 8 mitoses per 50hpf.
Perineural invasion of retroperitoneal (periuncinate) neural plexus: Not identified.
Presence of unusual histologic features: Inconspicuous.

Presence of other pathological components: The adjacent pancreatic parenchyma shows patchy fibrosis, acinar atrophy, fat necrosis, autolysis and focal PAN-IN 1B. PAN-IN is not seen at the pancreatic neck margin. The sections of small bowel and ampulla appear within normal histologic limits. The separate small bowel "polyp" shows features of pancreatic heterotopia. The gallbladder shows mild non-specific chronic cholecystitis and is partiallyobscured by mucosal autolysis.
Presence of non-ischaemic tumour necrosis: Not identified.
Extension out of pancreas: Not identified.
Involvement of serosal/peritoneal surfaces: Not identified.
Invasion of adjacent organs/structures: Not identified.
Distance of invasive tumour from resection margins:
Periuncinate soft tissue: Clear of tumour (macroscopic).
Common bile duct: Clear of tumour.
Small bowel margins: Clear of tumour (>10mm).
Number of lymph nodes from main resection specimen: Six.
Numberof involved lymph nodes from main resection specimen: None of six (0/6).
Separately received lymph nodes: Not included.
Ki-67 immunoproliferative index: Variable, up to 3% of tumour cell nuclei positive.
45mm, pTNM stage IB, well differentiated endocrine neoplasm of pancreatic head, intermediate grade.
Tumour is close to the posterior margin (1.1mm) and anterior margin (3.3mm) and is clear of the remaining margins (>5.5mm).
No evidence of malignancy in six peri-pancreatic lymph nodes (0/6).
Location:  MEDIC/SURGERY WARD-NARROMINE HOSPITAL & COMMUNITY HEALTH

A.  Specimen labelled "Stomach" consists of a total gastrectomy with attached omentum. The wall of the distal oesophagus and proximal stomach (up to proximal body) is expanded by an exophytic circumscribed tumour 75 x 50 x 40mm. The tumour is lined by intact mucosa with and area of possible ulceration 10 mm in diameter in the oesophagus. The tumour extends into the stomach along the anterior wall and lesser curve. The serosa of the stomach is smooth and shiny and appears uninvolved. The cut surface of the tumour is lobulated, solid andwell circumscribed with fibrous appearance there are no areas of haemorrhage or necrosis.  The mucosal surface surrounding the tumour has a flattened appearance. The rest of the gastric mucosa is homogenous and smooth. Proximal margin isinked blue, distal margin black and proximal serosal surface green.

Blocks: 1 to 3 -closest  proximal margin; 4 - proximal margin; 5 - tumour with normal mucosa; 6 - tumour with  lesser omentum; 7 - tumour; 9 - tumour with flattened surrounding mucosa; 10 and 11 - tumour; 12 - tumour with distal mucosa; 13 - representative fundus; 14 - representative antral; 15 - distal margin; 16 & 17 - representative section of fatty serosal nodule; 18 to 20 - greatest curve lymph nodes; 21 to 23 - lesser curve lymph node; 24 & 25 - representative sections of omentum.

B.Specimen labelled "Small bowel" consists of an unorientated segment of small intestine 80 x 20mm. The external surface is unremarkable.  The mucosal surface is smooth and homogeneous.  No lesions are identified.  The surgical margins are inked black and blue.
Blocks:  1 - surgical margins; 2 - representative sections from normal mucosa.

A.  The 75mm polypoid tumour is a leiomyoma.  The circumscribed unencapsulated tumour straddles the cardio-oesophageal junction.  The tumour expands the wall of the distal oesophagus and extends into the upper stomach along its anterior wall reaching the proximal body.  Within the distal oesophagus the tumour appears to be focally continuous with attenuated muscularis mucosa and pushesinto outer muscularis propria. Within the mucosa and submucosa are univolved and the tumour expands the muscularis propria compartment displacing the native smooth muscle fibres.  The overlying gastro-oesophageal mucosais non-ulcerated, however in the distal oesophagus the surface is depressed and lined by attenuated stratified squamous epithelium showing reactive change, overlying a focus of granulation tissue; the appearances suggest regeneration overa prior ulcer.

The leiomyoma has a lobulated multinodular configuration with a main circumscribed nodule plus a few smaller adjacent nodules.  The tumour is composed of broad fascicles of hypocellular fairly uniform cells with bipolar elongated nuclei, pale chromatin, small nucleoli and eosinophilic cytoplasm.  An isolated typical mitotic figure is seen (<1/50 hpf) but no cellular areas, significant nuclear pleomorphism or tumour necrosis is seen.  The tumour is 2mm clear of the proximal (oesophageal) resection margin and well clear of the distal (duodenum) resection margin.
Four (4) lesser omental and sixteen (16) greater omental lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy.
The tumour cells stain as follows:
Negative:  CD117 (minimal background staining and mast cells positive), S100 (minimal non-specific background staining), CD34 (highlights capillaries).
The Ki67 proliferation index is less than 1%.

The oesophageal squamous epithelium shows mild patchy lymphocytic exocytosis and very mild patchy submucosal non-specific chronic inflammation.  No glandular metaplasia, intestinal metaplasia or dysplasia is seen.  There is mild chronic carditis and very mild non-specified gastritis within the gastric body and antrum.  No Helicobacter organisms are seen and no intestinal metaplasia or dysplasia is seen.  The duodenal villi are mostly denuded but the residual mucosa and wall show nosignificant abnormality.

The loosely attached haemorrhagic and nodular portion of adipose tissue described grossly anteriorly near the antrum shows subserosal organising haemorrhage, organising thrombus with vessels, patchy fat necrosis and organising septal fibrosis.  The aetiology is unclear but torsion is a possibility.
There is no evidence of malignancy.
B.Sections show unremarkable small bowel wall including essentially normal mucosa.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
- 2mm clear of closest (oesophageal) resection margin, well clear of distal (duodenal) margin
- Mild non-specific chronic carditis and very mild non-specific chronic gastritis

MICROSCOPIC (reported by Dr J Regner & Dr J Forguson):

Sections of kidney show a well circumscribed tumour arising from the renal cortex.  The tumour is composed of cords, nests and trabeculae of plump eosinophilic cells with moderate amounts of granular eosinophilic cytoplasm.  There are focal areas with cystic dilatation and other areas with a loose oedematous stroma.  The nuclei are centrallyplaced with smooth round borders, even chromatin and occasional small nucleoli.  No mitoses are identified and no necrosis is seen. The Hale's colloidal ironstain show occasional focal cytoplasmic staining.
Immunohistochemical stains show positive staining for CD117, patchy weak staining for CD10 and focal single cell staining for CK7.  The vimentin stain is negative.
The morphological appearance and immunohistochemical profile are consistent with a renal oncocytoma.
The tumour abuts the renal capsule and is 2mm clear of the surgical resection margin.  The uninvolved renal tissue shows no significant abnormality.

The cut surface reveals a haemorrhagic necrotic and partly cream-tan tumour taking up the majority of the testis measuring 68 x 36 x 34mm.  The tumour does not appear to invade into the rete testis or into the tunica vaginalis.

Sections of testis show a mixed germ cell tumour including a mixture of embryonal carcinoma (70%), yolk sac tumour (25%) and choriocarcinoma (5%).  Intratubular germ cell neoplasia is present.  Focal areas of necrosis and haemorrhage are present.  There is evidence of focal lymphovascular invasion (block 4).  The tumour is limited to the testis.  The tumour invades the tunica albuginea butnot the tunica vaginalis.  The tumour is completely excised and the resection margin is well clear.  The spermatic cord is unremarkable.  The epididymis is unremarkable.  There is no evidence of perineural invasion.

A&B. Both specimens show similar features and consist of cerebellum infiltrated by sheets and cohesive nests of large cells with pleomorphic nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. Mitotic activity is brisk and large areas of necrosis are present. While the overall appearance of the tumour is poorly differentiated,several foci of possible glandular differentiation are seen in the Diastase stain, consistent with a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma.

Comment: The posterior fossa tumour is a metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma, favour adenocarcinoma. Melanoma and neuroendocrine markers are negative. PSA and TTF-1 negativity makes prostate and lung primaries unlikely, respectively.  CDX-2 is a marker of intestinal differentiation and can be seen in adenocarcinomas of GI tract, pancreas and biliary origin. CK7 positivity and CK20negativity makes an upper GI primary more likely. Correlation with clinical and radiologic findings is required.
A&B. POSTERIOR FOSSA: METASTATIC POORLY DIFFERENTIATED CARCINOMA, FAVOUR ADENOCARCINOMA. SEE COMMENT

A.Specimen labelled "Right hemicolectomy for sarcoma" consists of a right hemicolectomy measuring 330mm in length with a section of attached terminal ileum 155mm.  The appendix is not present. The piece overlying the terminal ileum measures 70 x 65 x 38mm and is 25mm from the proximal resection margin.  There are multiple nodules on the serosa of the caecum and ascending colon; these are covered by peritoneum and have a smooth surface.  The serosal nodules involve a length of 130mm and extend to a point 55mm from the distal excision margin.  On sectioning, the nodulesconsist of uniform fatty tissue which abut and push into the bowel wall but do not appear to penetrate into or through the muscularis propria.  Multiple diverticula are identified within the colonic mucosa.  One large diverticulum has a firm hard black nodule of impacted faeces within it.  Two possibe lymph nodes are identified within the colonic mesenteric fat.  Two donuts of bowel wall are received separately withthe specimen, measuring 50 and 25mm in maximum dimension.

The tumour abuts the muscularis propria of the ileum and colon and it extends through the muscularis propria into the submucosa of thecolon in at least one area (block A4).  There are occasional foci where the tumour shows an increase in cellularity and atypia but no de-differentiation is seen.  Three lymph nodes which were found in the mesenteric fat are unremarkable.  There is a fibrous capsule overlying part of the tumour and a small amount of liver tissue isnoted attached to this capsule in one section (block A12).  Tumour involves subserosal fat at the resection margin of the terminal ileum (block A).  Sections of the two separate donuts show unremarkable small and large intestinal wall.

B.  Sections show liposarcoma with some adjacent small bowel wall.  The tumour is adherent to, and focally invades into, the outer muscularis propria of the small bowel wall.  The tumour is sclerosing-type.  No de-differentiation is seen.
C.  Sections show a nodule of well differentiated sclerosing liposarcoma.  Focally the tumour is moderately cellular and shows more marked atypia (block C3) but no
de-differentiation, with the histologic pattern seen in the previous tumour (59B23808), is seen.

A.  Specimen labelled "Liver" consists of a right segment of liver 70mm (medial-lateral) x 170mm (anterior-posterior) and 220mm (superior-inferior).  The serosal surface is unremarkable.  The surgical margin is inked green.  Two white solid nodules are identified measuring 5 and 10mm in maximum diameter.  The largest nodule is 12mm from the surgical margin and the smallest one is more than 30mm from the surgical margin.  The rest of the parenchyma is unremarkable.
Blocks:  1 & 2 - small metastasis; 3 to 5 - large tumour (block 4 - reserve block); 6 & 7 - normal liver.

B.  Specimen labelled "Gallbladder" consists of an enlarged gallbladder 95 x 50 x 30mm.  The external surface has a few adhesions.  The mucosal surface is green and velvety.  It is filled with bile.  No gallstones are identified.  The wall has a maximum thickness of 2mm.
Blocks:  1 - one TS resection margin cystic duct and one TS neck; 2 - cystic duct lymph node; 3 - TS body; 4 - two LS fundus.   (ND/cc 1/3/63)
A.  Sections confirm the presence of two foci of moderately to well differentiated adenocarcinoma, 5mm and 10mm in maximum macroscopic dimension, respectively.
Immunohistochemical stainswere performed and the results are as follows:
Carcinoma cells positive for: CK20, CK19.
Carcinoma cells negative for: CK7, hepar-1, TTF-1, PSA.
The overall morphology and pattern of immunohistochemical staining would be consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma of primary colorectal origin.

The adjacent non-neoplastic liver shows preservation of overall hepatic architecture. The hepatocellular cords areregular and are of normal thickness. The portal tracts are of normal size and show patchy mild chronic inflammation. The portal tract structures, including bile ducts and portal vessels, are normal. There is a mild to moderate increase in stainable iron in the hepatocytes in a diffuse distribution (grade 2 of 4 - Modified Scheuer score). Otherwise, the hepatocytes show mild reactive changes. The lobules contain patchy mild macrovesicular steatosis and scattered foci of mild inflammation. A reticulin and masson's trichrome stain show no significant fibrosis or evidence of cirrhosis. There is no increase in stainable copper. No diPAS positive alpha-1-antitrypsin globules are present. No cytoplasmic viral inclusions are seen.

B.  Sections of gallbladder show chronic cholecystitis. The gallbladder wall shows mild fibromuscular hyperplasia, minimal Rokitansky Aschoff sinus formation and patchy mild chronicinflammation. There are no unusual features. The cystic duct lymph node shows lipogranulomatosis. There is no evidence of dysplasia or malignancy.

The liver contains two foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma, with features consistent with primary colorectal origin. There is also a mild to moderate increase in stainable iron (grade2 of 4), raising the possibility of hereditary haemochromatosis. There is also mild non-specific portal inflammation and patchy mild macrovesicular steatosis.
Representative slides seen with Dr H Mardirosian.
Metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with primary colorectal origin.
Mild to moderate increase in stainable iron (grade 2 of 4), raising the possibility of hereditary haemochromatosis.
Mild non-specific portal inflammation and patchy mild macrovesicular steatosis.

A.   Sections show a grade 3 papillary renal cell carcinoma with nucleoli easily identified (x10 objective). The tumour measures 28 x 25 x 22mm and is classified as a type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma (the tumour cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm). There is no tumour necrosis.  The tumour invades through the renal capsuleinto perinephric fat and is focally present at the perinephric margin.  There is a fibrous adhesion between the tumour and the segment of colon and this dense fibrous adhesion contains scattered small tumour aggregates (T4 - beyond Gerota's fascia).

The tumour does not invade the renal hilum or pelvicalyceal system and there is no abnormality of the renal vessels or proximal ureter.  The kidney away from the tumour appears normal and one small uninvolved perinephric lymph node is identified.

The segment of colon shows no abnormality and the five small mesenteric lymph nodes identified are free of tumour. There is a focus of fat necrosis and dense fibrosis within the mesentery which also contains an occasional tumour aggregate.  This focus within the mesentery is unrelated to the adhesion between the tumour and the colon.
There is also organising haemorrhage within the perirenal fat consistent with a recent core/FNA.

B.   The large paracaval mass has the appearance of metastatic papillary renal cell carcinoma and there is a small amount of residual node at the periphery of the mass.  This mass shows focal perinodal infiltration.
C.   Three (3) of the four (4) distal paracaval lymph nodes identified are partly or totally replaced by metastatic papillary renal cell carcinoma.  (ec)

Interphase FISH detected high-level of MDM2, relative to the 12 centromere loci. Nuclei were seen with mostIy two (2) copies of 12 centromere, but occasionally larger nuclei showed four (4) copies of this (reference) locus.

The attached fallopian tube shows no evidence of malignancy.

The endometrium is atrophic. There is no evidence of hyperplasia or malignancy.
The cervix shows no evidence of CIN or HPV effect.
D. Sections show poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma completely replacing the left ovary, and also involving the left fallopian tube.
Tumour is present in the pericolic fat.  The lesion abuts but does not invade into the wall of the sigmoid colon.
9 peri-colic lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy.

G. Sections show a deposit of poorly differentiated serous adenocarcinoma. The lesion abuts but does not invade into the attached detrusor muscle.
H. Sections show omental fat with no evidence of malignancy.
