A.  Sections of the endometrium shows a grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma.  The tumour consists of complex and branched endometrial glands lined by atypical columnar epithelial cells.  There is some squamous metaplasia however no areas of solid growth are seen.  There is superficial myometrial invasion.  Maximum depth of invasion is 4mm out of a total myometrial thickness of 10mm.  There is no lymphovascular invasion.  There is probable focal tumour involvement of the surface of the endocervix but no cervical stromal invasion is seen; the focus of probable surface cervical involvement is 14mm from the ectocervical margin.  The cervix is otherwise unremarkable.  The endometrium away from the tumour is inactive.  Several benign leiomyomas are confirmed.  The parametrial tissue is unremarkable.
B. Sections from the abdominal wall show skeletal muscle and adipose tissue with marked fibrosis. There is no evidence of malignancy.

Carcinoma appears confined to the cervix, but focally (at the posterior left aspect), carcinoma is 0.56mm from paracervical adipose tissue (F23). The tumour is 8.0mm from the ectocervical margin (block F4) and is 4.0mm from the deep margin. No convincing lymphovascular space or perineural invasion is seen. No convincing glandular dysplasia is identified.

Scattered vessels show inflammatory change, most likely related to the adjacent abscess.

Many of the tumour cells have vacuolated cytoplasm; mucin stains (alcian blue and PASD) highlight many macrophages associated with the tumour but no convincing mucin is identified in the cytoplasm of tumour cells. It measures 24mm in length (slides 14 and 15) andaround 25mm wide, and invades the cervical stroma to a depth of 12mm out of a total wall thickness of 21mm. There is also mesonephric hyperplasia in the cervix.
The endometrium shows features of exogenous hormone effect.  Leiomyomas are confirmed in the myometrium.  The ovaries and fallopian tubes are unremarkable.

A.  Sections of ovary showan endometrioid adenocarcinoma admixed with clear cell adenocarcinoma.  Most of the ovary is occupied by the tumour including a mixture of endometrioid adenocarcinoma (65%) and clear cell adenocarcinoma (35%).The endometrioid adenocarcinoma component is well differentiated (grade 1) with grade 1 architecture and grade 2 nuclei.  There is extensive squamous differentiation.  The clear cell adenocarcinoma component shows high grade nuclei with papillary pattern.  The papillae are lined by hobnail cells and have hyalinised cores.  Large areas of necrosis are present.  The fallopian tube is unremarkable.

B.  Sections of uterus show a moderately differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma (grade 2).  The carcinoma shows grade 2 nuclei and grade 2 architecture with 10% solid area.  The carcinoma invades into the outer half of myometrium.  The maximal depth of tumour invasion is 20mm and the myometrial thickness is 22mm (block B2).  The rest of myometrium shows features of adenomyosis and leiomyoma.  The serosa is unremarkable except foci of endometriosis.  There is no evidence of definite lymphovascular invasion.  The carcinoma involves the endocervix and cervical muscle wall.  The cervical/vaginal resection margin is clear.  The parametrium is unremarkable.

PMP - Peritonectomy.  PCI 24.  Peritonectomy.  Bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.  Gallbladder.  Right hemicolectomy.

A.  'OMENTUM + RIGHT COLON'.  Omentum and colon, as well as a number of separate pieces of tissue.  The omentum is approximately 300x300x20mm.  No lesions are seen in the omentum.  The three separate smaller pieces of tissue are approximately 20x20x5mm in aggregate.

The colon consists of terminal ileum, appendix and right colon with some attached pericolic fat and peritoneum.  The ileum is approximately 230mm in length and 30mm in circumference.  The serosal surface and the mesentery are unremarkable.  There are no nodules present.The colon is 280mm in length and 80mm in circumference.  The serosal surface is unremarkable, the wall is 3mm in thickness and the mucosa is unremarkable.  A single diverticulum is noted.  The attached pericolic fat is 100x50x20mm.  There are no nodules present on the surface.  The peritoneum attached to the fatty tissue is 200x150x2mm.  No nodules are present.

The appendix is 60mm in length andat the base is 5mm in diameter for the proximal 10mm and then the appendix is dilated to 18mm in diameter maximally in the remaining appendis.  The wall is 2-3mm in thickness and the lumen is filled with mucin.  The mesoappendix contains a mucinous nodule which is 20mm in maximum dimension.  No perforation is observed.  (1,2 omentum; 3-5 representative samples of separate pieces of tissue; 6and7 proximal end of appendix [the transverse section in block 6 is most proximal]; 8-18 appendix from base to tip; 19 proximal and distal resection margins of small and large bowel; 20 caecum; 21-23 lymph nodes [21 four, 22 three, 23 three]; 24 further section of small bowel; 25 further section of large bowel; 26-30 sections of peritoneum).  RS (30-30).

B.  'RIGHT AND LEFT TUBE AND PERITONEUM OVARY'.  Multiple pieces of tissue which includes fatty tissue peritoneum with attached fat and an attached fallopian tube with ovary and a separate piece of tissue consisting of fallopian tube and ovary.
Fallopian tube and ovary one consists of fallopian tube 50x10mm with an ovary 20x10x10mm.  A mucinous cyst 7mm in diameter is present on the fallopian tube surface.

Fallopian tube two consists of a fallopian tube 50x10mm with attachedovary 20x10x10mm.  There is a well demarcated white whorled nodule 10mm in diameter attached to the ovary.  There is also a cyst 10mm in diameter with a small amount of mucinous material alongside the fallopian tube. The peritoneum is irregularly shaped being approximately 280x60x2-10mm.  There are no solid or mucinous nodules attached.   (1-5 fallopian tube and ovary one; 6-8 fallopian tube and ovary two; 9-11 sections of peritoneum).  RS (M-11).

C.  'GALLBLADDER'.  A closed gallbladder with a staple at the cystic duct.  The gallbladder is 100x40mm.  The serosal surface is smooth and shiny, the wall is 3mm in thickness and the mucosal surface is green and granular.  Numerous stones are present in the fundus measuring an aggregate of 50x50x10mm.  A lymph node  10mm in diameter is present at the cystic duct.  (1 cystic duct and lymph node; 2 body; 3 fundus).  RS (4-3/BI/nh).
Muscularis propria is disrupted by mucin extending through the wall (A16).
Low cellularity mucin with mucinous epithelium present on serosal surface.
Mucinous deposits contain neoplastic mucinous epithelium
Atypia of neoplastic mucinous epithelium is low grade
Some of the peritoneal deposits consist of acellular mucin only.
Sampled mesenteric lymph nodes are negative for tumour (0/8)
The small bowel and colon and gallbladder are otherwise unremarkable.
B. 'Right and left tube and peritoneum ovary'.

The ovaries and tubes show focal surface involvement by low grade pseudomyxoma peritonei.  One ovary shows a paratubal leiomyoma.  The attached peritoneum shows involvement by low grade pseudomyxoma.  There is some mucin in the lumens of the fallopian tubes. The ovaries and tubes are otherwise unremarkable.
The gallbladder has some small serosal deposits of acellular mucin.
A binary (low/high) grading scheme for pseudomyxoma peritonei of appendix origin,

is recommended by WHO (2010). The current peritoneal tumour deposits show features of low grade pseudomyxoma peritonei, broadly equivalent todisseminated peritoneal adenomucinosis (DPAM) (Ronnett 2001). Current TNM recommends staging as peritoneal metastasis (pM1a).

SYNOPTIC REPORT FOR INVASIVE BREAST CARCINOMA

The carcinoma consists of carcinoma cells arranged in infiltrative glands, trabeculae and linear files. The carcinoma is E-Cadherin positive. Although the main tumour nodule seen macroscopically is up to 40mm in dimension, focally, tongues ofcarcinoma extend towards the upper outer quadrant to a maximum dimension of 55mm.
Lymphovascular invasion: Foci suspicious for LVSI are present.
Maximum extent of DCIS: Present in association with invasive carcinoma over an approximate maximum extent of 45mm.
Degree of DCIS in tumour: Minimal.
Predominant intensity of staining: moderate to strong.
HER SISH:  Performed at American Standard Companies, MONTO HOSPITAL Hospital, see separate report.
Nipple: The carcinoma is within breast tissue immediately behind the nipple. Carcinoma cellsabut, but do not appear to involve, the overlying epidermis. There is no convincing Paget's disease.
Lymph node(s): See specimens B and C.

55mm grade 2 left breast carcinoma with associated focal intermediate grade DCIS.
ER and PR positive; HER-2 negative.
Her-2 SISH is being performed and a separate report will be issued.

C.  Axillary lymph nodes (level 2): Metastatic carcinoma in four lymph nodes (4/4). Extranodal extension up to 3.3mm is present.

MICROSCOPIC (reported by Dr G Gantvoort & Dr G Veals):

A.  Sections show carcinosarcoma of the endometrium.  The epithelial component is predominantly serous carcinoma together with large areas of squamous differentiation.  The mesenchymal component is predominantly comprised of malignant ovoid to spindle cells with foci of chondroid differentiation.   Approximately 60% of the tumour is carcinoma while approximately 40% is sarcoma.  No lymphovascular invasion is identified.  Tumour focally involves adenomyosis.

The tumour invades the myometrium to a depth of 24.5mm over a total wall thickness of 25mm.  The serosa appears clear of tumour by 0.5mm.  The specimen is received disrupted making margin assessment difficult however, tumour invades the endocervical stroma coming to within approximately 10mm of the cervical resection margin.  Carcinoma in situ extends into ectocervical squamous epithelium coming to within 7mm of the cervical resection margin.
The tumour shows strong positivity with ER within the epithelial component and is focally positive for PR.
B & C.  Sections of ovary and fallopian tube show no significant abnormality.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
D.  Sections show vaginal squamous mucosa with no significant abnormality.  No discrete lesion is identified.  There is no evidence of malignancy.
E.  Sections show eight (8) lymph nodes which are not involved with tumour.
F.  Sections show ten (10) lymph nodes which are not involved with tumour.
G.  Sections show one (1) lymph node which is not involved with tumour.
H.  Sections show three (3) lymph nodes.  One (1) of the lymph nodes has been replaced by metastatic carcinosarcoma measuring approximately15 mm across.  No extranodal spread is seen.
I.  Sections of the omentum show no significant abnormality.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

-  Invasion to a depth of 24.5mm over a total wall thickness 25mm.
-  Cervical margin clear of invasive tumour by 10mm
-  Cervical margin clear of in situ tumour by 7mm
- One (1) of twenty-two lymph nodes involved with metastatic carcinosarcoma.

Specimen labelled "Pineal tumour", consists of a piece of brown coloured friable tissue/blood clot 25 x 18 x 12mm with fragments of pale tissue and blood clot 25 x 15x 5mm in total aggregate.  Block 1 - fragmented pale tissue and blood clot; 2-4 - nodular tissue. AE.   (TO: XA;GF/ec   16.5.64)
MICROSCOPIC: (Reported by Dr O Lunford & registrar Dr O Montero)

Sections show moderately cellular tumour growing mostly in solid sheets and in large lobules.  Thereis focal rosette formation.  The tumour cells are monomorphic with mildly atypical round to oval nuclei and stippled chromatin.  Mitotic figures are sparse, numbering up to 1 per 10 high power fields.  There is no necrosis.

The tumour cells stain positive for CD 56 and synaptophysin and there is focal filamentous positive staining for neurofilament.  The tumour cells do not stain for chromgranin A or GFAP.  The proliferation index with a Ki-67 stain is around 2%.

In view of diffuse growth pattern, focal staining for neurofilament and occasional mitotic figures, this tumour is best regarded as a pineal parenchymal tumour of intermediate differentiation (WHO grade 2).

A & B.  The sections of brain show sheets of highly atypical epithelial cells associated with abundant necrosis.  Islands of viable tumour cells are present in a perivascular location.  The tumour cells are arranged in solid sheets and there are so areas of pseudoglandular and papillary-like patterns.  There is marked nuclear pleomorphism and abundant mitoses, many of which are atypical.
No intracytoplasmic pigment is identified and no squamous differentiation is seen.

The tumour cells show strong positive staining for CAM 5.2 but are negative for GFAP, consistent with metastatic carcinoma.  There is also positive staining for Keratin 7 and Oestrogen receptor.  Progesterone receptor is negative and the Oestrogen receptor staining is weak and focal.  TTF-1, CEA, Keratin 20 and P63 are all negative.  The P63 stain shows positive nuclear staining in a minority of cells within the tumour.

The histological appearances are consistent with metastatic poorly differentiated carcinoma.  The presence of Oestrogen receptor staining raises the possibility of origin from breast or female genital tract amongst other sites.  Staining for CA125 and WT1 have been performed and are negative.  The CA125 shows very focal staining of uncertain significance.
The adjacent cerebral tissue shows changes suggestive of Congophilic angiopathy.

The tumour is composed of sheets and short fascicles of pleomorphic spindled and epithelioid cells as well as malignant multinucleated cellswith bizarre, hyperchromatic nuclei. Malignant melanoma shows invasion into underlying skeletal muscle but no connection to the epidermis is seen. No obvious lymphovascular or perineural invasion is identified.

However, lentiginous proliferation of these melanocytes is not seen. Subepithelial collections of lymphocytes are focally present but no definite features ofa regressed melanocytic lesion are identified.

Received from the SANDRINGHAM HOSPITAL Hospital MACKAY, 1 block labelled "09Y05113_B4".
The sample was reviewed by apathologist and was considered to have 50% tumour cells within the area selected for analysis.

The sample was analysed for mutations at or surrounding codon 600 within exon 15 of the BRAF gene encompassing the region containing 97% of all BRAF mutations, using high resolution melting (HRM) analysis (Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer [1]). Abnormal HRM traces are subjected to DNA sequencing for characterisation. This assay is capable of detecting BRAF mutations providing the mutant allele is present at a level of 10% or greater.
No BRAF mutation was detected at or surrounding codon 600 indicating that this patient will not respond to the current V600E specific BRAF inhibitors.

BRAF mutations are foundin 5-20% of colorectal cancers and 30-70% melanomas, in the majority of cases (90% in melanoma) the mutation results in the V600E protein change [1-2]. V600E specific BRAF inhibitors e.g. vemurafenib and dabrafenib have been developed toinhibit oncogenic BRAF in melanoma patients. Trials of these inhibitors have shown that melanoma patients with the BRAF V600K mutation may also benefit from treatment [3,4,5]. The presence of a BRAF mutation in colorectal cancer can be used to rule-out Lynch syndrome and it also indicates that the patient will be insensitive to EGFR inhibitors e.g. cetuximab [6].
Please note: Synonymous changes are not reported.

Reference articles: 1) Catalogue of Somatic Mutations in Cancer: http://www.sanger.ac.uk/genetics/CGP/cosmic/. 2) Garnett and Marais (2004) Cancer Cell; 6:313-319. 3) Chapman at al., (2011) N Engl J Med; (364)26: 2507-16. 4) Hauschild etal., (2012) Lancet; 380: 358-65. 5) Ascierto et al., (2013) J Clin Oncol 31: 3205-11. 6)Sharma et al., (2010) Arch Pathol Lab Med; 134:1225-1228. Reference Sequence GenBank Accession Number: BRAF NNM_004333.4.

Right hemicolectomy.  &gt;5cm margins.  Also liver resection.   Segment 2 &amp; 3.   Extended hemi-hepatectomy.

A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left liver resection and gallbladder&quot;, consists of a hemi-hepatectomy, 160 x 130 x 35mm, weighing 437g, and a separate gallbladder, 90 x 38 x 37mm.  The serosal surface of the liver is tan and smooth.  The main stapled liver resection margin is inked black.  On thin sectioning of the liver there is a well-circumscribed, roughly ovoid, pale grey tumour, 25 x 30 x 24mm.  The tumour is centrally necrotic and appears to focally extend to the margin.  The tumour is at least 4mm clear of the serosal surface of the liver.
The gallbladder has a blue/green, smooth serosal surface.  The wall thickness is 1mm and the mucosa is dark green and velvety.  There are no gallstones.
Blocks: 1 to 3 - liver tumour and margin; 4 &amp; 5 - composite full face liver tumour; 6 - liver distal to tumour; 7 - TS neck/cystic duct gallbladder, and LS fundus; 8 - mid TS gallbladder.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Segment 2 &amp; 3&quot;, consists of a wedge of liver, 74 x 32 x 9mm.  The serosal surface is tan and smooth.  The stapled surgical margin is inked blue.  On sectioning, there is a pale grey, firm tumour, 12 x 10 x 8mm.  The tumour is 9mm from the resection margin, and focally abuts the serosal surface.  The remaining hepatic parenchyma is tan and unremarkable.
Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - complete tumour; 3 - representative liver distal to tumour.

C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right hemicolectomy&quot;, consists of a right hemicolectomy including a  segment of large bowel (140mm length by 68mm circumference), terminal ileum (40mm length by 38mm circumference), appendix (52mm length by 8mm diameter) and mesentery (up to 70mm wide).  Adjacent to the ileocaecal valve (9mm distal) there is a firm, centrally ulcerated, circumferential tumour with raised edges, measuring 37mm in length.  The tumour is at least 50mm from both the proximal and distal resection margins.  On sectioning, the tumour extends through the bowel wall into the sub-serosa, with a separate 15mm diameter tumour deposit abutting the serosal surface.  The appendix has a pale grey and smooth serosal surface.  The wall thickness is 1mm.  Lymph nodes are identified.

Blocks: 1 - LS proximal surgical margin; 2 - LS distal surgical margin; 3 to 5 - tumour extension into adventicia; 6 - tumour (MSI); 7 &amp; 8 - tumour deposit abutting serosa; 9 - LS complete distal tip of appendix, and mid TS; 10 - apical vascular margin, apical lymph nodes as seen; 11 to 13 - lymph nodes as seen; 14 - single lymph node, bisected; 15 - single lymph node.

A.  Sections of liver show a deposit of metastatic well differentiated adenocarcinoma.  The tumour consists of glands lined by atypical columnar epithelial cells.  There is prominent associated necrosis.  The features are consistent with a metastasis from colon.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is identified.
Tumour appears to extend to part of the hepatic resection margin, in an area where the margin is disrupted (blocks A1, A2).
Tumour does not extend to the serosal surface.
A section of liver away from the tumour mass shows mild centrilobular congestion but is otherwise unremarkable; special stains will be performed and a supplementary report issued.
Sections of the gallbladder are unremarkable.

B.  Sections of liver show a deposit of well differentiated adenocarcinoma, consistent with a metastasis from colon.  There is associated prominent necrosis.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is identified.  The resection margin is free of tumour and tumour does not extend to the serosal surface of the liver.
Liver away from the tumour does not show any significant abnormality.

A. The sections of the tumour show areas of necrosis and prominent areas of haemorrhage. There is an oedematous stromal background in which sheets of highly cellular tumour are seen together with areas of nodular tumour. The tumour shows various morphologies including microfollicular pattern with Call-Exner bodies, gyriform and trabecular appearances and with somewhat organoid nests present. The cells are relatively uniform with round to ovoid morphology with some nuclear shape variation and with longitudinal nuclear grooves seen in many cells. Small nucleoli are present. There are up to 16 mitoses per 10 high power fields. Haemosiderin laden macrophages are also seen in the stroma. The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumour.
Immunohistochemistry (block A9). Calretinin, inhibin and WT1 are positive. EMA and AE1/AE3 are negative.

B. The sections show fibrofatty tissue including nodules of tumour similar to that seen in specimen A. The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumor. Immunohistochemistry (block B1): Inhibin and calretinin show focal weak staining. WT is positive. EMA and AE1/AE3 are negative.
C. The sections show omentum with reactive mesothelial cells and focal crushed groups of cells of uncertian significance. No diagnostic evidence of tumour is seen.
Comment: The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumor. Clinical correlation is recommended.

A.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left fallopian tube + ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube and a solid cystic ovarian mass, 55 x 45 x 30mm. The mass is adherent to the fallopian tube and has a smooth outer surface with some roughened areas. The cut surface shows a uniloculated cyst with papillary and solid areas. The solid area makes up approximately 20% of the mass. Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - fallopian tube with adherent ovarian mass; 3 to 10 - RS ovarian mass; 11 - biobank. RS. Shown to Dr Q Nipp.

B.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right tube + ovary&quot;, consists of a fallopian tube and ovary with attached ligament, 50 x 40 x 20mm. The fallopian tube is 60mm in length and up to 8mm in maximum diameter. There is a solid cystic mass, 10 x 7 x 6mm attached to the fallopian tube. The ovary measures 20 x 12 x 10mm. There is also another solid cystic lesion, 8 x 10 x 5mm attached to the ovary. The ovary has an unremarkable cut surface. Shown to Dr Q Manfre. Blocks: 1 to 8 - fallopian tube and ovary. RS.
C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right round ligament&quot;, consists of a tan to haemorrhagic nodular piece of tissue, 20 x 15 x 8mm. Sectioned and AE 2 blocks.

D.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right uterosacral&quot;, consists of a fragment of ligament and attached solid cystic mass, 40 x 20 x 18mm. The attached solid cystic mass is 25 x 20 x 15mm. Serially sectioned and AE 6 blocks.

E.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right rectal mass&quot;, consists of multiple fragments of friable, tan and fatty tissue, 90 x 65 x 30mm in aggregate. Shown to Dr Q Easdon. Unable to identify rectum in specimen. There are areas of haemorrhage but no obvious necrosis seen. Blocks: 1 to 4 - one almost complete face of tumour; 5 to 9 - further RS mass. RS.

F.  Specimen labelled &quot;Rectal tumour&quot;, consists of an irregular tan and haemorrhagic piece of tissue with attached adipose tissue, 60 x 20 x 18mm. Cut surface shows solid and papillary areas. Serially sectioned and AE 6 blocks.

G.  Specimen labelled &quot;Left rectal nodule&quot;, consists of a multinodular tan tissue with attached adipose tissue, 32 x 20 x 10mm. The cut surface is pale, firm and nodular. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.
H.  Specimen labelled &quot;Rectal mesentery&quot;, consists of an irregular tan and haemorrhagic piece of tissue, with attached adipose tissue, 30 x 20 x 13mm. Serially sliced and AE 2 blocks.

I.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid nodule&quot;, consists of a tan and haemorrhagic nodule with attached adipose tissue, 33 x 25 x 20mm. The nodule has a rough outer surface, and the cut surface shows a pale and uniform cut surface. Serially sectioned and AE 5 blocks. RS.
J.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid mesentery&quot;, consists of tan and haemorrhagic fibrofatty tissue, 23 x 15 x 8mm. Sectioned and AE 1 block.

K.  Specimen labelled &quot;Sigmoid epiploic&quot;, consists of a piece of fatty tissue with attache tan nodule, 33 x 20 x 10mm. There are multiple pale to tan nodules attached ranging from 3 to 10mm in maximum diameter. Serially sectioned AE 2 blocks.

L.  Specimen labelled &quot;Bladder nodule&quot;, consists of a fibrous piece of tissue with attached multinodular mass, 35 x 18 x 13mm. There is a multicystic mass measuring 10 x 6 x 7mm attached. Resection margin inked. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

M.  Specimen labelled &quot;Right common iliac lymph node&quot;, consists of haemorrhagic and fatty piece of tissue, 35 x 20 x 15mm. On sectioning, there does not appear to be a normal lymph node and appears to be a solid cystic nodule with about 50% of the nodule being solid and the solid areas also contain papillary areas as well. Shown to Dr Q Barcelo. Serially sectioned and AE 3 blocks.

N.  Specimen labelled &quot;Omentum&quot;, consists of a piece of fatty tissue with attached multiple solid cystic masses 340 x 340 x 45mm in total. There are up to nine solid cystic masses ranging from 25mm to 85mm in maximum diameter. The cut surface of the larger mass appears to be cystic and solid areas with necrosis. Shown to Dr Q Armon. Blocks: 1 to 10 - RS solid cystic mass. RS.
A. The left fallopian tube and ovary are widely replaced by High grade Serous carcinoma showing no convincing response to adjuvant therapy.

It is characterised by widely cystic papillary appearance with areas of more solid and micropapillary appearance and in other areas the tumour tracks through stroma associated with a desmoplastic reaction. Scattered calcifications are seen. The tumour shows variable pleomorphism including marked atypical cells and nucleoli. The fimbrial end is lined partially by tumour cells resembling the carcinoma in keeping with fallopian tube origin.
The ovary shows a corpus albicans.
B. The right ovary is involved by the carcinoma. Some mesothelial inclusion cysts and corpora albicantes are noted. The fallopian tube shows no in situ component.
C. The right round ligament is widely involved by carcinoma.
D. The right uterosacral fibrous tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.
E. The right rectal tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.
F. The rectal fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma. A focus is suspicious for lymphovascular invasion. An unremarkable lymph node is included (0/1).
G. The left rectal fibrofatty tissue is widely involved by carcinoma. Lymphovascular invasion is present.
H. The rectal mesentery fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.
I. The sigmoid fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma and extends into one lymph node (1/1).
J. The sigmoid mesentery fibrofatty tissue is widely involved by carcinoma.
K. The sigmoid epiploic fibrofatty tissue is involved by carcinoma.
L. The bladder nodule shows fibrofatty tissue and some columnar mucosa and is involved by carcinoma.
M. The right common iliac lymph node is widely replaced by carcinoma (1/1). The deposit is at least 14mm across and no convincing extranodal extension is seen.
N. The omental fibrofatty tissue is widely replaced by carcinoma.

B. Right tube + ovary: High grade Serous carcinoma.

A. The sections of the tumour show areas of necrosis and prominent areas of haemorrhage. There is an oedematous stromal background in which sheets of highly cellular tumour are seen together with areas of nodular tumour. The tumour shows various morphologies including microfollicular pattern with Call-Exner bodies, gyriform and trabecular appearances and with somewhat organoid nests present. The cells are relatively uniform with round to ovoid morphology with some nuclear shape variation and with longitudinal nuclear grooves seen in many cells. Small nucleoli are present. There are up to 16 mitoses per 10 high power fields. Haemosiderin laden macrophages are also seen in the stroma. The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumour.
Immunohistochemistry (block A9). Calretinin, inhibin and WT1 are positive. EMA and AE1/AE3 are negative.

B. The sections show fibrofatty tissue including nodules of tumour similar to that seen in specimen A. The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumor. Immunohistochemistry (block B1): Inhibin and calretinin show focal weak staining. WT is positive. EMA and AE1/AE3 are negative.
C. The sections show omentum with reactive mesothelial cells and focal crushed groups of cells of uncertian significance. No diagnostic evidence of tumour is seen.
Comment: The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumor. Clinical correlation is recommended.
A. RIGHT OVARY AND TUBE - ADULT GRANULOSA CELL TUMOR.
B. RIGHT PELVIC SIDEWALL - ADULT GRANULOSA CELL TUMOR.
C. OMENTUM - NEGATIVE FOR TUMOUR - SEE TEXT.

Right forearm lesion suture proximal.  Tissue biobanking.  Sarcoma - previous XRT.

Specimen labelled &quot;Right forearm lesion stitch proximal&quot;, consists of a 90 x 87 x 10mm somewhat circular excision of skin with a suture present towards one end as described and will be designated 12 o&apos;clock.  In the centre of the excision is a 50 x 43mm nodule.  Skeletal muscle is present on the deep surface.  3 o&apos;clock inked blue and 9 o&apos;clock inked black.  Specimen is sectioned from proximal to distal into nine slices.  There is a lobulated tan tumour 55 x 45 x 25mm.  The tumour is 22mm from the 3 o&apos;clock margin, 25mm from the 9 o&apos;clock margin and abuts the deep margin.  30% of the tumour is possibly necrotic and there are areas of myxoid change.  Blocks: 1 &amp; 2 - LS proximal; 3 &amp; 4 - tumour; 5 &amp; 6 - tumour; 7 - closest 3 o&apos;clock margin; 8 to 12 - full face slice 5 (8 - closest  9 o&apos;clock margin); 13 to 15 - tumour; 16 &amp; 17 - LS (distal); 18 - biobank.  See diagram.  (TO:YL/ec 28/9/72)

Sections show skin excised to include subcutaneous fat plus a small amount of underlying skeletal muscle. There is a lobulated and somewhat circumscribed cellular tumour centred in the subcutaneous fat. The tumour focally bulges into deep dermis. The superficial dermis, epidermis and skeletal muscle are uninvolved. The tumour is composed of compact fascicles of plump spindle cells with moderate amounts of lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, enlarged nuclei and one to two nucleoli. Mitotic figures are occasionally seen and focally number up to 4 per 10 HPF. Necrosis is not identified. There are moderate numbers of admixed inflammatory cells including lymphocytes, plasma cells and eosinophils within the tumour. The tumour also shows nodular areas of hyalinisation and myxoid change associated with foamy histiocytes and haemosiderin laden macrophages. These alteration is regarded as treatment related changes and is seen in approximately 60% of the tumour. No lymphovascular or perineural invasion is seen.
The tumour cells show the following immunoprofile:
-  Equivocal:  S100 (scattered tumour cells, no more than 5%) and Melan A (faint cytoplasmic staining in around 1% of tumour cells).
-  Negative:  MNF116, Cam5.2, CK5/6, SOX10, HMB45, MUM1, CD34, SMA, desmin, myogenin, STAT6, MUC4 and ALK.
Nuclear expression of H3K37m3 is retained.
The Ki-67 proliferation index is up to around 10% at hotspots by visual estimation.
The overall features are those of a malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with an undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.

The cellular tumour mass itself is 1 mm from the deep margin (Block 14). However, the tissue deep to the tumour has a paucicellular and loose myxoid appearance in which there are interspersed atypical cells . These cells may represent reactive atypia in benign stromal cells although tumour cells with treatment effect can show a similar cytology and as such, definite clearance of tumour at the deep margin cannot be guaranteed. This loose myxoid change is present at the deep margin over at least a 5 mm front (Blocks 13, 14 &amp; 15). The tumour mass and deep loose myxoid stromal change are &gt; 10 mm from all peripheral margins.
Excision of lesion, right forearm (post radiotherapy):  Malignant spindle cell tumour consistent with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma with treatment effect

A. Sections show fibrofatty tissue with large nerve bundles and one benign lymph node.

B. The biopsy shows a cross section of vas deferens which is attached to a large strip of densely fibromuscular tissue, probably representing a large vessel wall. There is an organising blood clot attached to the inner surface. A segment of large bowel muscularis propria is also attached to the outside of the specimen fibromuscular tissue.

C. The surface nodules are zones of diathermied liver capsule. The liver shows moderate macrovesicular steatosis in a centrilobular distribution. The identified lesions are all cavernous haemangiomas with identical features. They show ectatic dilated and interconnected blood channels which are separated by fibrous septa and are lined by a single layer of bland endothelial cells. The lesions are well circumscribed and there are no atypical features. There is no malignancy.

D. The bowel wall is unremarkable. The macroscopically described possible polyp is a zone of inspissated mucin mixed with mucosal fragments and cellular debris attached to the mucosal surface. The external surface of the bowel has an adherent strip of dense fibromuscular tissue, probably representing vessel wall, which pushes into the muscularis propria focally. It is associated with surrounding mesenteric fibrosis and it has an adherent organising blood clot. The vessel wall histology is altered by the fibrotic reaction. The blood clot extends into the wall of the bowel.  The mesenteric fat shows foreign body reaction to empty vacuoles and minimal suture material. There are two lymph nodes with no malignancy.
E. Five lymph nodes with no malignancy.

- Fibrotic probable vessel wall adherent to the muscularis propria of the bowel segment.

The section with gallbladder, it measures 70mm in length with a maximum diameter of 25mm. The serosa is smooth and unremarkable. The wall is up to 2mm thick. The mucosa is granular green in appearance. No stones are found within the lumen.
(1 cystic duct and neck of gallbladder; 2 body and fundus)
Omentum - It measures 410x150x30mm.  No suspicious areas are identified on sectioning or palpation.   (3&amp;4 RS of omentum)

Uterus with attached cervix. There is also attached posteriorly a segment of large bowel with one blind end and one open end.  The segment of large bowel measures 60mm in length with a maximum diameter of 25mm.  Distal margin is inked black, radial margin green.  On opening the lumen, it shows normal mucosal fold.  No discrete mass lesion is noted within.  Within the attached peritoneum is a plaque measuring 15x15mm (? tumour).  Also noted within the mesocolic fat are deposits of tumour with a mucinous cut surface.
(5 blind end of large bowel; 6 distal margin; 7-9 tumour deposits within mesocolic fat and peritoneum; 10-13 possible nodes [10 six nodes, 11-13 one node bisected each)

The uterus with attached cervix weighs 51g and it measures 75mm superior to inferior, 35mm intercornual distance. Ectocervix is 30x10mm with a slit like os 7mm.  Anterior endomyometrium measures 12mm, posterior endomyometrium 14mm.  Anterior is inked blue, posterior black. The serosa is smooth. Ectocervix is grey to cream coloured and unremarkable.  On sectioning through the myometrium no discrete lesion is identified.
(14 anterior cervix; 15 posterior cervix; 16 anterior and posterior endomyometrium; 17 cervix with attached peritoneum posteriorly)

The right ovary and fallopian tube together weigh 10g.  Fallopian tube measures 55mm in length with a maximum diameter of 10mm. The serosa shows multiple paratubal cysts.  They range from less than 1mm to 2mm.  Ovary measures 30x15x15mm.  On the serosal surface is possible mucinous deposits of tumour.  On sectioning through the ovary there is a 10mm cyst filled with gelatinous material.  (18 right fallopian tube; 19 right ovary)

The left ovary and fallopian tubes together weigh 9g. Fallopian tube measures 45mm in length with a maximum diameter of 6mm.  Ovary is 30x10x8mm.  The fallopian tube serosa shows multiple paratubal and parafimbrial cyst ranging from 2-6mm. On the serosal surface of the ovary is a possible mucinous tumour deposit.  On sectioning the cut surface is pale white and firm.  Underlying the area with the possible tumour deposit shows a mucinous cut surface.  (20 left fallopian tube; 21 left ovary)
Separate pieces of fibrofatty tissue some consistent with peritoneum, altogether measuring 150x80x40mm.  No suspicious areas are seen on sectioning.
(22&amp;23 separate pieces of fibrofatty tissue). RS (M-23)

C.  &quot;LEFT ARTERY LND&quot;.  Consists of a piece of fibrofatty tissue 50x50x20mm. Seven possible nodes identified. (1 six nodes; 2 one node bisected). RS (M-2/MC 30/6/2065 ank)

Mesocolic lymph node is negative for tumour (0/11).

- Right tube: Area of nodular fibrosis.
- Right ovary: Metastatic adenocarcinoma with mucinous features, moderately differentiated, similar appearance to mesocolic deposits, present over peritoneal surface and invading within ovary.

- Omentum: areas of surface fibrous scarring present.

There are no stones found within the lumen.
(1 cystic duct neck of gallbladder; 2 body and fundus).

(3&amp;4 sections of tumour attached to hilar fat; 5 capsular roughening [4 tumour block])

Right hemicolectomy - it comprises of terminal ileum, caecum and ascending colon with attached mesocolic fat.  Appendix is not present.  It measures 220mm in length (terminal ileum 75mm, ascending colon 150mm).  Proximal margin is 50mm distal margin, distal margin 40mm.  Attached mesocolic fat is up to 55mm wide.  The serosa shows areas of roughening.  On opening the mucosa shows normal mucosal folds. There is a possible polyp at the proximal ascending colon measuring 7mm maximum dimension.  No other discrete lesions are identified.  Proximal margin inked blue, distal black.

(6 proximal and distal margins; 7 polyp; 8 two sections through roughened serosa; 9 section through appendiceal orifice at caecum; 10-12 eight possible nodes [10 six nodes, 11&amp;12 one node bisected each])

The separate pieces of fibrofatty tissue consistent with peritoneum altogether measures 250x150x50mm.  The pieces are covered by a mucinous tumour deposit.  One of the fatty pieces is consistent with omentum and is covered by mucinous tumour deposit.
(13&amp;14 sections of peritoneum involved by mucinous tumour; 15 section of fatty tissue consistent with omentum).  RS (M-15)

D.  &quot;NODULE FROM BLADDER&quot;. Consists of a piece of fibrous tissue 10x7x4mm.  AE (1-1/MC 29/9/2068 ank)
A.  Paraffin sections show benign fibromuscular tissue.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

B.  Sections show involvement of the serosal surface of the neck of the gallbladder, the capsule and hilar aspect of the spleen, the serosal surface of the right hemicolectomy segment and fragments of peritoneum by low grade mucinous neoplasm (disseminated peritoneal adenomucinosis - Ronnett / low grade mucinous carcinoma peritonei - Bradley).

The involvement is characterised by numerous lakes of mucin dissecting through tissue planes.  Many of the mucin lakes are rimmed by atypical mucinous epithelium.  The tumour is overall of low to moderate cellularity, and there are two small foci of questionable destructive invasion interpreted as increased proliferation (block B15).  There are no definite high grade nuclear or architectural features and signet-ring cells are not seen.  Seven benign reactive pericolic lymph nodes are identified.

The parenchyma of the spleen is unremarkable.  The mucosa of the gallbladder shows features of mild chronic cholecystitis.  The small and large bowel mucosa sampled is unremarkable.  No polyps are identified in the segment of bowel.
Sections from the region of the appendiceal orifice shows irregular scar tissue in the submucosa and muscularis with occasional suture granulomas.
C.  Sections show one benign reactive lymph node.
D.  Sections show a portion of inflamed scar tissue with focal surface peritoneum.  The fibroblastic scar tissue includes clefts containing acellular extracellular mucin.

- INVOLVEMENT OF THE SEROSAL ASPECT OF THE HEMICOLON, GALLBLADDER AND SPLEEN
C.  LEFT ILIAC LYMPH NODE -  ONE BENIGN REACTIVE LYMPH NODE
- ORGANISING EXTRACELLULAR MUCIN WITHIN SCAR TISSUE.

A. &quot;OMENTUM, DIAPHRAGM, OVARIES, FALLOPIAN TUBES, RIGHT COLON, APPENDIX, CAECUM, PERITONEUM, PELVIC STRIP&quot;. Consists of appendix with attached bowel and surrounding fatty tissue, a segment of small bowel and large bowel with attached mesocolic fat, a strip of skin with underlying tissue, fragments of mucin, a detached ovary with fallopian tube, another possible ovary, gallbladder, omentum and fragments of peritoneum.

The appendix measures 50x45x30mm and is removed with a short 10mm wide cuff of caecum wall attached. The appendix has some surrounding fatty tissue. The appendix serosal surface is patchy brown and contains mucin. The cut surface of the appendix shows mucin in the lumen as well as thickened pale appendix wall. The lumen of the appendix is dilated to 20mm internal diameter.There is a possible fallopian tube attached next to the wall of appendix. (1-7  TS of appendix [6&amp;7  one full face]).
There is light brown mucinous material 50x30x12mm in aggregate. (8  mucin).

There is a long thin strip of skin 230x10mm with underlying fatty subcutis tissue up to 50mm in depth, with a 15mm-20mm strip of fibrotic fascia at the deep plane. There is a depression ?umbilicus or ?port site identified in the middle of the skin. There is a fibrous scar at the level of fascia running along the specimen, with thin black sutures. Skin surface is  unremarkable. One cross-section of umbilical skin and underlying tissue taken.

There is an ovary 25x18x13mm with attached fallopian tube 30x5mm. The ovary and fallopian tube outer surface and cut surface is unremarkable. The fimbrial end is unabled to be identified on the fallopian tube. The ovary weighs 1.9g. There is a separate possible ovary 11x10x8mm and weighs 0.6g.
(10  ovary [ovary all embedded]; 11  fallopian tube; 12  other possible ovary).

There are multiple fragments of peritoneum in aggregate 180x160x25mm, possible mucin identified on peritoneum surface. There are seperate brown tissues identified ? muscle ?diaphragm. One pale firm tissue identified ? ovarian tissue.
(13  peritoneal surface with possible mucin; 14  ?muscle ?diaphragm; 15  pale tissue ?ovary).
There is a 60x20mm opened disrupted gallbladder. Serosal surface is pale and shiny. Mucosal surface is green and velvety. No gallstones identified in the specimen.

There is a bowel segment consisting of small bowel 110x20mm joined with caecum 100x30mm with attached mesocolic fat 45mm wide. The serosal surface of small bowel and large bowel is roughened and patchy brown ?granulation tissue. Possible mucin identified on serosal surface. The mucosal surface of the small bowel and large bowel is unremarkable.
(17  small bowel; 18  large bowel; 19  one lymph node; 20  one lymph node; 21  five lymph nodes; 22  five lymph nodes).
There are multiple fragments of omentum in aggregate 340x140x20mm. No obvious tumour deposits identified.  (23-25  omentum). Representative sections. (M-25/SL 9/6/2070 km).

26,26 small and large bowel surface; 28-29 proximal appendix; 30 adjacent more proximal close to caecum segment; 32-32 section of mid-appendix with mucin on surface; 33 trimmed tissue from 33 - thick section; 34 tissue near appendix ?surface; 35-38 peritoneal tissue adhesions; 29 detached tissue fragment; RS LV

The appendix is involved in all areas by a low grade mucinous neoplasm (LAMN) forming a cystically dilated appendix mass. The LAMN shows fibrosis of the lamina propria and there is fibrosis and calcification of the appendix wall with lost of normal structures. The wall of the appendix is obliterated by penetrating mucin and neoplastic epithelium. There is extensive organising acellular mucin over the surface of the appendix. In two sections (4, 34), mucinous epithelium extends to the peritoneal surface of the appendix (pT4a).

There are numerous deposits of acellular organising mucin involving the surfaces of both fallopian tubes (one fallopian tube is attached to the appendix mass) ,  the surfaces of both  ovaries, the serosal surface of small and large bowel, with similar surface deposits over peritoneal tissue and omentum. The deposits have associated granulation tissue, fibrosis, calcification and in areas there is a foreign body giant cell reaction. The surface acellular mucin does not invade into subsurface tissue.
Sampled mesenteric lymph nodes are negative  (8 lymph nodes sampled).
The skin has a subsurface scar with sutures.
There is a focus of endometriosis within appendix muscularis propria.
(based on CAP 2018 guidelines, AJJC TMN 8th ed, and Pai review 2018)
Tumor size:  Greatest dimension 50 mm length, 20mm internal diameter
Histologic type:  Low-grade appendiceal mucinous neoplasm (LAMN)
Tumor extension:  Tumor (mucin and epithelium) invades the visceral peritoneum (serosa).
Appendix LAMN well clear of mucosal margins (colon and small bowel ends).
Mesoappendix margin probably involved (extensive surface mucin deposits)
Number of lymph nodes examined: 8 nodes sampled.
- DISSEMINATED PERITONEAL MUCINOUS DISEASE IS PRESENT;
- Deposits area acellular organising mucin, negative for identifiable mucinous epithelium;
Fallopian tubes x1, and surface involvement of other fallopian tube attached to appendix
Distant metastases other than peritoneum (histologically confirmed):  Not applicable
Additional pathologic findings:  Focus of endometriosis in appendix muscle wall.
Ancillary studies:  MMRP pending, block 5, appendix
The gallbladder is unremarkable. The skin has a subsurface scar with sutures.
PATHOLOGIC STAGE CLASSIFICATION (pTNM, AJCC 8th ed):  pT4a M1a

The AJCC eighth edition now defines M1a as intraperitoneal acellular mucin without identifiable tumor cells in the disseminated peritoneal mucinous deposits. There is limited literature data on the prognostic significance of acellular intraperitoneal mucinous disease The limited literature data suggest that patients with intraperitoneal acellular mucinous disease have a decreased risk of recurrence compared with patients with cellular disease and support the inclusion of a separate M category for intraperitoneal acellular mucinous disease.
- LAMN invades/penetrates through full thickness of appendix wall;
- mucin and neoplastic mucinous epithelium of LAMN involves appendix peritoneal surface.
- DISSEMINATED INTRAPERITONEAL ACELLULAR MUCINOUS DEPOSITS involving ovaries, fallopian tubes, peritoneal tissue, omentum, and surface of small and large bowel.
This is the normal pattern of MMRP staining.

A. Paraffin sections confirm the frozen section diagnosis of low-grade mucinous tumour. The distal appendiceal mucosa is replaced by mucinous epithelium characterised by mildly stratified basal columnar epithelial nuclei, apical cytoplasmic mucin, and flat to low villiform architecture. The mucosa is effaced, and in many areas, the mucinous epithelium rests on fibrotic tissue or muscularis propria. In the initial sections, there is a focal aggregate of organising mucin within the appendiceal fat. There is also focal mucin on the surface of the appendix which is not organising and is interpreted as surface contamination during specimen processing. There are no high-grade cytological or archictectural changes.
The remainder of the appendix will be embedded and a further report (including final classification and staging) will follow.

B. Sections show high-grade serous carcinoma partially replacing the ovary. The carcinoma is characterised by papillary and solid architecture with slit-like glandular spaces, high nuclear grade and risk mitotic activity. Scattered psammoma bodies are identified. There is focal ovarian surface involvement. There is no identifiable serous tubal intraepithelial carcinoma (STIC). The fallopian tube includes several cystic Walthard nests. The uninvolved ovarian parenchyma shows no specific pathology.
C. Sections show involvement of the fibroadipose tissue by deposits of high-grade serous carcinoma with appearances as described in Specimen B.
D. Sections show a lobule of adipose tissue with appearances in keeping with the clinical description of appendix epiploicae. There is no evidence of malignancy.
E. Sections show focal involvement of the fatty omental tissue by high-grade serous carcinoma.
- LOW-GRADE MUCINOUS TUMOUR, ORGANISING MUCIN WITHIN MESOAPPENDIX. NO ORGANISING MUCIN IDENTIFIED BEYOND THE SEROSAL SURFACE, FINAL REPORT TO FOLLOW.
B. RIGHT OVARY AND FALLOPIAN TUBE
- HIGH-GRADE SEROUS CARCINOMA INVOLVING THE OVARY.
A. The remainder of the appendix has been embedded.

As in the initial sections, there is evidence of mucin dissection through the muscularis propria to the level of peri-appendiceal fat, but not beyond the serosal surface. No mucinous epithelium or organising mucin is identified beyond the appendix.
The features are those of a low grade mucinous neoplasm of the appendix (LAMN, PSOGI classification). pT3, pNX, pMX (AJCC, 10th edition)
p53 - completely negative (consistent with high grade tumour)

A. The base of the appendix has been all embedded and sections show unremarkable colonic mucosa forming the mucosal lining. The low grade appendical neoplasm is well clear of the base of appendix margin.
- LOW-GRADE MUCINOUS TUMOUR OF THE APPENDIX (LAMN), ORGANISING MUCIN WITHIN MESOAPPENDIX. NO ORGANISING MUCIN IDENTIFIED BEYOND THE SEROSAL SURFACE, CLEAR OF BASE OF APPENDIX MARGIN.
B. RIGHT OVARY AND FALLOPIAN TUBE
- HIGH-GRADE SEROUS CARCINOMA INVOLVING THE OVARY.

The appendix is involved in all areas by a low grade mucinous neoplasm (LAMN) forming a cystically dilated appendix mass. The LAMN shows fibrosis of the lamina propria and there is fibrosis and calcification of the appendix wall with lost of normal structures. The wall of the appendix is obliterated by penetrating mucin and neoplastic epithelium. There is extensive organising acellular mucin over the surface of the appendix. In two sections (4, 34), mucinous epithelium extends to the peritoneal surface of the appendix (pT4a).

There are numerous deposits of acellular organising mucin involving the surfaces of both fallopian tubes (one fallopian tube is attached to the appendix mass) ,  the surfaces of both  ovaries, the serosal surface of small and large bowel, with similar surface deposits over peritoneal tissue and omentum. The deposits have associated granulation tissue, fibrosis, calcification and in areas there is a foreign body giant cell reaction. The surface acellular mucin does not invade into subsurface tissue.
Sampled mesenteric lymph nodes are negative  (8 lymph nodes sampled).
The skin has a subsurface scar with sutures.
There is a focus of endometriosis within appendix muscularis propria.
(based on CAP 2018 guidelines, AJJC TMN 8th ed, and Pai review 2018)

The AJCC eighth edition now defines M1a as intraperitoneal acellular mucin without identifiable tumor cells in the disseminated peritoneal mucinous deposits. There is limited literature data on the prognostic significance of acellular intraperitoneal mucinous disease The limited literature data suggest that patients with intraperitoneal acellular mucinous disease have a decreased risk of recurrence compared with patients with cellular disease and support the inclusion of a separate M category for intraperitoneal acellular mucinous disease.
- LAMN invades/penetrates through full thickness of appendix wall;
- mucin and neoplastic mucinous epithelium of LAMN involves appendix peritoneal surface.

B.  COLON, SPLEEN, SMALL BOWEL AND OMENTUM - MODERATELY DIFFERENTIATED ADENOCARCINOMA WITH METASTASES TO OMENTUM, SPLENIC SEROSA, AND PERITONEAL ADIPOSE TISSUE.
Immunostains for MSI proteins (Sprint Nextel Corporation Orana; block: B13)

Absence of staining for either MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSH-H), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair enzyme.
Positive staining of a carcinoma for MLH1,  PMS2,  MSH2  and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

The antibodies used are not fully characterised for routine diagnostic use. Results may be affected by storage and fixation of specimens, and should be interpreted in conjunction with other investigation, including MSI testing where possible.

A. UTERUS, BILATERAL TUBES AND OVARIES

The frozen sections were difficult to assess, and not contributory, with the diagnosis at frozen section uncertain. The paraffin sections show a partly solid and partly cystic ovarian epithelial tumour. There are areas with a sex-cord/stromal like growth pattern. The more solid area show endometrioid carcinoma with a dense fibrous stroma. The larger cyst locules have nonspecific appearance mainly mucinous lining. The softer and partly necrotic areas within the mass show poorly differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma with sarcomatous stroma (carcinosarcoma), with focal chondrosarcomatous heterologous differentiation. There is tumour necrosis and there is perivascular sparing of tumour. The epithelial areas and sarcomatous areas both have brisk mitotic activity (50 mitoses /10 hpf).
The tumour does not appear to involve the surface of the ovary.
The disrupted area described macroscopically has tumour exposed to the open disrupted surface.

The carcinoma invades into the posterior myometrial wall in the area where the tumour is adherent (depth of invasion into myometrium is appropriately 6 mm), and invades focally into attached adipose tissue over what appeared to be the anterior surface.
Excision margins (paracervical, anterior attached fat) are negative for tumour.

The tumour stains with keratin CK7 and PAX8. CK7 stains most area of the tumour (3+) including moderately differentiated epithelial areas and poorly differentiated areas and there is some probable positive staining in sarcomatoid areas.
The undifferentiated areaS shows weak staining with Cam 5.2.
Inhibin and calretinin show very focal weak positive staining of uncertain significance
TTF-1 shows focal positive (3+) staining in a small area of the poorly differentiated area of the tumour. The larger cyst locules are TTF1 negative.
ER and PR are negative, p53 shows nonspecific mainly negative staining
The endometrium is inactive and atrophic.
The uterine surface shows some fibrous adhesions.
There is occasional endosalphingiosis. No endometriosis seen.
Left and right fallopian tubes shows no abnormality.
Right ovary shows some surface adhesions.
Two lymph nodes are present. No tumour seen.
The omentum shows no tumour involvement.
I have shown sections of the left ovary tumour to other pathologists in the department who agree with the diagnosis.

A. The sections of the tumour show areas of necrosis and prominent areas of haemorrhage. There is an oedematous stromal background in which sheets of highly cellular tumour are seen together with areas of nodular tumour. The tumour shows various morphologies including microfollicular pattern with Call-Exner bodies, gyriform and trabecular appearances and with somewhat organoid nests present. The cells are relatively uniform with round to ovoid morphology with some nuclear shape variation and with longitudinal nuclear grooves seen in many cells. Small nucleoli are present. There are up to 16 mitoses per 10 high power fields. Haemosiderin laden macrophages are also seen in the stroma. The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumour.
Immunohistochemistry (block A9). Calretinin, inhibin and WT1 are positive. EMA and AE1/AE3 are negative.

B. The sections show fibrofatty tissue including nodules of tumour similar to that seen in specimen A. The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumor. Immunohistochemistry (block B1): Inhibin and calretinin show focal weak staining. WT is positive. EMA and AE1/AE3 are negative.
C. The sections show omentum with reactive mesothelial cells and focal crushed groups of cells of uncertian significance. No diagnostic evidence of tumour is seen.
Comment: The appearances are those of adult granulosa cell tumor. Clinical correlation is recommended.

A. The sections show a tumour with variable appearances including cystic spaces lined by columnar mucinous epithelium with a fibrous and oedematous stroma. In several areas, there is multi-layering with highly atypical epithelium and numerous mitotic figures indicative of intraepithelial carcinoma. In other areas, confluent, glandular and papillary architecture with high-grade cytology is identified and associated with necrosis within gland lumina and also with broad areas of tumour necrosis. A desmoplastic stromal reaction is not seen. The appearances are those of mucinous adenocarcinoma with expansile pattern invasion. No mucin is seen on the surface of the ovary.
B. Sections of the fallopian tube show normal appearing epithelium. On the serosal surface, there is prominent macrophage and chronic inflammatory reaction. Negative for malignancy.

C. The sections show omentum with prominent macrophage and chronic inflammatory reaction on the serosal surface and subserosal connective tissue. Possible focal surface acellular mucin is seen in the PAS-D stain. Negative for malignancy.
D. One lymph node is identified and shows reactive changes. Negative for malignancy.
E. The sections show lymph node with reactive changes. Negative for malignancy.

F. Sections show fatty tissue with prominent macrophage reaction of the serosal surface with reactive mesothelial hyperplasia and with underlying chronic subserosal chronic inflammation. Negative for malignancy.

G. The sections of the fallopian tube are unremarkable. The ovary shows a hyalinised and partly calcified nodule which is consistent with ovarian fibroma. There is also a cyst lined by a cuboidal to attenuated simple epithelial layer including occasional ciliated cells and the appearances are those of benign serous cystadenoma. Benign serous inclusions are also seen within the ovarian cortex. On the serosal surface of the ovary and fallopian tubes, there are macrophage reaction and mesothelial reaction with patchy subserosal chronic inflammation. Negative for malignancy.

Immunohistochemistry (Block A14): There is strong staining for both CK7 and CK20 but with greater staining for CK7. CDX-2 shows very focal staining. PAX-8 shows non-specific staining only. ER and PR are negative CEA is positive.

Comment: The appearances of the right ovary are those of a moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma with expansile pattern invasion. No ovarian surface involvement is identified in the sections examined. There is prominent macrophage reaction on the serosal surfaces of the omentum, the appendicae epiploicae and the left ovary and fallopian tube and with possible focal acellular mucus on the omental surface that suggests possible previous rupture/leakage of the cystic tumour. Clinical correlation is recommended.
A. RIGHT OVARY - MUCINOUS ADENOCARCINOMA (WITH PATTERN EXPANSILE INVASION).
- BENIGN FIBROMA AND BENIGN SEROUS CYSTADENOMA.

(1 larger lymph node trisected; 2 second smaller lymph node quadrisected).  AE (M-2).

C.  &quot;PELVIC SENTINEL LYMPH NODE, LEFT&quot;.  A piece of fibrofatty tissue up to 25x10x8mm, containing one lymph node 18x6x3mm, cut into five transverse sections and serially all embedded in one block.  AE (5-1).
D.  &quot;OMENTUM&quot;.  A piece of fatty tissue 80x30x10mm.  There are no palpable nodules or lymph nodes within the specimen.  Sampled omental roll in two blocks.  RS (M-2/MY 7/5/2066 nh)
Tumour type:  Serous carcinoma (with background endometrioid carcinoma with mucinous differentiation- see comment)
Tumour involves: The carcinoma involves a large endometrial polyp and also adjacent endometrium of the fundus of the uterus
Vascular/lymphatic invasion:  Focally present in the polyp
Involvement of uterine serosa:  Not present
Total number:  3 (2 right pelvic sentinel nodes and 1 left pelvic sentinel node)
Other tissues:  The omentum (D) is not involved by malignancy.

Comment:  The large endometrial polyp contains foci of high grade serous carcinoma over the surface of the polyp and adjacent glands with small focal areas of adjacent stromal invasion in the polyp with focal lymphatic vascular invasion. Serous carcinoma is also seen within the adjacent endometrium of the fundus of the uterus where there is very focal early stromal/myometrial invasion (0.5mm, block 6). Serous carcinoma shows positivity for P53, WT1, P16, ER (20% 2-3+).  Additionally within the polyp there is background of a lower grade endometrioid carcinoma with mucinous differentiation, grade 2 which comprises about 75% of the tumour volume, with serous carcinoma about 20%. There is also a small focal area of more solid malignancy with increased mitoses which lies within the polyp and adjacent endometrium of the uterus within a 4mm area (&lt;5% of the tumour, block 9). This small focus retains cytokeratin expression favouring a diagnosis of poorly differentiated/ de-differentiated endometrioid carcinoma.

Absence of staining for either MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSH-H), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair enzyme.
Positive staining of a carcinoma for MLH1,  PMS2,  MSH2  and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

The antibodies used are not fully characterised for routine diagnostic use. Results may be affected by storage and fixation of specimens, and should be interpreted in conjunction with other investigation, including MSI testing where possible.

Sections of the uterus show an invasive endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma with patchy mucinous differentiation.  The tumour  invades into the outer half of the myometrium, 20.5mm through a wall of 25mm thick.   In some areas the tumour shows a melting pattern of invasion.  Extension of tumour into foci of adenomyosis is also seen.  The carcinoma shows FIGO grade 1 architecture and is composed of complex glandular and papillary structures lined by stratified columnar epithelium with grade 2 nuclei (overall FIGO grade 1).   There is patchy  intracytoplasmic as well as extracellular mucin.  Three foci of lymphovascular are present (block 16).   The tumour does not invade the cervix and is well clear of the inferior margin.  The uninvolved endometrium is essentially inactive. The uterus also shows multiple leiomyomas.  The left fallopian tube contains patchy mild chronic inflammation including occasional lymphoid aggregates underlying the epithelium, including reactive lymphoid follicles.  The right fallopian tube is unremarkable.  The left and right ovary shows senescent changes only.

Sections of pancreas show a 16mm grade 1 (low grade) neuroendocrine tumour composed of nest and cords of neoplastic cells.  The neoplastic cells have salt-and-pepper chromatin and granular eosinophilic cytoplasm.  There is less than one mitosis per ten high-power-fields, and the Ki67 index is less than 2%.  No perineural or lymphovascular invasion is identified.  There is no necrosis.  The tumour is positive for CD56 (strong and diffuse), chomogranin A (moderate and diffuse), synaptophysin (weak and patchy), and insulin (moderate and diffuse).  The CD34 stain is negative. The tumour is 4mm from the (closest) anterior surface, 8mm from the portal vein margin, 11mm from the posterior surface, and 12mm from the SMA/uncinate margin.  The stomach and small bowel margins are well clear.  Additionally, there is a separate 1.1mm neuroendocrine microadenoma located 5mm from the (closest) posterior surface.  Twenty (20) lymph nodes are negative for tumour.  The adjacent pancreas shows patchy autolytic change and the gallbladder mucosa is extensively denuded.  The omentum shows no significant abnormality.
- Grade 1 (low grade) neuroendocrine tumour, consistent with insulinoma in the appropriate clinical context, clear of margins
Further information supplied by Dr P Grunwald (endocrinologist):  Clinically the tumour is a proinsulinoma rather than insulinoma.

Sections show fatty connective tissue with an overlying layer of peritoneal mesothelium. The subsurface tissue is extensively involved by an infiltrative malignancy which has a predominantly cystic pseudoglandular architecture. The spaces are lined by large epithelial cells with moderate amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm and eccentric nuclei. The nuclei show variable atypia. There are some papillary structures present. In intervening stromal tissue there is a patchy chronic inflammatory infiltrate and there are some aggregates of foam cells. There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes. The subsurface epithelial proliferation merges with overlying mesothelial cells. Some cells contain cytoplasmic vacuoles.
The histologic features are consistent with MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA.
There is deep invasion of subsurface fat by mesothelioma.
B. Uterus, Bilateral Tubes And Ovaries:

- Ectocervical mucosa is normal. Endocervical mucosa is normal. The endometrium is inactive and there is focal inactive adenomyosis present. There is a small intramural leiomyoma. The serosal/peritoneal surface of the uterus shows no abnormality.
- The right ovary has some surface fibrous adhesions and small microcalcifications within granulation tissue. There is reactive mesothelial hyperplasia.
- The right fallopian tube shows no significant abnormality.

- The left ovary shows areas of surface reactive mesothelial hyperplasia, and some small surface fibrous adhesions and granulation tissue. Within the granulation tissue, there are embedded aggregates of psammoma bodies.
- The left fallopian tube shows no significant abnormality.
Tumour is not identified in this specimen.

Sections show fatty subperitoneal tissue with a surface layer of peritoneal mesothelium. There is a subsurface partly solid and partly cystic mass with a papillary, solid and pseudoglandular architecture of similar appearance to the tumour in specimen A (MESOTHELIOMA). The subsurface lesion has an invasive growth pattern and involves much of the specimen. The cells have a variable decidoid appearance. There is a stromal inflammatory infiltrate of small lymphocytes in areas and some xanthoma cells. Some psammoma bodies are present. There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes.  The tumour invades some attached skeletal muscle in one  section (C7). There is overlying mesothelial hyperplasia, fibrous adhesions and areas of granulation tissue and in some areas there are aggregates of psammoma bodies.
The omental tissue contains deposits of MESOTHELIOMA.
Sections show fatty tissue with MESOTHELIOMA. There are also some aggregates of foamy histiocytes and cholesterol crystals and moderate numbers of psammomatous calcifications.
Sections show subperitoneal fatty tissue with subsurface involvement by MESOTHELIOMA.
There is deep invasion of subsurface fat.

Sections show fatty tissue with involvement by MESOTHELIOMA. There is deep invasion of subsurface fat. There are some sheets of foamy histiocytes associated with the tumour and a patchy chronic inflammatory infiltrate of small lymphocytes and plasma cells. The tumour cells have a decidual appearance.
Other suitable block for testing: A2
Positive: WT1, Podoplanin (D2-40), calretinin, CK5/6 (all 3+ positive)
Negative: CD31, MOC-31, CEA, PAX8, ER, TTF1, CEA.
BAP1: Immunohistochemical loss of nuclear staining

The Immunohistochemical profile is consistent with mesothelioma. Immunohistochemical loss of nuclear BRCA-associated protein 1 (BAP1) is a highly specific marker of malignancy in mesothelial lesions. In the current case there are other diagnostic features of malignancy (in particular deep invasion of subsurface tisssues).
- Invasion into subsurface fat (at least 20mm depth). Focal invasion of skeletal muscle in right diaphragmatic wall specimen (?focal diaphragm invasion)
- Not applicable, but tumour involves margins of some pieces.
- I am unaware of an agreed formal staging system for peritoneal mesothelioma.
- There are moderate numbers of tumour infiltrating lymphocytes (TILs) in most areas of the tumour.
- MMRP deficiency is rare in mesothelioma and has not been tested.
- Tumour tissue is retained if testing for other biomarkers is required.

The distal pancreas is entirely embedded and examined.  Within the distal tail of the pancreas there is a 10mm tumour composed of a moderately cellular arrangement of malignant spindle cells.  The spindle cells display predominately moderate but scattered highly pleomorphic forms with hyperchromatic vesicular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli.  There are numerous mitoses including atypical forms.  The tumour has a fascicular arrangement arrangement and there are patchy areas of both hyalinisation and necrosis, involving about 20% of the tumour compatible with a treatment response.    The tumour has both an infiltrative as well as pushing border and at focally there is a thin fibrous pseudocapsule.  There are patchy areas of oedema and occasional vessels within the tumour show fibromyxoid intimal change compatible with previous treatment.  Apart from focal PanIN-1, the pancreatic parenchyma is unremarkable.  The tumour cells do not appear to arise from vessel walls.  The tumour is well clear of the pancreatic resection margin and appears confined to the pancreas.  The spleen is unremarkable and uninvolved.  Sixteen lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy (0/16).
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive: SMA, Desmin and P63 (patchy weak)
Negative: Myogenin, AE1/AE3, CK5/6,  CD34, EMA, CD117, SOX10, HMB45.
The tumour Ki67 proliferation index is approximately 60%.

The tumour is well clear of the pancreatic resection margin.  The tumour is 1.4mm from the posterior pancreatic surface, 3mm from the anterior pancreatic surface and about 9mm from the inferior edge.  No lymphovascular invasion or perineural invasion is seen.

The morphology and immunoprofile is consistent with leiomyosarcoma.  The history of a soft tissue leiomyosarcoma in the right thigh is noted.  In this context the tumour within the tail of the pancreas is consistent with a metastasis from the that tumour.
TAH, BSO omentectomy.  Likely ovarian cancer.

C.  Specimen labelled &quot;Uterus, cervix, sigmoid colon&quot;, consists of a uterus with attached cervix and a segment of sigmoid colon with peritoneum.  The uterus measures 65 x 40 x 23mm and has a smooth shiny serosal surface anteriorly and a roughened surface posteriorly.  The ectocervix measures 25 x 25mm and has an unremarkable surface.  It is inked blue anteriorly and black posteriorly.  On sectioning, the endometrium is generally less than 1mm in maximum thickness and the myometrium is 13mm in maximum thickness.  A 5mm cream nodule is present on the endometrium at the posterior fundus.  The left and right adnexa are both markedly ragged with no macroscopically identifiable ovaries or fallopian tubes.  Attached to the right lower uterine segment and cervix is a sheet-like 100 x 90mm portion of peritoneum which is predominately smooth over the anterolateral surface and ragged on the posterior aspect.  There is a 25 x 15 x 13mm papillary lesion with surrounding foci of calcification on the posterior aspect of the peritoneum.  The sigmoid colon is 190 x 30mm with mesocolon to a maximum width of 20mm.  The serosal surface is roughened with patchy calcification and scattered nodules.  The margins of the bowel are inked: proximal blue and distal black.  On opening, the colonic mucosa is smooth and tan with two firm submucosal nodules in the mid portion.  The first nodule (proximal) is 15 x 15mm and is present 75mm from the nearest surgical margin (distal).  The second nodule (distal) is approximately 12 x 13mm and is 50mm from the nearest surgical margin (distal).  The serosa overlying these nodules has a calcified plaque 20 x 25mm.  The muscularis propria at the proximal colonic margin also appears thickened with scattered foci of calcification.  No mucosal lesion is seen at this site.

Blocks: 1 to 3 - full LS of anterior body and cervix; 4 to 6 - full LS posterior body and cervix (4 - with 5mm cream nodule); 7 to 10 - serial sections of left adnexa; 11 to 14 - RS right adnexa; 15 &amp; 16 - RS peritoneal thickening and papillary lesion; 17 - LS distal colonic margin; 18 &amp; 19 - paired blocks, LS of two submucosal nodules (18 - distal; 19 - proximal with green ink on proximal cut surface); 20 - greatest serosal involvement of colon; 21 - LS of proximal colonic margin with muscularis propria thickening; 22 - possible apical lymph node; 23 - four possible lymph nodes; 24 - four possible lymph nodes; 25 - three possible lymph nodes.

A, B.  Sections show a serous tumour with papillary, micropapillary and cribriform architecture.  The tumour cells have mild and moderate cytologic atypia.  Numerous psammoma bodies are noted.  The tumour is predominantly a low grade serous carcinoma but there is also a component with features of a serous borderline tumour.  A minority of the tumour shows infarct-like necrosis.  No normal ovarian tissue is seen.

Sections of the endometrium show a small endometrial polyp at the fundus.  The endometrium is otherwise inactive and unremarkable.  The myometrium is unremarkable.  Sections show deposits of low grade serous carcinoma, with associated fibrous stroma, on the serosa of the anterior and posterior uterus.

Sections of left adnexal tissue show involvement by low grade serous carcinoma.  The left fallopian tube is identified and is unremarkable but the surrounding soft tissue is extensively involved by low grade serous carcinoma.

No ovarian tissue is identified in the sections of the adnexae.
Sections of the peritoneum attached to the uterus and colon segment show extensive involvement by low grade serous carcinoma.

Sections of the described submucosal nodules in the colon segment show low grade serous carcinoma on the serosa and invading into muscularis propria and submucosa of the bowel wall.  The proximal and distal excision margins of the colon segment are free of tumour.

Sections of nine lymph nodes which were found in the bowel mesentery show partial involvement of five of these nodes by serous tumour; in the context of the other specimens these deposits are consistent with metastatic low grade serous carcinoma.  Occasional extranodal tumour deposits are also noted in the mesentery.

E.  Sections show fibrofat with extensive involvement by low grade serous carcinoma.  All the tissue has been blocked and no appendix is identified.
F.  Sections of each donut show unremarkable large intestinal wall.  No tumour is seen.
Representative slides have also been viewed by Dr X Gerlock.

There is no evidence of malignancy.

The fallopian tube shows broadening and fusion of the plicae with a mild inflammatory infiltrate composed of aggregates of foamy histiocytes, lymphocytes and plasma cells.  The degree of inflammation is milder compared to specimen A.  Both the ovary and tubal serosa show patchy haemorrhage.  A benign paratubal cyst is present.  The ovarian parenchyma shows no specific abnormality.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

C.  The endometrial curettings show detached strips of benign glandular epithelium and fragments of ectocervical squamous epithelium.  There is insufficient intact endometrium for assessment.  There is no evidence of malignancy.

Sections show fibroadipose tissue containing a large artery as well as medium sized nerves.  Within the fibrous tissue there is proliferation of disorganised nerve bundles associated with fibrosis.  The appearance is compatible with a traumatic neuroma.  In the adjacent tissue there is a granulomatous reaction to foreign material consistent with suture granulomata.  There is focal chronic inflammation.  No evidence of malignancy is seen.  No evidence of tumour is seen.

C.  One lymph is almost completely replaced by  metastatic neuroendocrine tumour.  The tumour shows is composed of epithelioid cells with round relatively uniform nuclei with granular to vesicular chromatin, variably present small nucleoli and a moderate amount of amphophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests/trabeculae with focal tubule formation.  Mitoses number up to
9/10hpf and the Ki67 proliferation index is 8%.  Extranodal extension is not seen.
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive: Synaptophysin, Chromogranin (patchy), Glucagon  (sparse patchy), Somatostatin (sparse patchy) and CD56.
The deposit shows similar morphology to the primary pancreatic tumour and initial locoregional metastases and is consistent with metastatic pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour, grade 2.

A.  The oesophageal tumour is a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. A synoptic report for oesophageal carcinoma follows:
Histologic grade: Grade  2- 3 (Moderately to poorly differentiated) (49% or less of the tumour composed of glands)
Note: tumour focally is present between outer layers of muscularis propria, where the deeper muscle is focally deficient. However, no diagnostic extension beyond the outer muscle layer is seen (A30).
Lymphatic and capillary space invasion: Not identified.
Vein and artery space invasion: Not identified.
Grade 3: Absent response &#8211; Minimal or no tumour kill; extensive residual cancer.
Background changes consistent with neoadjuvant therapy present.
Distance of carcinoma to proximal margin: 40mm
Distance of carcinoma to distal margin: 38mm
Distance of carcinoma to radial/circumferential margin: 3.3mm.
Donut: Not involved (see specimen D and E).

The squamous mucosa shows patchy active inflammation with associated atypia which is indefinite for dysplasia. The gastric mucosa shows extensive moderate active chronic gastritis with foci of intestinal metaplasia. No definite Helicobacter organisms are seen.

The atypical epithelium extends focally to the diathermied margin. No definite Helicobacter organisms are seen. No intestinal metaplasia is identified. There is no evidence of malignancy.
