A.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show core biopsies of pancreatic tissue.  There is marked acinar atrophy with replacement dense hyaline type fibrosis. There is background retention of a lobular architecture however interspersed amongst the dense fibrous tissue are occasional atypical tubular glands. The glands show  mild to focally moderate nuclear pleomorphism which is difficult to assess in a frozen section sample.  Features often associated with carcinoma in core biopsy samples such as nuclear size variation of 3:1, conspicuous macronucleoli, disrupted glands, perineural invasion, necrosis in lumina are not definitively present, however the glands are atypical and the context of the appearances seen in specimen B likely represent well differentiated adenocarcinoma.

B.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show a wedge of pancreatic tissue which is partially infiltrated by a well differentiated invasive adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows an infiltrative pattern amongst background pancreatic parenchyma which shows variable acinar atrophy.  The glands are tubular with focal secondary lumina and are lined by cells with minimal or mild nuclear pleomorphism and a small to moderate amount eosinophilic cytoplasm.  No morphological evidence of intestinal differentiation such as goblet cells or Paneth cells are seen.  There is associated fibromyxoid desmoplastic stroma and foci of perineural and intraneural invasion are also seen.  No associated extracellular mucin is present.  The sample includes uninvolved pancreatic parenchyma and the ducts here do not show evidence of high grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN).  No lymph nodes are identified.  No definite lymphovascular invasion is seen.
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

C.  Paraffin sections of the specimen examined at the time of intraoperative frozen section consultation show oedematous fibrovascular cores surfaced by variably ciliated Mullerian type epithelium showing hierarchical branching.  Although some of the papillae appear unsupported they are not four times as high as they are wide.  Nuclear atypia is mild to moderate.  No features of microinvasion are seen. The features are those of a low grade serous borderline tumour.

D.  Sections of ovary show invasive adenocarcinoma.  Differentiation varies with predominantly well to moderate differentiation and a minor poorly differentiated component.  The tumour is composed of tubular and cribriform glandular structures within a moderately cellular oedematous desmoplastic stroma.  In addition to small tubular and cribriform structures the tumour also contains a component of more cystically dilated glands a proportion of which are lined by very bland or mildly atypical simple or stratified columnar mucinous epithelium. Expansile nodular or intracystic papillary growth is not seen.  Some of the cystically dilated areas show higher grade nuclear atypia. Whilst the tumour mainly shows destructive stromal invasion with associated desmoplasia, some area including the cysts are associated with ovarian stroma in a pattern resembling an ovarian mucinous borderline neoplasm  with and without intracystic carcinoma .  The poorly differentiated component comprises minor foci (less than 5%) in which there is either single cell infiltration or signet ring-like differentiation (eg D8, D16, D18).  No associated extracellular mucin deposition to indicate pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  No microscopic surface mucin, or surface deposits are seen. Two small areas of surface disruption are noted.    Occasional glands contain necrotic luminal debris which are predominantly of inflammatory cells with some associated necrotic epithelial cells. Invasive adenocarcinoma involves the fallopian tube with invasion of the wall from the serosal surface (D18, D20) reaching the mucosa at the fimbrial end (D21) .  There is focal endometriosis close to the fallopian tube (D21). The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and no serous tubular carcinoma in-situ is seen.  No benign Brenner component is seen. The ovarian hilum is not identified.
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the tumour cells stain as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.

E.  Sections of uterus show metastatic adenocarcinoma seenpredominantly surface deposits on the anterior surface (E4).  Adenocarcinoma is also present in the vicinity of the right cornua (E10) and close to the posterior peritoneal reflection (E12).  The carcinoma shows similar morphology to the pancreatic and ovarian disease.   There are also foci of endosalpingiosis (eg E5, E7) as well as endometriosis (E13).  The uterus shows a couple of fibroids (E14, E1) and is otherwise unremarkable. The endometrium is predominantly basal but appears inactive.  The ectocervix and and endocervix are uninvolved and unremarkable.

F.  The right ovary is extensively sampled and the attached fallopian tube including fimbrial end entirely embedded and examined.  Sections of ovary confirm a surface serous low grade borderline tumour associated with psammomatous calcifications as well as multiple deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The adenocarcinoma shows similar features to that seen in the left ovary and pancreas.  The deposits are seen on the surface of the ovary and also as a single expansile nodule. The expansile nodule shows areas in which the malignant glands are present with  ovarian stroma as well as areas with stromal  desmoplasia. The surface deposits which show similar cytomorphology are present amongst desmoplastic stroma.  The glands show a tubular and cribriform morphology with some poorly differentiated areas with single cell growth (eg F6).  No pseudomyxoma ovarii is seen.  Metastatic moderate to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma is also seen within the right ovarian hilum (F11).  Definite lymphovascular invasion is not identified.  Foci of endometriosis are also seen (F11).The right fallopian tube is entirely embedded and examined and is unremarkable and uninvolved.
In the presence of positive and adequate controls the adenocarcinoma stains as follows:
Positive:  CK7 (&gt;50%), CK20 (&gt;50%), CK19 and CDX2
Negative: ER, PR, WT1 and PAX8.
In contrast to the adenocarcinoma the serous borderline tumour shows typical expression for PAX8, WT1, CK7, ER and PR. CK19 is also positive while CK20 and CDX2 are negative.

G.  Sections of omentum show multiple foci of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar morphology to that seen within the ovaries and pancreas. The carcinoma is composed of small tubular and cribriform glands within a desmoplastic stroma and is seen on the serosal surface associated with mesothelial cell reaction.  Scattered foci of psammomatous calcification are seen both in the vicinity of tumour and separately.  Foci of endosalpingiosis are also seen (G5 and G6). One lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).

H.   Sections of peritoneal lined adipose tissue show several deposits of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma shows similar morphology to that seen within the pancreas and ovaries. The carcinoma is composed of surface deposits within desmoplastic stroma. The carcinoma appears well to moderately differentiated with well formed tubular or cribriform glands.  One small lymph node shows no evidence of malignancy (0/1).
I &amp; J.  Sections of fibroadipose tissue show a deposit of metastatic adenocarcinoma with similar features to that seen in the other sites.  The carcinoma is well to moderately differentiated.

The adenocarcinoma present with the right ovary, uterus, omentum, peritoneal nodule , right side wall and bladder peritoneal nodule is consistent with metastatic disease with predemoniantly surface deposits.  The morphology  of the adenocarcinoma in the pancreas, in the limited sample, is well differentiated but shows  morphogical features, including perineural invasion, dense hyaline stroma and small tubular glands compatible with pancreatic primary. High grade pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia is not seen, in the limited sample. The right ovary shows features of (mucinous) adenocarcinoma with varying differentiation (predominantly well to moderate with minor poorly differentiated areas). Areas in the ovarian tumour resemble the pancreatic tumour albeit with some cystic areas and minor poorly differentiated areas in the  more representative ovarian sample.  The presence of bilateral ovarian involvement , extensive intraabdominal disease, destructive stromal reaction in the left ovary and presence of single cells are features that would favour metastatic pancreatic adenocarcinoma to the ovaries in this case. However as the left ovary is very large, has a smooth external surface, lacks expansile nodular growth or surface deposits and shows some areas with bland mucinous epithelium resembling an ovarian borderline mucinous neoplasm, the possibility of synchronous pancreatic and ovarian primaries cannot entirely be excluded.  The presence in the left ovary  of a minor component of relatively bland mucinous tumour is not a helpful discriminator,  as metastatic adenocarcinoma from the pancreas to ovary is a great morphologic mimic of primary ovarian mucinous neoplasm including benign and borderline mucinous neoplasms.   The immunoprofile or the tumour in the pancreas and right and left ovaries (CK7, CK20, CK19 and CDX2 expression) is identical and consistent with intestinal type differentiation.  In the absence of PAX8 expression ( seen in only about 30% of primary ovarian mucinous adenocarcinomas but not in pancreatic primaries)  the immunoprofile is not helpful in determining origin of the disease.  This expression profile could also be seen in other upper gastrointestinal tract primaries.  The immunoprofile, with diffuse CK7 expression argues against appendiceal origin, although examination of the appendix (not received) would be beneficial for completeness.   Selected slides of this case have been seen in consultation with Dr J Moniot who favours a pancreatic primary with metastatic intraabdominal disease including to the ovaries. Dr Gonzalo comments that the morphology in the larger left ovary, with extensive stromal desmoplasia, is more typical of metastatic disease and that intraabdominal metastatic disease from the ovary, including to the pancreas would be exceedingly rare.  Correlation with the disease biology and preoperative imaging features of the pancreatic tumour (eg vascular and nodal involvement) is essential in this case.
-    Atypical mucinous epithelium which in this context is consistent with adenocarcinoma.
D.  Left ovary and fallopian tube (including frozen section):
-    Adenocarcinoma within ovary and fallopian tube (see comment).
F.  Right ovary and fallopian tube:
-    Ovarian low grade serous borderline tumour.
The findings were discussed with Drs J Godown &amp; J Grinage and  Profs. J Dudycha and J Ulses.

Peritoneum. Gallbladder. Spleen. Rt colon. Rectosigmoid. Small intestine. Omentum.

A. &quot;ILEOCAECAL MASS&quot;. Consists of a right hemicolectomy. There is a mass in fat at ileocaecal junction with involved nodes. No appendix identified. Frozen section from ?ulcer in terminal ileum and one lymph node.
F/S: &quot;Adenocarcinoma with signet ring cell features. No appendix identified&quot; per phone to Dr. C Blott by Dr. C. Eastlick on 1/1/67.

Further macroscopic decription after fixation. The specimen consists of a right hemicolecotmy specimen, with colon, measuring 135mm in length and 65mm in open-diameter. The ileum measures 62mm in length and 30mm in open diameter. There is up to 85mm of attached mesentery. There is a tumour present which appears to be based in the caecum, 30x20x20mm. It abuts the serosal surface as well as the black inked soft tissue, retrocaecal margin. It is located 50mm from the proximal margin and 100mm from the distal margin. The proximal and distal staple margins are inked green and removed. The retrocaecal soft tissue margin is inked black, and the roughened serosal surface overlying the other aspect of the caecum is inked blue. There are numerous serosal deposits, 1-3mm, throughout the specimen. The appendix cannot be identified.

(3 longitudinal proximal and distal margin; 4 first apical node; 5 second apical node, trisected; 6 third apical node; 7-9 composite section of tumour, show mucosa and serosa; 10 bisected longitudinal section from mucosa through the serosa; 11 tumour and black inked soft tissue margin; 12 serosal deposit; 13 tumour towards ileum ?continuation of tumour; 14 further section of tumour and serosa; 15 one lymph node; 16 one lymph node; 17 two possible lymph nodes or possible areas of serosal deposits; 18 one lymph node; 19 two serosal deposits; 20 one lymph node; 21 one lymph node). RS (M-21/ LK/cy)
B. &quot;DIAPHRAGM, OMENTUM, PERITONEAL DISEASE, SPLEEN, SMALL BOWEL, COLON&quot;.

There is a gallbladder, 80x40x15mm. The serosal surface is predominantly smooth and shiny with an area of brown discoloration 15mm in maximum extent, adjacent to the bare area. The cystic duct margin is inked blue. The mucosal surface is green and velvety and shows cholesterolosis. No gallstones are present. The average wall thickness is 2mm.

(1 shaved cystic duct margin TS of gallbladder body showing area of brown discoloration and LS fundus; 2 two adjacent sections to the cystic duct margin showing gallbladder neck and possible cystic duct node).

The spleen is present 105x65x15mm and has attached fatty tissue, presumed omentum, 150x100x80mm. The trimmed weight of spleen is 148g. There are pale fibrous thickened areas of the capsular surface of the spleen between the spleen and the adjacent fatty tissue ?tumour. The attached fatty tissue is firm to palpation and infiltrated by areas of white fibrous tissue ?suspicious for tumour in addition bright yellow areas ?fat necrosis.
(3-5 sections of spleen; 6&amp;7 fatty tissue ?omentum and tumour).

There is a section of bowel, with circumferential ring of soft tissue at one end presumed to be rectum, 300mm in length and 45mm in opened circumference. There are fibrous adhesions between the presumed distal and proximal margins, causing the specimen U-shaped. Also attached to this specimen is mesentery up to 80mm in extent in addition to grey fibrous tissue ?peritoneum possibly including muscle also, 230x120x12mm. The presumed perirectal soft tissue margin is inked green. Sectioning reveals that there is a pale band of tumour connecting the rectum and more proximal bowel.

(8&amp;9 composite section between rectum [B8] and more proximal bowel [B9]; 10 rectum, and tumour abutting green perirectal margin; 11 rectum and attached fibrous tissue and tumour; 12 two sections from attached fibrous tissue ?peritoneum and tumour).

Two further separate segments of colon, one measures 115mm in length, and 55mm in open circumference with up to 35mm of attached mesentery. The other measures  110mm in length, 60mm in open circumference with up to 30mm of attached mesentery. The first of these displays oedematous and haemorrhagic mucosa but no other significant abnormalities. The second of these also shows oedematous mucosa and possible peritoneal deposits.

(13 two sections of haemorrhagic oedematous mucosa and section of possible peritoneal disease from the first segment of bowel; 14 two sections of second segment of bowel showing peritoneal disease and underlying colonic mucosa).

There is a segment of small bowel 430mm in length and 55mm in open circumference. There are three sutured areas, which appear to be corresponding to defect in the small bowel wall, possibly iatrogenic or possible perforation.
(15 TS through each of the sutured areas; 16 section of peritoneal deposit and section of separate peritoneal deposits with underlying lymph nodes).
There is a further small segment of possible colon, 70mm in width and 30mm in length. There is a sutured line present along one edge 60mm in length.
(17 RS of this separate piece of possible colon).

The remaining pieces of tissue are unorientated pieces of fibroadipose tissue resembling parts of omentum and peritoneum 20-120mm in size and 280x240x40mm in aggregate. There are innumerable tumour deposits both on the surface of and within the areas of peritoneum and presumed omentum.
(18 three RS of peritoneal involvement; 19 tumour and peritoneum; 20 tumour and greater omentum [this is the designated block for tumour banking]). RS (M-20/LK/ht).
Operation type:  Right hemicolectomy (Specimen A) - Appendix not identified.
Radial:  0mm, abuts black inked retrocaecal soft tissue margin
Tumour description:  Pale, exophytic and endophytic
Lymph nodes: Abnormal: suspicious: pale, firm, enlarged
Comments on macro: Appendix not identified.

A.  Sections show poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with glandular and signet ring differentiation arising in the region of the ileocaecal valve and extending right through colonic and ileal wall to involve the serosa and free mesothelial surface. The rest of the colonic wall shows no focal abnormality. The tumour shows extensive lymphovascular invasion. No large vein invasion is seen. Seven out of ten lymph nodes examined show metastatic adenocarcinoma. The apical lymph node is not involved by adenocarcinoma. Numerous deposits of extranodal adenocarcinoma are present within  the mesenteric fat. In addition there appears to be extension of the adenocarcinoma to the caecal soft tissue resection margin. The proximal and distal resection margins are clear of any lesions. Immunoperoxidase staining of the tumour shows positive staining with CK 20, CK 7, CDX2 and CEA.

Sections show disseminated poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with signet ring and intestinal differentiation involving adipose tissue attached to gallbladder, splenic capsule including involvement of a splenic hilar lymph node, serosa of separately submitted segments of small bowel and colonic segment including colonic wall and submucosa.

Metastatic adenocarcinoma is also seen in separately submitted peritoneal fragments, omentum and subcutaneous tissues with overlying unremarkable skin. The gallbladder mucosa and wall show no focal abnormalities. The cystic duct lymph node is unremarkable. The colonic mucosa and small bowel mucosa show no focal abnormality. The splenic parenchyma is unremarkable.
Sections through gastric body shows metastatic adenocarcinoma involving adipose tissue attached to serosa without involvement of gastric wall.

In view of the large ileocaecal mass, this may represent the primary tumour although the morphology is unusual. Origin from upper GI tract is also possible. Clinicopathological correlation is recommended.
- POORLY DIFFERENTIATED ADENOCARCINOMA WITH SIGNET RING AND INTESTINAL DIFFERENTIATION.
DIAPHRAGM, PERITONEAL DISEASE, SPLEEN, SMALL BOWEL COLON:

- POORLY DIFFERENTIATED ADENOCARCINOMA WITH SIGNET RING AND INTESTINAL DIFFERENTIATION INVOLVING OMENTUM, PERITONEUM, SPLENIC CAPSULE, SEGMENTS OF SMALL BOWEL AND COLON AND ADIPOSE TISSUE ATTACHED TO GALLBLADDER AND SEGMENT OF STOMACH.
Immunostains for MSI proteins (MACQUARIE WARD NORMANTON HOSPITAL; block: A8)

Absence of staining for either MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 or MSH6 is associated with microsatellite instability phenotype (MSH-H), and may reflect the presence of a germline mutation or somatic inactivation of that mismatch repair enzyme.
Positive staining of a carcinoma for MLH1,  PMS2,  MSH2  and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.

The antibodies used are not fully characterised for routine diagnostic use. Results may be affected by storage and fixation of specimens, and should be interpreted in conjunction with other investigation, including MSI testing where possible.

Colonic carcinoma.  Confirmed on colonoscopy.  Lap R hemicolectomy.  No Mets, no perforation.  NB:  Specimen received fresh.  Small pieces sampled and stored for Biobanking on 25/05/2015 at 17:10hr by AU.

Specimen labelled &quot;Right hemicolectomy&quot;, consists of right hemicolectomy specimen measuring 130mm in length, consisting of 50mm of terminal ileum incontinuum with 110mm of caecum and ascending colon.  There is attached appendix measuring 50mm in length with an outer diameter of 4mm.  Mesocolon measures up to 50mm.  Situated 75mm from the proximal resection margin, 40mm from distal resection margin is a plaque like lesion measuring 35mm x 30mm occupying 90% of the open luminal circumference.  The tumour is on the mesenteric surface.  The serosal surface shows fat wrapping around the tumour area.  The rest of the serosal surface is unremarkable.  On sectioning the tumour invades through the muscularis propria into fat.  Several lymph nodes identified.

Blocks: 1 - Proximal and distal resection margin; 2 - RS of normal terminal ileum; 3 - RS of normal colon; 4 &amp; 5 - appendix (block 4 longitudinal sections of base + one TS); 5 - two longitudinal sections of tip plus one TS; 6 to 9 - full profile of tumour; 10 to 12 - RS with deepest invasion; 13 to 25 - lymph node (13 - one lymph node; 14 - one lymph node; 15 - one lymph node; 16 - one lymph node; 17 - one lymph node; 18 - one lymph node; 19 - one lymph node; 20 - one lymph node; 21 - one lymph node; 22 - one lymph node; 23 - lymph nodes as seen; 24 - one lymph node; 25 - one lymph node).
MICROSCOPIC (Reported by A/Prof D Scobie and Dr D D Toren):
Distance of tumour to nearer cut end: 40mm ( distal margin)
Histological measurement from tumour to non-peritonealised margin:  0.5mm (12)
Carcinoma is seen wrapping around nerves within the main tumour mass, but no distant perineural invasion is identified.
Sections of the appendix show sessile serrated adenoma. No evidence of malignancy.
Preserved nuclear staining of a carcinoma for MLH1, PMS2, MSH2 and MSH6 indicates a low likelihood of microsatellite instability phenotype.
- 35mm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma clear of resection margins
- 0.5mm clearance of tumour from the non peritonealised surface.
